PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 22 May, on motion by Mr Keating:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand it is the wish of the House to debate this order of the day concurrently with orders of the day Nos 2 to 4. There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are again discussing tax and tomorrow we will also be discussing tax.
—About time.

—The honourable member says: `About time'. We have been discussing tax since 19 September last year, when the Government produced its tax package. We have been waiting eight months for Bills to be introduced. Bills have been introduced into the Parliament without explanatory memoranda. Honourable members opposite who say it is about time we discussed tax should go to the Bills and Papers Office and ask for a copy of the explanatory memorandum for the capital gains tax legislation; it has been eight or nine months in preparation and is not ready. The Opposition got a proof copy of the explanatory memorandum for the capital gains tax legislation from the Treasurer (Mr Keating) after we kicked up a fuss about it last week in the Parliament and on national television. The legislation comprises 103 pages and the explanatory memorandum comprises 150 pages or so. It is still not available for honourable members who have to discuss the legislation tomorrow. The way in which this Government has been handling these tax measures is an absolute disgrace.

SPEECH.PARA: That is not the end of it. We have had before the Parliament, since the 19 September so-called reform statement of the Treasurer, an additional 625 pages of taxation legislation, on top of the original 1,100 pages in the taxation Act. Since the so-called reforms of 19 September we have had a 57 1/2 per cent increase in taxation law. Some reform indeed! The latest package of measures was introduced in the House late on Thursday night-at 8 o'clock, to be precise. No detailed explanatory memoranda have been provided for the capital gains tax legislation, the Taxation Laws Amendment (Foreign Tax Credits) Bill or the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2). An explanatory memorandum has been provided only for the Taxation Boards of Review (Transfer of Jurisdiction) Bill, which is one of the measures being considered this morning.

We regard this as being totally unsatisfactory. If this Government wishes to get some sort of community acceptance for its taxation measures, if it is to live up to its original claims that it would take the community into its confidence by holding a national taxation summit, having discussions with interested groups and proper consideration by the Parliament, it must not introduce legislation on a Thursday night without providing explanatory memoranda, expect the Opposition to consult with its advisers over the weekend, to have a shadow Cabinet meeting on a Monday, and then come into the Parliament on a Wednesday and Thursday to discuss 275 pages of complicated legislation. That is not good enough. It is an abuse of the Parliament, it is an insult to the Australian people, and it is typical of the way in which the Treasurer of this Government works.

I have been a member of this House for about eight years now, and during that period I have seen Treasurers under two governments. I do not think that anyone could possibly say that the former Treasurer, the present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), treated the House with the contempt with which the present Treasurer treats the House. This is quite unconscionable. We lodge the strongest possible protest. I have to qualify my remarks today as the lead speaker for the Opposition in the House of Representatives-which requirement is a disgrace-by saying that these 275 pages of legislation will require considerable additional study before they go to the Senate, because there may well be things in them the full explanation for which we do not understand. We have not had a chance to consult external advisers to any degree. The whole of the business community, the whole of the taxation accounting community and the whole of the legal fraternity that has to worry about these things have been waiting around for eight months to look at the detailed proposals, have had them, and have had no chance to pass any comment on them before they have to be debated in the House of Representatives. That is a national disgrace. The way in which this Treasurer handles these matters is a cause of grave censure.

At Question Time in the House on Friday, the Treasurer made remarks about my failure to attend a briefing which had been organised on Friday morning. Let me come back to that, because this is one of those smart responses from this arrogant Treasurer, and just what he does has to be exposed. Unlike the previous Treasurer, the present Treasurer refused briefings on taxation Bills to the Opposition. It is outrageous behaviour within a parliament to refuse access to officials to discuss the technical aspects of taxation legislation. I know of no examples under the previous Government where such briefings were refused, but they were refused arrogantly and contemptuously by the present Treasurer.

I raised this matter, as did my colleague in the Senate, Senator Messner. We created a fuss about it. There was some public pressure about it. Then the Treasurer decided, on Thursday night, that a briefing would be made available to us at 11 a.m. on Friday. It so happened that it was absolutely impossible for me, because of unbreakable previous commitments, to attend that briefing. The Leader of the Opposition and I arranged for our respective staff officers to attend the briefing, which they did. We were thankful for it-except that it was in the context of having 275 pages of legislation dumped on us the night before at 8 p.m., to be considered over the weekend. What chance did we have to consider that in great detail? Actually, I will qualify that. We got advance copies at about 4 o'clock in the afternoon on Thursday, so we had from about 4 o'clock until midnight to look through the 275 pages. Anyone who knows about tax legislation will know that that is not simple. Then we were required to attend on the Friday morning. Maybe something could have been arranged over the weekend to bring in the officers concerned, but we have our commitments back in our electorates, and we needed also some time for reflection over Saturday and Sunday-which all of us spent working the whole time on the wretched things. It was, therefore, really a very meagre concession by the Treasurer to arrange that briefing.

Following that, on the Friday, at Question Time, the Treasurer got stuck into the shadow Treasurer for not attending that briefing. I reject totally any charge that I was acting improperly or not taking advantage of an offer. Really, this fellow must be exposed. I understand that he treats the Caucus in the same way as he treats this Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.

—The honourable member says that he does not. I have talked to many of your colleagues, my dear fellow, who make it clear to me, and have told me, that many of the ways in which the Treasurer treats us in this House are nothing like the way that he treats some of his colleagues in the Caucus-and I know it from them.
—Nonsense; arrant nonsense.
—Do not try to tell me that.
—Order! The honourable member will speak through the Chair.

—These people opposite, Madam Speaker, know exactly what happens, and many of them have told me what happens. Okay; that is the way that the Government handles these tax measures. Let me deal with the Opposition's response to the particular measures that we are looking at this morning. We are looking at the Taxation Laws Amendment (Foreign Tax Credits) Bill, which the Opposition will be opposing.

SPEECH.PARA: We are looking at proposals for taxation boards of review in the Taxation Boards of Review (Transfer of Jurisdiction) Bill. We have grave doubts about whether or not it has been adequately discussed in the Parliament and throughout the community. We do not believe that it has been properly examined, and we seek to have the passage of that measure through the Parliament delayed to allow proper consideration by interested bodies. It proposes a major change which I will speak about later. If we are unsuccessful in having it delayed, we may well feel bound to oppose it in the Senate, but we will put to the Government the proposal that it be left for further consideration and not be introduced on the proposed date. We will not oppose the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) except for one clause, clause 4, which relates to the secrecy provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act. I will explain exactly why later. We will not oppose the Income Tax (Securities and Agreements) (Withholding Tax Recoupment) Bill, which is a fairly technical matter of imposing a tax under other measures.

Let me deal first with the proposal for the transfer of jurisdiction from the taxation boards of review to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. It is really a fundamental change in the way in which taxation appeals are heard. It arises out of the recommendation of the Administrative Review Council in June 1983. It is proposed that the provisions in the Bill will take effect from 1 July.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a very short time.

—A very short time is allowed. The honourable member for Denison quite correctly expresses his concern about this matter. There is a very serious concern on the part of the Government and the Australian community over the immense backlog in dealing with appeals under the taxation Acts. This is causing very great concern because people are in a state of anxiety and uncertainty. If they have had an assessment rejected or amended and they wish to appeal, they may well be held up for a couple of years. In the meantime, they have to pay tax, they have to pay interest and so on. It is obviously a very burdensome matter, particularly for taxpayers and also, of course, for those who have to administer the Acts.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill proposes to amend a number of Federal taxing Acts and the most significant of these is the Income Tax Assessment Act. The amendments will abolish the taxation boards of review and transfer their jurisdiction to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. A Taxation Appeals Division will be created, and existing board members may transfer to that Division if they so wish. The Commissioner of Taxation will be allowed to extend the current strict 60-day limit for lodging and objection, and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal or the Supreme Court will be allowed to extend the time for lodging an appeal against the Commissioner's decision to disallow an objection. There is a plan to have more uniformity in the appeal process of Federal tax laws, and the objection and appeal process of the sales tax is to be brought more into line with the comparable income tax provisions. We do not quarrel with that.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no quarrel with that lot.

—I acknowledge the interjection of the honourable member for Hawker. There is quite a lot of useful stuff in this Bill. I am not putting up the Opposition's concerns about this issue in any adversary way at all.
—I have had concerns the same as yours, I must confess.

—I thank the honourable member for Hawker. We have a sincere concern about certain aspects of this measure which we think require further consideration in the Parliament and in the community. Let me say what some of those concerns are. The first one is that a board of review currently has three members. It will be possible under the Administrative Appeals Tribunal system to have just one member sitting on a board. That member may be an officer or a former officer of the Australian Taxation Office. Although it would obviously speed up procedures if many more people were sitting individually and it would get rid of the backlog, there is concern that the rights of a taxpayer presenting an appeal might be somewhat more restricted if there is an individual commissioner hearing that appeal. If that commissioner has had a background within the Taxation Office, there might be a concern, without any disrespect to any individual officer-I am not implying that-that that person, when looking at the appeal, having spent a life as a gamekeeper, so to speak, and seeing the poacher come up before him, might have a somewhat more strict view of that appeal than would an independent taxation person or somebody from the outside community who is unrelated to the process. That is one concern.
—Caesar unto Caesar.

—Yes, Caesar unto Caesar, as my friend the honourable member for Denison so correctly points out. That concern is magnified by the fact that the appeal procedures are being altered quite considerably. I have a chart here which shows the income tax objection and appeal process that exists currently. It is quite complicated but the key point is that 97 per cent of appeals which go to a higher process go to a board of review; some 3 per cent go direct to the Supreme Court but I will not talk about those. If the appeal is not agreed to there is an appeal to the Supreme Court; following that there is an appeal by leave to the Federal Court of Australia and there can be an appeal by special leave in the most exceptional cases to the High Court of Australia. That is the current appeal procedure. First, there is a board of review with three members; secondly, appeal to a Supreme Court; thirdly, appeal by leave to the Federal Court; and finally, appeal by special leave to the High Court.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposed system is that the appeal will go to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, which could have only one member sitting, and then there is an appeal to the Federal Court only. There is no higher appeal beyond that. That is a very severe restriction on the rights of appeal. Perhaps there is a case for this which is more evident than that in the explanatory notes we were given on Thursday afternoon, but we do not believe that a change of this kind should be introduced by 1 July without a great deal more public discussion. That is just one aspect of the matter.

Also, there is a limitation on objection rights. Objection rights against an amended assessment are to be limited to the particular amendment; that is, the amendment of the original assessment. Appeals from the AAT will be to the Federal Court and will be only on the actual point of law upon which the appeal is lost. Previously a taxpayer could appeal to a Supreme Court from a board of review and virtually have a rehearsing of the whole case. That is quite an important restriction because the original ground might not be the most important one. If an appeal is considered by the Supreme Court after a hearing by a board of review and if there is a capacity to examine the whole case and not a very narrowly constrained set of arguments, obviously that is of much greater benefit to the taxpayer and the taxpayer's civil liberties will be better looked after.

On our reading of the legislation, it appears that under the proposed system, unlike the present system, in which the Department has to give the taxpayer reasons for amendment of the assessment-and those can be thought about by the advisers to the taxpayer before the board of review hears the matter-the Commissioner is not obliged to give reasons to the taxpayer before the AAT hearing. If our reading of it is correct-perhaps we have misread it but I do not think we have-we do not like it at all. It has been argued that most of the reasons that must be given by the Commissioner are relatively unimportant, that there is a great deal of junk, so to speak, in what is given, but the important reasons are also given at present. The fact that these might not be available to the person lodging the objection until the AAT hearing strikes us as a denial of basic rights and therefore we would like to have that looked at again.

TALK.START.PARA: —How can one draw a notice of appeal if one does not know the reasons?

—That is correct. As the honourable member says, how can one draw a notice of appeal if one does not know the reasons for the rejection of the claim? The next problem we have is the provision for the Attorney-General to intervene in cases of public interest. We would like to know a little more about that. Currently a person who lodges an appeal is up against the Commissioner, but he is not also up against the Attorney-General.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill provides for the Attorney-General to get into the act as well. So it is two against one. Maybe there are very sound reasons for that which go beyond the notes that we have been given. However, we have some concerns about this provision.

We also have concerns based on reports from people who have appeared both before boards of review and before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Unless some considerable change were made in the taxation division of the AAT, we would be concerned about the additional formality of the AAT system compared with the current system of boards of review. Boards of review hearings are held in a relatively informal and quite speedy way. Those who have appeared before both types of bodies inform me that there is a great deal more formality in AAT procedures. Indeed, some of the speeding up which might be hoped for under this change might not eventuate unless there is a rather substantial change in the way in which the hearings are conducted.

I do not have a great deal of time in this debate, but I think I have raised most of the points I wanted to put. I think I have raised sufficient points of query, worry and concern on quite fundamental issues to suggest that it really is not satisfactory to introduce a Bill of this complexity on a Thursday night, rush it through the Parliament on the following Wednesday, have it through the Senate within a week or two and bring it in on 1 July 1986. We do not think that is on. We sincerely ask the Government to reconsider that program. Certainly, if it does not, we will feel obliged in the Senate to try to seek support at least to hold it up.

I now turn to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1986, which contains a number of amendments on deferred interest security, interest withholding tax and a variety of other matters which we are not opposing. However, I would like to pick out one matter about which we are very concerned. There is a proposal to relax the secrecy provisions to permit the Commissioner of Taxation to communicate information on superannuation funds to the Secretary to the Treasury or any new authority created for the purpose of supervision or regulation of superannuation funds. It is stated that the decision as to whether certain responsibilities will be transferred will be made prior to the Budget sittings. No detail has been provided for the reasoning for this proposed change. This is a quite extraordinary provision. The Parliament is being asked to allow the Commissioner of Taxation to pass secret information about superannuation and taxation matters to another person or to a body not yet formed. Although we know who the present Secretary to the Treasury is, we would have grave doubts about transferring that information to the Secretary to the Treasury as such.

We are being asked to agree to the relaxation of the secrecy provisions to allow passage of information to a body not yet formed. This is absolutely not on. We cannot do that. We will vote against that clause. We want to know who or what it is that we are providing this secret information to. That is an incredible proposal. We do not know whether a body will be set up under Gough Whitlam, Al Grassby--

TALK.START.PARA: —Or Malcolm Fraser?

—Or Malcolm Fraser, or maybe Garry Weaven of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. Mr Weaven has a great interest in superannuation. He is the fellow who is rushing around at the moment clobbering all the employers on superannuation matters. Maybe the Government has a proposal to make Garry Weaven the head of a new body to regulate superannuation. The Opposition has absolutely no intention-I hope that the Government will accept the reasonableness of this proposition-of buying this pig in a poke. We will vote against that clause.

SPEECH.PARA: Another little quite entertaining admission which is tucked away in this Bill is the provision to remove the need for signing of receipts et cetera, required after 30 June 1986 as part of the new substantiation rules, recognising, of course, the total unreality of having all receipts or invoices signed by the supplier when this is not normal business practice. In other words, under the proposals put up under the fringe benefits tax and superannuation rules, which in the case of the entertainment tax Bill that we dealt with a few months ago involved some 20-odd pages, one would have to have one's service station receipts, for instance, signed. All sorts of other fiddling receipts would have to be signed. This is the first admission publicly by this Government that its substantiation and fringe benefits tax rules are unworkable. We predict that this will be the first of a whole lot of backdowns of this kind. If there are not backdowns of this kind these matters will have to be cleared up by the incoming Liberal-National government.

I turn to a very important aspect of this legislation, the Taxation Laws Amendment (Foreign Tax Credits) Bill. Let me deal with it in the limited time I have available. I might say that, as with other major areas of legislation, we still do not have any explanatory memorandum for this Bill. I have been given an explanatory memorandum for the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1986 but I think that is the one I already have. We still do not have the explanatory memorandum for the Taxation Laws Amendment (Foreign Tax Credits) Bill. It is a very important measure and it is having quite a deleterious effect on business investment by Australian companies abroad. Broadly speaking, what happens at the moment is that a company receiving income from an overseas subsidiary pays tax on that income in the other country and that is taken as being the tax paid. Very simplistically, this Bill says that, if the company tax rate in the foreign country where the subsidiary is operating is lower than the Australian rate, when that company brings the income back to Australia it will pay an additional tax up to the level of the 49c in the dollar Australian company rate.

This is really a very silly proposal. Let us consider a company that is operating as a subsidiary in Singapore, and let us say that it is the only subsidiary-there are one or two arrangements which would help very big companies with widespread interests where they can average around a number of countries. Let us say that somebody has been entrepreneurial enough to set up a new operation in Singapore and that operation is set up in order to service exports from Australia. In other words, if one has a subsidiary company in Singapore designed to carry out a sales operation there to make money for Australian exports, under this measure that subsidiary will pay tax in Singapore, and the tax rate there is 40c in the dollar. The income will then come back to Australia and there will be an additional tax because the Commissioner of Taxation will say: `You have paid only 40 per cent in Singapore. The rate is 49 per cent in Australia, so you will have to pay an additional tax'.

If an Australian company with a branch in Singapore has an Australian income of $100,000 and its Singapore income is $40,000, the present Australian tax would be $49,000-this is when we get the 49c rate in Australia-and the present Singapore tax at 40c in the dollar would be $16,000. So we have a total tax payment of $65,000. Under the new proposal we are looking at this morning the company would pay the Singapore tax of $16,000 and it would pay the $49,000 Australian tax, but it would also have to pay the difference in Australia between the Singapore tax and the Australian tax. So the new tax would be $68,600 on the whole income for the company, versus $65,000 before; that is $3,600 additional tax for being entrepreneurial, going to Singapore, setting up a subsidiary to sell Australian goods there, and making a profit. Now that is a nonsense.

This funny little foreign tax credit thing was dredged up by the Australian Taxation Office and the Treasury when we were in office. In fact, we announced it in the late 1970s. Most people did not understand what it was all about-the foreign tax credits system is a rather arcane thing-but business houses obviously do. There was a lot of examination of it by people in the business and they raised very substantial objections to it. Because a country like Australia really wants to start getting out into overseas operations and setting up export arrangements and subsidiaries that operate in their own right, it was decided by the then Treasurer, the present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), that this was just not on, that the proposal was unworkable and that it would be totally counter-productive. Now this Government has bought it and the reason it has bought it, as I see it, is that it is just desperate for extra revenue following its failure to broaden the tax base at the National Economic Summit. So all these old nasties that have been sitting around in the Taxation and Treasury cupboards for years have been dragged out and dusted off and, believe it or not, this absurd arrangement-the foreign tax credits scheme-has been put forward again.

This Government has made a couple of amendments since its original announcement which allow companies to average out over a number of different countries. Some of the big boys who have very widespread operations will like that and they will move money all over the place to make sure that they do not pay any extra tax; but anybody who is battling in new areas with low tax regimes or setting up subsidiaries in a single country-I might say that the United Kingdom and the United States of America have tax rates that are lower than ours and they are going lower-will be clobbered by this tax.

So, if one wants to set up subsidiaries in those countries one will be clobbered by this tax. Of course, what will happen is that people just will not do it or they will move their money around the world in ways to avoid bringing the money back to Australia. The Government reckons that it will get $60m out of this tax. If this tax goes ahead it will stop a whole lot of entrepreneurial activity in the first place; that is point one. In other words, it is a stupid thing to bring in at this time when we are really trying to get investment in exports, and so on. That is the absurdity of it in the first place. Secondly, I do not think anybody is going to pay it. They will find out ways of moving stuff from Singapore, they will set up another subsidiary somewhere else, and so on; and we can bet that the smart guys will somehow avoid the tax coming back. Therefore, why set up something that virtually invites this, is totally counter-productive, and so on? When we were in government we opposed this when it came up in the late 1970s, after we had had a look at it, and we withdrew it. We will oppose the measure in this instance here and we will oppose it in the Senate; and we will invite the support of the Australian Democrats. I do not think they have yet had a close look at it, but after they have had a close look at it I think they may well support us.

We have this complicated range of measures in 275 pages of tax legislation. I repeat what I said at the beginning: Given the almost zero time that we have had to look at this and the fact that explanatory memoranda are not available for some of the most important parts of it, essentially this is a preliminary reaction from the Opposition. I now find that we have another explanatory memorandum on foreign tax credits. Well, splendid, it has just arrived! That is great; I have half a minute now to read that, absorb it and carry on with this debate. We will make other views known when the measure gets to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mountford Mr J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1986, the Income Tax (Securities and Agreements) (Withholding Tax Recoupment) Bill 1986, the Taxation Laws Amendment (Foreign Tax Credits) Bill 1986 and the Taxation Boards of Review (Transfer of Jurisdiction) Bill 1986 before us today. It is unfortunate, though understandable, that the four tax Bills that we are about to discuss should have become overshadowed in the great debate over capital gains, which shall be before us tomorrow, and the fringe benefits tax, which this House passed last week. It is understandable because these measures represent the most direct attack upon the inequities of the present taxation system. It is unfortunate because the Bills now before us are still an integral part of the Hawke Labor Government's overall strategy to establish a fair system of tax which will remove the enormous burden that has been shifted to the shoulders of marginal taxpayers from the shoulders of better off Australians. While capital gains, fringe benefits and the like have rightly been given a place as a most decisive part of the Government's tax reform package, we would do well to remember that the Bills before us are just as committed to the task of tax equity.

SPEECH.PARA: Each year difficulties arise within the tax system, loopholes are exploited, flaws are exposed, and legal decisions change the meaning of certain provisions. It is the responsibility of government to review these changes every year to ensure that such difficulties are addressed before too much abuse of them takes place. Our predecessors were sadly remiss in this respect and it is mainly because of their neglect that this Government has been forced to make the decisions that some now find so hard to take. The fringe benefits tax is a good example of this. For years employers used fringe benefit packages to attract staff by providing them with a tax-free benefit. The benefits of the rich became greater while their taxable income remained the same. Had honourable members opposite acted sooner, the present tax would not be necessary, but they neglected their duty, allowed the lower income earners to take on a greater burden and consigned the whole problem of tax equity to the too-hard basket.

There are other necessary changes which need to be made to the tax system from time to time, which are not nearly as far-reaching as fringe benefits but which are still important. It is such legislation which is before us today-a fine tuning, as it were, of the taxation system. Honourable members should make no mistake about it; the spirit of equity and just distribution of the tax burden which is to be found in the capital gains and fringe benefits legislation is also present in the four Bills now before us. For example, the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) deals with two major changes to the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 and with a number of minor changes. Firstly, the Bill will deal with discounted and other deferred interest securities. At present securities which issue most or all of their income only at maturity have been taxed only on redemption or prior to sale when the benefit is received in cash. This has created a situation in which holders of such securities are at an advantage relative to the position of holders of more traditional interest bearing securities.

Clauses 16, 26, 27 and 28 are designed to eliminate such unfair tax deferral advantages. The imbalance will be redressed by taxing that portion of the ultimate gain which accrues to the security only in that particular financial year. Examples of the types of securities to which the changes apply are original issue discount securities interest at maturity securities and securities which separately market the entitlements to principal and interest on underlying securities. Even such securities will need to satisfy three criteria: Firstly, the issue needs to have taken place after 16 December 1984, when the initiative was first announced; secondly, the expected term will need to exceed, or be likely to exceed, one year; and, thirdly, the sum of all payments, other than periodic interest payments, will need to exceed the issue price. The new laws will not apply where the excess is less than 1.5 per cent per annum of the sum of the payments.

The definitions are fairly clear, but to ensure that there is no doubt the legislation allows for inquirers to apply to the issuer of such securities for a notice as to whether the security comes under the new law or not. The legislation allows for varying accrual methods where the return to the security is not known for certain. Where determination in advance is not able to be calculated the Commissioner of Taxation will have authority to determine the amount to be included in the taxpayer's income.

Allowance also is made for deductibility where the income ultimately is not received at the end of the term. For example, where the issuer becomes insolvent the amount already paid will become deductible as a bad debt. To ensure that no unfair disadvantage is imposed on holders of such securities the Bill provides also for cases in which the income of such securities is included in a private company's taxable income. Such income is excluded under Division 7 for tax circulation purposes until the security is sold or redeemed. Also provision is made for the sale of the security before maturity. Again, income arising from the sale of an affected security for more than the accrued value will be accounted as taxable income of the seller, whereas a loss will be an allowable deduction.

Such moves prove that when the Australian Labor Party speaks of equity in the tax system it refers to fairness throughout the entire system, even when it relates to a part of the tax system which usually affects only the wealthier income earners. The new tax measure will result in gains to revenue of an unquantifiable amount. Related to this reform is another initiative announced in December 1984 designed to strengthen the presently existing provisions in the tax laws dealing with withholding tax. It has been the hallmark of the tax policy of the present Opposition when in government to let loopholes develop without closing them. Clauses 12 to 15 and 19 to 28 of this legislation are intended to close such loopholes.

At present when a non-resident holds a security such as the ones I have just dealt with a lurk has evolved whereby withholding tax can be avoided by selling the security to a resident just before it reaches maturity. The proposed amendments make the profit from such transfers by non-residents to residents income that consists of interest. The profit will thus come under Division 2A of Part III of the existing Act and will be subject to withholding tax.

The amendments will also deal with a situation in which a resident has entered into a hire purchase or finance lease agreement after 16 December 1984 with a non-resident. The charges under such an agreement at present are not classed as interest under the withholding tax rules. However, such charges obviously are the return for the provision of finance. The amendments will treat the excess of total payments over the cost price of such goods as interest assessable for withholding tax purposes.

The Bill also removes any confusion about the necessity to pay withholding tax on the discounted element of a bank accepted bill where a resident reimburses a non-resident acceptor for the face value of the bill when it matures. It is obvious that if the resident drawer had met the face value of the bill immediately withholding tax would be payable. The Bill makes it clear that withholding tax is still payable on any discounted security or interest under a bill of exchange, thereby eliminating uncertainty and closing a possible abuse of the taxation system. The interest withholding tax provisions will not directly lead to a gain in revenue, but without these charges an unquantifiable amount would continue to be lost.

While the provisions relating to discounted and other deferred interest securities and the interest withholding arrangement are the main features of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) there are a number of other important features. For example, clauses 5, 8, 18 and 30 will exempt certain parts of the formal training allowance payable to trainees under the Commonwealth Department of Employment and Industrial Relations scheme introduced from 1 January 1986. The amendments will exempt from tax those components of the formal training allowance which equate with the presently exempt social security pension or benefit entitlements. The assessable component of the allowance will be subject to tax instalment deductions under the pay as you earn system. By this provision, people in receipt of the formal training allowance will not be disadvantaged by being taxed on their social security equivalent payment. The move is a part of the Government's efforts to improve the training, education and employment prospects of young people. This change will cost revenue approximately $100,000 in 1986-87 and about $200,000 in a full year. The incentive given to the young, however, outweighs the cost.

In the category of corrective legislation, clause 17 will eliminate an unintended effect of the income tax rebate provisions which limit the rate of tax payable on certain payments made on termination of employment. The intention of the original legislation, section 160aa, is to limit tax on lump sum superannuation after 30 June 1983 to 30 per cent or in some cases 15 per cent. However, a technical difficulty in section 160aa means that some schemes where part of the relevant termination payment is taxed at the lowest marginal rate may not get the full rebate. The amendment will remedy that situation. The cost to revenue of this measure will be minimal.

Clause 4 of the Bill allows for the possibility at a later date of the transfer of responsibility for the non-revenue aspects of superannuation fund regulations. At present, the Commissioner of Taxation is responsible for these regulations, but it is proposed that some changes be allowed possibly to extend responsibility to the Treasury, or a new authority set up for the purpose. Naturally, any such move would require consultations with the relevant business and employee groups. In preparation for this possible change, the secrecy provisions of the present Act are being changed to allow the Commissioner to communicate relevant information about superannuation funds to the prospective authority.

The Bill will also allow donations of $2 and over to the Pearl Watson Foundation to be tax deductible. This foundation has been set up in memory of the wife of Mr Justice R. S. Watson of the Family Court in recognition of her great contribution to the Australian community. The foundation promotes programs in areas related to the Family Court's operations in marital breakdown, marriage counselling and conciliation. The estimated cost to revenue of $10,000 per year will be more than worth it.

To ensure that the provisions of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) dealing with withholding taxes are given enough sanction to make them effective, the second of the Bills before us, the Income Tax (Securities and Agreements) (Withholding Tax Recoupment) Act 1986 has been introduced. Where parties try to avoid the provisions of the new legislation, for example, by selling a security at less than its arm's length negotiated value, the Commissioner has authority to adjust the sale price to a truer reflection of its market value, and tax the item accordingly. In cases where tax is being avoided by a transaction between residents and non-residents, the Bill imposes liability for the avoided income on the resident, due to the difficulty of getting the tax from the non-resident. By such means, the Government hopes to prevent collusion in joint dealings which have as their ultimate aim the defrauding of the Australian taxation system.

The Taxation Laws Amendment (Foreign Tax Credits) Bill 1986 addresses yet another abuse which our opponents did not confront-the avoidance of Australian tax by appearing to give income an artificial overseas source. Under the present laws the income of Australian residents derived from foreign sources is in most cases exempt from tax here if it has been subject to tax overseas. No matter how little the overseas tax may have been, the income is subject to no further review. This scheme is obviously open to abuse of the worst kind. It encourages the existence of tax havens.

This legislation is a perfect example of how the Opposition failed to keep pace with change while in government. This blatant tax rort has been dealt with long ago by many other nations, including the United States of America, the United Kingdom, Japan and West Germany-nations which are hardly in the vanguard of socialist reform. The attention of the Australian Government to the problem was aroused as early as 1975 by the Asprey Taxation Review Committee, which recommended the use of a foreign tax credit system to eliminate the rort. In 1978 our opponents began to legislate to deal with the problem, but backed off when they were criticised by their masters in big business. As a result, a glaring abuse of our tax rules has been sanctioned for almost a decade. Rest assured that this Government will not shrink from the task.

Put simply, the foreign tax credit system will allow for overseas sources of income to be taxed at the normal Australian rate, and a credit will be allowed against that tax on the basis of the foreign tax paid. The system is based on the White Paper and the reforms announced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) last September. Since then, discussions have been held with interested business and professional groups to ensure that the tax is fairly and effectively imposed. The legislation as it stands will allow for excess foreign tax credits from high tax countries and ensures that company tax is paid in such a way as to prevent possible abuses while not subjecting companies to a system of double taxation. The Bill recognises the need to exempt income earned overseas and taxed in the other country. It also contains provisions to convert currency from foreign money into Australian dollars.

This tax is a most direct example of the Hawke Labor Government's determination to ensure that each Australian shoulders his or her fair proportion of the tax burden, and does not escape that responsibility, leaving it to others to bear. It is expected that the Bill will bring an increase in revenue of $60m per annum, measured in 1985-86 dollars. The legislation will take effect from 1 July 1987. The first results will appear in the financial year 1988-89.

Finally, the Taxation Boards of Review (Transfer of Jurisdiction) Bill 1986 deals with several administrative points of taxation appeal organisation. The Bill for the most part adopts the recommendations of the Administrative Review Council. The major recommendation followed in this Bill is the abolition of the taxation boards of review and the transfer of their power to a new Taxation Appeals Division within the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The new arrangements are designed to retain the high standards and legal expertise of the present taxation boards of review while coupling with it the flexibility of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The backlog of cases left over from the tax avoidance boom during the Opposition's period in government has delayed many hearings of appeals. The structure of the new Tribunal will allow for hearings by a single member, which will substantially increase the number of appeals that may go through. Once again, we see that it is left to this Government to clean up the mess of our predecessors.

The four Bills before us now are an integral part of the Labor Government's commitment to tax equity. Certainly, they may not attract the enormous media attention of the other legislation which forms part of our total reform package; but in their initiatives to create new laws, correct or replace old laws, and advance and streamline the procedures involved in taxation administration, they are every bit as important as the other elements of the package. They prove that the Labor Government is determined to succeed on difficult technical points, just as much as on sweeping innovations. I commend the Bills to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Dr D.J.H.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to make a couple of general observations on matters which were partly covered by the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton). I think it is worthwhile reiterating them now. The Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, in case some Government members have not seen it, has about 1,200 to 1,300 pages and is fairly complex legislation. Even though I was a professor of accounting, I would not claim to have a great deal of expertise in the area of taxation law. The mere fact that the Government wants to push through such legislation without giving this House, and members of the Opposition and the public, sufficient time to consider it is absolutely disgraceful.

I have consulted some of my colleagues who lecture in taxation law and members of major chartered accounting firms. Not even Ian Gzell has had sufficient time to absorb and respond significantly to the legislation which was introduced last Thursday night. Not even his committee in the Taxation Institute of Australia, which is looking at this legislation, has had sufficient time to absorb and understand it. When I say very few Government members could comment, obviously some of them have had the help of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in writing their speeches, but very few Government members, let alone Opposition members, who have had less time to look at it, could actually absorb this legislation. The legislation involves significant extra bookkeeping and significant extra recordkeeping. It will involve significantly increased costs for professional consultation. I must admit that my friends in chartered and public accounting must be rubbing their hands because of the actions of this Government. The legislation will certainly increase the amount of advice that will be sought from them and also, I am sure, from legal practitioners. It will increase the costs of doing business. It will also increase the risks of doing business because of the self-assessment system and the fact that businesses will have to live with a significant amount of risk in the taxation area for a period of up to at least six years. The system is becoming even more unwieldy than is already the case. No one would argue that the taxation system does not need some simplification, but the legislation that has been introduced does not go in that direction. In fact, the legislation is seen to be almost arbitrary. It is considered to be less fair today than it was in the past. I believe that that process, which has been going on for some time, will be compounded in the future.

The Government has had this legislation in its mind since at least September 1985. It has taken eight months to produce it. In the meantime, it has had a significantly detrimental effect on business and on the investment climate in Australia. It is not only that; when we get the legislation, what do we see? We see at most the debit side. All the nasties are presented. We have not yet seen the tax cuts. We have not yet seen the imputation system. Will that system be guillotined through? Why is that legislation, which is absolutely critical to business in the future, not being guillotined through at the same time and with the same haste as the nasties? We know that the corporate tax rate will rise to 49 per cent. Why are the positive aspects not being introduced at the same time?

Australia seems at present to be going in the opposite direction-this will lead me on to the Bill on foreign tax credits-to that of most of our competitors. There is before the Senate in the United States of America a Bill in relation to which the House of Representatives there has suggested that the corporate tax rate in the United States should fall to 36 per cent. The United States Treasury has suggested that tax rates should fall to 33 per cent, and there is some indication that President Reagan will not simply accept a fall from 46 per cent to 36 per cent but will insist on a 33 per cent tax rate. The United Kingdom has just completed its corporate tax renewal, dropping its rate to 35 per cent. Singapore dropped its rate from 40 per cent to 33 per cent, the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) announcing that on 7 March this year. He announced the drop to improve the after-tax return on capital. Yet in Australia we shall be increasing our corporate rate to 49 per cent, and we have yet to see any imputation system.

I now turn to the Taxation Laws Amendment (Foreign Tax Credits) Bill. At a time when business is being requested-almost pressured-to invest in Australia, when we have leaders in the Australian Council of Trade Unions exhorting business to increase investments and exports, and when we have a problem with our balance of payments, there is introduced a Bill to tax foreign revenue. The argument, of course, is that any criticism of the Bill overlooks the fact that foreign tax credit systems are common in developed countries, such as the United States of America, West Germany and Japan. The problem is that Australia faces a major problem with its exports. At present we need all the competitive advantage we can possibly muster. Even though an imputation system is to be introduced-so we are led to believe-and even though the return to shareholders may be higher after tax because of that, the fact is that Australian companies will be facing a high marginal rate of 49 per cent, and they will be competing with companies overseas that will be facing low marginal rates of figures around the low 30s. Our companies themselves must finance the tax. They are the ones that will have to pay it and finance it. That will give foreign companies against which they are competing a comparative advantage in the market-place. At a time when we need everything to go our way, we have the taxation system, in essence, going in exactly the opposite way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Maybe they will invest in Australia for a change.

—They would not invest in Australia because of the cost system that Australian Labor Party members have helped to introduce. Labor members, including the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) when he was President of the ACTU, did damage to Australia and increased the costs of operating in Australia more than any other individual. Labor members and their Treasurer have not helped one iota.

SPEECH.PARA: I now turn to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1986. On page 12 of his second reading speech, the Treasurer indicated that it had been decided to transfer responsibility to somebody else-perhaps the Secretary to the Department of the Treasury, perhaps to some new supervisory authority. We have no idea what kind of structure will be proposed. Whatever the new organisational structure is, we have no idea how far its responsibilities will go. We have no idea who may or may not be in that organisation. We have no way of knowing how much information should or should not be transferred to this unnamed organisation. We do not know how it is to be limited. We do not know how secure that information will be in the hands of this new body. Although there may be problems from time to time, the confidentiality of taxation records has generally been very high under our taxation system. We do not know whether the same kinds of standards will be met by this body. Yet this Parliament is asked to give a blank cheque to the Treasurer. We would hardly buy a new car from him, let alone give him a blank cheque. This legislation should be considered only when we know what the new statutory body will be and what its powers will be. Then we can have drafted an Act and a set of regulations which limit the information to be transferred, in a more appropriate way.

I now turn to the Taxation Boards of Review (Transfer of Jurisdiction) Bill 1986. The transfer of jurisdiction from boards of review to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal undoubtedly has some very positive aspects to it. The added flexibility associated with being able to have one or more members will undoubtedly help to cut the backlog of taxation appeals. Another positive aspect will be the fact that it is possible that more details will be provided to taxpayers in appeals through the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. It is also a positive aspect that the AAT and the Supreme Courts are to be given some discretion to permit a taxpayer to widen the grounds of objection in appropriate cases. Certainly, minor as it may be, the abolition of the $2 fee is probably welcome.

However, in saying that I must reiterate in some detail the questions raised earlier by the honourable member for Mackellar. Taxation boards of review are presently composed under section 178 of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, and each board consists of a chairman and two other members. It has been the practice that the chairman is usually chosen from senior officers of the Australian Taxation Office, while one of the other members is usually chosen from the legal profession, and one other is chosen from the ranks of practising public accountants. This has given each of the taxation boards of review a breadth of experience and a breadth of background in considering any particular case. With the new proposal, the only thing that we are told is that the Attorney-General, in appointing members to this new division of the AAT, must consult the Treasurer. We do not know whether the same kinds of practices in getting the breadth of experience will be followed. Even though the present Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) seems to be quite reasonable, we have seen Labor Attorneys-General in the past noted for their lack of judgment-going anywhere from the break-in of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation to flights over Tasmania. So, we must be concerned somewhat with the process of appointments to the new AAT division to begin with.

Secondly, there is a second stage to the allocation process. The President of the AAT will need to appoint individual members of the division to individual cases. There is a significant backlog. Given the provisions in these Bills that will be debated over the next couple of weeks, I would say that a significantly greater number of cases will go to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. I think the majority of cases held up in the backlog at the moment deal with section 51 (1) of the Income Tax Assessment Act, where deductions are less than $500. While matters such as those are relatively minor, except for the taxpayer involved, and certainly can be handled by one member of a board, whether it be a former officer of the Australian Taxation Office, a chartered accountant or a lawyer, it will be difficult for a commissioner to distinguish some matters of substance.

Matters of substance really require a much broader tribunal to hear the case. That is important because not only must justice be done but justice must also be seen to be done. I would like a statement either from the Treasurer or from the Attorney-General to assure the public of Australia that people who will be appointed to the Taxation Appeals Division of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal will have a variety of backgrounds and that some guidance will be given to the Tribunal on what individuals will be appointed to particular cases. At the moment the only guidance given is in that part of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act which states that the President of the Tribunal:
(a) shall have regard to the degree of public importance-
I hope that refers not only to the cases in which the Attorney-General decides to intervene-
or complexity of the matters to which that proceeding relates.

One of the important attributes that need to be taken into account by the President of the Tribunal when he is allocating people to individual cases is that the breadth of their experience be appropriate to the substance of the law and of the case being considered. The taxation appeals system will be considered fair only if the appeal process itself is considered to be reasonable. There simply has not been sufficient time, either before or during this debate, to consider all of the things that one would like to consider in legislation such as this. I believe that the Opposition will simply have to do considerable searching of this legislation when it comes before the Senate, because it simply has not been given that opportunity in this House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today, we are debating the latest in the Government's tax package legislation. We are canvassing the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1986, the Income Tax (Securities and Agreements) (Withholding Tax Recoupment) Bill 1986, the Taxation Laws Amendment (Foreign Tax Credits) Bill 1986 and the Taxation Boards of Review (Transfer of Jurisdiction) Bill 1986, each of which has a very significant part to play in this Government's attempt to overcome the difficulties inherent in the taxation system that has operated in this country for a number of years and which, regrettably, were certainly not stamped out by the former Government when in power, when it was in a position to do so. As has been demonstrated time and time again in this House, the rorts in the taxation system were known to those opposite when they were in government. Many points of view were put forward to the effect that something should be done about it but, of course, the previous Government was shown to be totally inactive and incapable of attacking the problem. As usual, it has fallen to the Labor Government to remedy the situation and put it in its true perspective.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to talk specifically about two of the Bills before the House. The first is the Taxation Boards of Review (Transfer of Jurisdiction) Bill and I want to make one or two comments also about the Taxation Laws Amendment (Foreign Tax Credits) Bill. I also wish to pick up on a couple of points that were made by the shadow spokesman on Treasury matters, the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), and on some of the comments that have just been made by the honourable member for Forde (Dr Watson) in his contribution to this debate.

I turn firstly to the Taxation Boards of Review (Transfer of Jurisdiction) Bill. As we have already heard, and as the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has so capably pointed out in his second reading speech, this Bill reflects in large measure the Government's response to recommendations made in a report by the Administrative Review Council entitled `Review of Taxation Decisions by Boards of Review'. That document was published in June 1983 as parliamentary paper No. 219/1983. It set the scene for the legislation that has come before the House today. I will return a little later on to some of the points in that report.

In accordance with the recommendations contained in that report, the principal function of this Bill is to abolish the taxation boards of review and to transfer the present jurisdiction of the boards to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The changeover is to take effect as at 1 July 1986. The Bill also contains amendments to the sales tax law to give further partial effect to decisions of the former Government to revise the objection and appeals provisions of that law. I must pay tribute to the former Government in that it at least recognised some of the inequities in that law, but, as usual, it failed to carry forward that recognition into some practical effect. As usual, this Government has had to pick up the pieces. Other provisions in the Bill make further amendments to the objection and appeal provisions of the various laws administered by the Commissioner of Taxation, with a view to achieving a degree of desirable uniformity. I am sure that we would all agree that that is a most desirable effect.

In deciding to accept the recommendations of the Administrative Review Council, this Government was concerned to ensure that the complex and exacting task of reviewing taxation decisions be undertaken by persons with a high level of expertise in and specialist knowledge of the taxation laws. Therefore, a notable feature of this Bill is the creation within the Administrative Appeals Tribunal of a separate division to review taxation decisions. This goes to the heart of the point raised by the honourable member for Forde when he said that the provision that a tribunal may comprise just one representative meant that the opportunity for people with various degrees of expertise in law, taxation matters and so on to contribute would be lost. Quite clearly, this will not be the case because, as I have just indicated to the House, provision is made within this legislation for the creation of this separate Taxation Appeals Division to review taxation decisions, which will ensure the continued build-up of expertise in taxation matters.

I am sure that the people who lodge objections to their taxation returns will find, just as they have found in the past, that that degree of expertise will be brought to the assessment of their problems. In fact, the creation of this separate division will ensure that the review of taxation decisions will be undertaken by Tribunal members who have knowledge and skills relevant to that function. I think that is an important point, and it must be underlined. It really goes to repudiate the concern levelled at this matter by the honourable member for Forde in his speech some moments ago.

It is important to realise that one of the major features associated with the creation of tribunals and the provision that a tribunal may comprise one person is that the backlog of appeals will be dealt with far more quickly than it has been in the past. As we have seen, a substantial backlog of requests for review by the taxation boards of review has developed in recent years. That has occurred primarily as a consequence of the tax avoidance boom in the mid-1970s and the early 1980s-a tax avoidance boom which, I hasten to point out again, was not stamped out by the former Government but which, in fact, has contributed in later years to this backlog of requests for review by taxation boards of review. Therefore, the extra hearing capacity that will be provided under these more flexible procedures will enable the backlog to be dealt with more quickly than would otherwise normally be the case.

I think requests to have decisions of the Commissioner of Taxation reviewed by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal will be sent in the first instance to the Commissioner who will then refer them on to the Tribunal. As such, this procedure will enable decisions to be re-examined by the Commissioner before they are referred to the Tribunal for review. Again, within that system, we have a very staged arrangement whereby every facet of the appeal process is given careful scrutiny. To say that people will not get a fair hearing is not a true indication of the correct position-and I am sure that the honourable member for Forde will probably agree with that on reflection. Indeed, by this appeal process whereby various people with expert knowledge will examine the various objections, some of the basic problems which have arisen in the past will be overcome.

As a resource saving measure and to assist in making inroads into this backlog to which I have referred, the documents and the statement along the lines of those presently made available to the taxation boards of review will be provided until 30 June 1988. This will assist in the transitional arrangements. It is important to reflect on the number of cases which have existed in the past and the level of time it has taken to look at those cases and to bring them to finality.

I refer briefly to that document which spawned this legislation. It is the Administrative Review Council report to the Attorney-General which is entitled `Review of Taxation Decisions by Boards of Review' and is dated June 1983. This will clearly establish my point. Page 22 of that document talks about the expedition of cases. Unfortunately the figures are only comparative between 1975-76 and 1981-82; nevertheless they substantiate the claims that I am making. The figures demonstrate how the number of appeals has risen and the backlog that has been caused as a result of that factor alone. In 1975-76, there were something like 7,917,000 returns lodged and this increased to 8.6 million in 1981-82. The number of assessments issued each year has remained relatively constant. However, the number of objections has trebled, rising from 73,997 in 1975-76 to 201,376 in 1980-81. That clearly demonstrates some of the problems we have with people making objections about taxation assessments and the difficulties that that causes in a department which has its necessary expertise being overtaxed in time. Therefore there is the difficulty of a backlog developing. Quite clearly it is important that we establish clear guidelines through this legislation as to how that problem might be overcome in the future.

A very small proportion of the requests for reference to boards is to the boards of review. Of these, 50 per cent are settled; 25 per cent are allowed by the Commissioner of Taxation; and only 25 per cent are withdrawn by the taxpayers. The number of cases awaiting hearings before boards of review has risen about 50 per cent. If one compared 1981-82 with what has happened in the past year or so, one would see that those figures are a true representation of what has happened. According to the report, the Commissioner informed the Council-and one must remember that this was in 1983-that the delay in obtaining a hearing before the Board as at 30 June 1982 was as follow: Board No. 1, 18 months; Board No. 2, 29 months; Board No. 3, 9 months. I am sure that many honourable members in this House have had representations time and time again from legitimate taxpayers, people who are prepared to pay their fair share, but who believe they have a legitimate claim for review. These people realise that the ability to have that matter dealt with swiftly is being impeded because of the delays occasioned by these sorts of factors. I know from personal experience that that is the case and I am sure that the proposition that has been put before us today in this legislation to enable this problem of the ability to handle matters quickly and carefully will be welcomed by all those people in the community who are prepared to pay their fair share of tax. Hopefully, it will also appeal to those people who have previously rorted the system and those people who have tried to rort it even further by making fairly incredible claims on appeal to try to add further to their wealth.

It is important to make a brief statement on the sales tax system. Amendments in this Bill will bring the objection and appeal provisions of the sales tax law into line with the comparable income tax provisions. I think that that will be most appealing simply because sales tax payers will now have a right of objection or review in all cases where a liability for sales tax exists. Previously one just had to take a chance and if one was brought into court one fought the case through the court system. I believe that this is very fair and I am pleased that the Opposition has no objection to that particular part of the legislation.

I turn very briefly to the foreign tax credit system because I wish to pick up a couple of points that were made by the honourable member for Forde. He indicated that if people were paying a lower level of tax in a foreign country-and he used Singapore as an example-and the corporate rate of tax in Australia was 49 per cent, it was inconceivable that any difference in the tax should be paid in Australia. We on this side of the House totally reject that argument. We believe that if companies are prepared to invest overseas at the expense of investing in Australia they should be made to pay their fair share of tax. If they were investing in Australia, they would be seen and they would be paying their fair share of tax. Thus the burden would not fall back on the pay as you earn taxpayers. The foreign tax credit system has been criticised because many Australian businesses fear that such a system will harm their competitiveness. We do not believe that that is the case. The Government will seek to ensure that genuine overseas investment and trade interests are protected. The underlying factor there must be whether these overseas interests are genuine. Too often we have seen people who are prepared to go offshore for tax rorts and that does nothing to improve the Australian economy or the manufacturing sector which we all agree is in need of support at present.

The Government cannot agree to allow the Australian tax system to effectively subsidise operations of Australian companies in low tax countries on an open-ended basis. Under a foreign tax credit system we can reassert some control over the use of tax havens and low tax countries so that Australia's commercial interests are protected. Many of our trade competitors, such as the United States of America, Japan, the United Kingdom and West Germany, have successfully operated a foreign tax credit system without the dire consequences that some people have predicted for Australia. The honourable member for Forde, who is a former professor of accounting, said he thought that this was nonsense and that it would not happen, but the evidence from overseas clearly demonstrates that it can happen and that it can be policed effectively. I am sure that we will see that happening in this country. Therefore, such companies will not be at a tax advantage to other Australian businesses through this process and I am confident that this legislation will bring about a much fairer system whereby those people who should pay tax will pay it.

In the time remaining to me, I wish to pick up a couple of points that were raised by the shadow spokesman on Treasury matters, the honourable member for Mackellar. Frankly, I was a little disappointed by his contribution this morning. I came here specifically to sit through his speech in order to see the Opposition's response to the four Bills before us.

The Opposition's tourism policy has been dropped on us. Its education policy was leaked to us yesterday. The Opposition's aviation policy and primary industry policy have been leaked to us. But we do not have its tax policy.
—What about small business? There is some tax in that.

—We would like to see all the policies so that we can understand what the shadow spokesman has to say about tax in general. These fine upstanding citizens of Australia, these leaders in the business community whom people are supposed to look up to and whom those opposite are supposed to be representing, are imploring the business community of Australia to break the law.
