I think it is a sad reflection on those opposite if they vindicate what has been said by people in the business community such as Ansett and by other people such as Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen who claim that people should break the laws of the land. I honestly hope that I have misinterpreted what the honourable member for Mackellar said because, quite frankly, I thought he was a far better representative of the Australian people than that.

These Bills are part and parcel of the tax package to which this Government is committed to ensure that a much fairer system of taxation is established. The legislation will simplify the system. It will make it far more efficient and, more importantly, those people who have not paid tax in the past will be brought to account.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome this opportunity to be able to debate taxation matters and even economic matters. However, that opportunity is limited because I understand the time for debate has been cut down. Nevertheless, I want to refer to two aspects of the taxation legislation that is now before us. Firstly, I wish to refer to the Taxation Laws Amendment (Foreign Tax Credits) Bill 1986-a very vital Bill which will affect Australia's trading position in more ways than one. The second matter to which I wish to refer is the transition from the Taxation Board of Review to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. This is an area with which I had a close association during my days as a public accountant.

SPEECH.PARA: Nobody on the Government side will deny that Australia's trading deficit has received national and international prominence as this nation's major economic problem. However, the Taxation Laws Amendment (Foreign Tax Credits) Bill contains yet another disincentive to trade. I say `yet another disincentive' because there have been major disincentives over the last two or three years. The Treasurer (Mr Keating), in his exaggerated description in the past two weeks of our economy, failed to accept-or if he did accept it, he failed to reveal-that quite apart from the terms and conditions applying to international markets, the other major problem that Australia faces is the domestic environment in which we have asked business and manufacturers to produce and export. The Treasurer did not accept that that disincentive to trading was as much a problem in Australia at the moment as the terms of trade being experienced by our commodity exporters. I suggest that until the Treasurer realises and accepts that taxes such as the foreign credits tax, the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax are new and fresh barriers to Australia's production and to Australia's capacity to trade our economy will continue to deteriorate to the extent that the Treasurer predicted last week; and be that on his own head. The Australian economy requires less intervention and less tax. What we have had has been more intervention and higher taxes.

The foreign credits system is complex. We were told that the tax package would be in the interests of simplicity, fairness and equity. The amending legislation comprises 26 pages. I understand at the time of Federation the complete income tax Act was no more than four or five times that size. So, the legislation is not simple; it is complex. Of course, the cost of compliance will be just another cost to business. It will be just another tax on Australia's export sector. As a result, those people who have been genuinely operating overseas to market Australia's products, as we would want them to do, and who, in the past, would have been motivated on the basis of profit in foreign countries will now face a major disincentive. The previous speaker, the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin), mentioned that those who were genuinely operating in a foreign country would not be discriminated against. I fail to comprehend how the Australian Taxation Office, bearing in mind the way in which it operates, is going to differentiate, in the present climate of attacks being made on the taxpayer, between what is genuine and what is not.

Let us look at the economic differences, of which this tax will be only one aspect, between Australia and our major competitors. Many people go overseas on a marketing expedition and set up a branch office on the basis of the level of taxes that operate in foreign countries. I suggest that, on the whole, Asian tax rates are only a fraction of the Australian rates. For instance, the Hong Kong rate is 18.5 per cent. Of course, this has to be an incentive to a person who is looking at the whole set of criteria for trading overseas. Let me outline another reason why Australian firms may wish to operate overseas. Australia has an inflation rate of 9.2 per cent. The inflation rate in the United States of America is 3.2 per cent. The rate in Japan is 1.8 per cent. West Germany, which next year will have a negative consumer price index figure, has a rate of well under one per cent at the moment. This is another reason why Australian firms would want to go off-shore. In addition Australia's 18 per cent interest rates must rank as among the highest in the world. The rate in the United States is 7 per cent, in Japan 6 per cent and in West Germany 4.9 per cent. Why would a person considering the criteria for going overseas not look at that?

Our currency devaluation should have favoured exporters by at least 25 per cent in the last 12 months. Now profits made on foreign shores are going to be repatriated to Australia. Those profits will be assessed, not in foreign terms but in terms of the equivalent exchange rates. This indicates to me that on whatever Australian firms get from trading in foreign countries the tax rate will be 25 per cent higher because of the exchange rate on repatriated profits. Australia has to realise that the world does not owe it a living. Neither should we expect the world to pay Australia's penalising rates of tax-and that is precisely what this legislation proposes. I wonder whether it has been brought to the notice of the Treasurer or the Taxation Office that a major financial consultancy is now advising Australians to place or invest their funds and savings off-shore to gain the benefits of lower taxation, lower inflation and higher security.

We had a situation years ago where law and accounting firms were advising on tax avoidance. The foreign tax credit scheme will only increase legal tax avoidance for people who want to have secure funds by investing overseas. If this foreign tax credit scheme means that a company will pay a differential tax in Australian terms, its operations will go completely off-shore. In trying to import taxes we will be exporting Australian business in its entirety. Australia will then lose the investment, the work and the enterprise that we so desperately need at the moment. We should be encouraging our exporters, by creating a rational Australian economic environment, a rational tax regime. We should be trying to lower interest rates, and trying to improve the situation on the industrial front. There has been no encouragement to do that, and the foreign tax credit scheme is just a further discouragement for business.

The Opposition abhors the abuse of any system. We abhor it and we would try to correct it, but by introducing this foreign tax credit scheme to stamp out abuse, the Government is throwing out the baby with the bath water. It is not looking at the comparable tax regimes overseas. It is not looking at where we might involve people in investment overseas and still retain an Australian component. The interesting thing is that the Minister in his second reading speech apologised for his embarrassment at bringing this legislation into the House by saying that the tax regimes in the United States of America, West Germany and Japan have this provision. I ask all parliamentarians to look at the situation Australia faces in comparison with those three countries. If there is a pecking order, we are at the bottom of the list every time. Our trade balance is in a worse situation per capita, our whole domestic environment is different, and now the Government is saying that we must compare ourselves with the world's three economic giants and expect the rest of the world to accept it.

TALK.START.PARA: —How are we going to survive?
—We will not survive if we have new additional taxation imposed continually. Let me quote the comment of the Business Council of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . there is simply no Foreign Tax Credit system that we can envisage that would not do serious harm to the Australian economy, and in light of the uncertainties and concerns widespread in the business community it would be better for the nation for the Government to abandon the exercise.

The effect of the measure is to put a stranglehold on Australian companies operating overseas. To compete against local companies they must operate under the same tax rules as those competitors. If this measure were in place they would either withdraw their operations from low tax countries or find ways and means of keeping their earnings abroad. That is precisely what I outlined to the House earlier. No exporter or group of exporters that I have spoken to over the last six months, whether they are manufacturers or in the service or consultancy areas, have had a good word to say about this taxation. They are not whingers; they are people who are trying desperately to maintain the limited advantage we have in our export markets and they have all thoroughly condemned this measure. The wretched part about it is that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins) either are not aware of these comments or are not prepared to acknowledge that they are justified.

In every respect the legislation before us is a contradiction of the Government's other policies. The Government wants us to export and to trade but it then imposes a penalty in the form of this tax. The Government needs exports, Australia needs exports, but what we are doing is taxing those exporters out of existence. We are trying to compete, but we have inferior work practices, higher interest rates and a higher inflation rate. All the disincentives we have that are preventing growth in Australia are firmly linked to the Government's policies on the economy and all these disincentives have culminated in this current legislation.

Having been involved as a tax agent and chartered accountant within the profession for 25 years, there is no appeal tribunal in Australia that is closer to my heart than the Taxation Board of Review. The Board of Review always provided the taxpayer with the fairest approach. The Board itself was most approachable; one did not have to appear before it with a legal representative, and it was the least costly form of appeal. I am not sure whether the fee has been updated, but a taxpayer could take his case before a board of review for a cost of $2. I have found that those components are not necessarily incorporated in any other form of appeal against any other law in Australia. The composition of the boards was well balanced. They consisted perhaps of somebody who had retired from the Australian Taxation Office, somebody who was a specialist in law, and normally an accountant who had been practising on a professional basis. I believe that that composition was well balanced, and balanced in favour of the taxpayer. If there is a backlog of appeals it is not the fault of the Board of Review. The fault is in the taxation system and its complexity, as I have mentioned.

As I understand it, this new legislation consists of about 91 pages. In two pieces of separate legislation today we have the same volume content as in the complete income tax Act of 1901. The fault lies not in the Board of Review but in the departmental approach and the manner in which tax avoidance has been practised-I do not deny that. When people in the community deliberately set out to avoid tax we will have a bigger backlog as people appeal against assessments. I suggest that there has also been a bluffing on the part of the Department in making assessments. It takes the high ground and the taxpayer is then forced to follow through, in the interests of equity, with an appeal. That is one of the reasons for the backlog, but there are other factors such as the higher penalties that apply at the moment, and the cost of business compliance. While businesses are complying with all other aspects of taxation, perhaps they are not as dutiful as they might be in their original returns and this can be corrected only by an objection later on. I suggest that, if there is a backlog, it is because of the greed of the Government in trying to get more tax revenue into its coffers without looking at the other side of the equation and trying to curb expenditure.

I do not believe that these new procedures before the House will provide the same degree of fairness as the Board of Review has provided. Appeals will be more costly than they are at the moment because these one-man bands will not travel as the boards of review did. We will see the same thing happen as occurs with appeal tribunals in the social security area, where people have to go from their place of domicile to Brisbane or some other capital city. Because of the complexity of the procedures I believe that the new Administrative Appeals Tribunal system will not operate in the same way as the boards of review.

As I see it at the moment, the endangered species in Australia are the honest and upright taxpayer and the tax agent who tries to follow through the procedures of the Taxation Office to bring some justice to proceedings. These people are now an endangered species. More people are taking from the public purse at the moment than are putting into it. I recollect that in the early 1970s for every 10 taxpayers there was one beneficiary on welfare. Now we are approaching a situation where we have 10 taxpayers for every five beneficiaries on welfare, and those numbers of taxpayers have not been increasing at the same rate as the economy.

I have received a letter which I think encapsulates the Department's attitude as far as taxpayers are concerned. I just wish to mention one matter which the Australian Taxation Office might take on notice. A constituent wrote to me and said that he was told on 21 April by registered letter of 1986 that he had not lodged his return, which he thought he had lodged, and that proceedings would go before a magistrate on 15 May. On 22 April he provided a copy of the missing return, which showed that a credit of $1,381 was due to him. On 15 May, prior to the court hearing, he discussed the matter with the taxation representative, together with his accountant, and he offered to pay the fine, but to no avail. The magistrate went ahead and heard the case, at a cost of $200 to a man who had a credit available to him and who up to that stage had been an honest taxpayer, diligent in his operations with the Taxation Office. He had handled a large number of payments of group tax, company tax and prescribed payments tax for builders, and that is the treatment he got. I speak in this vein because I believe that the taxpayers of Australia are being screwed unmercifully. It is about time that some justice was given to them, both in the operation of the law and in the legislation with which they have to comply.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maher Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honour- able member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) made a number of interesting points. I want to comment on his reference to the taxation level in Hong Kong which, he pointed out, was 18.5 per cent; and I believe that in Singapore there is also a very low level of taxation. Such countries are not nations in which there is an extensive social security and welfare system. In Australia 30 per cent of revenue is paid out under the social security and welfare portfolio. We have age pensions and family allowances; we have an enormous commitment to people who are retired or who are poor. No country with such a commitment can have such a very low rate of taxation. The Government's whole tax exercise is designed to reduce the levels of direct taxation not only to taxpayers but also to Australian companies, and it is the most thorough-going reform of the Australian tax system that has ever been introduced into this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Dawson is quite wrong when he says that it involves more tax. It does not involve more tax. The whole idea of this tax package which is being debated here today, which was debated last week and which will be debated later in the week is that it is revenue neutral. There is $1 1/2 billion involved, but it will all come from people who are now walking around the tax system, receiving payments or goods in kind and facilities or benefits that are not taxed. Unlike the pay as you earn taxpayers, they are avoiding tax on part of their income. These people or their employers will be expected to pay tax on fringe benefits, on capital gains, on negative gearing, and all the other things that people were doing quite legitimately to take advantage of the tax laws of this country and to avoid their direct liability. The previous Government was in power for 30 years and overviewed the tax system but did nothing about changing it. There were reports and inquiries undertaken. The Asprey Taxation Review Committee of 1975 made a lot of recommendations but many of these were not acted on.

One of the Bills being debated in this cognate debate today is the Taxation Laws Amendment (Foreign Tax Credits) Bill 1986. This matter was raised before the Asprey Committee, which recommended the introduction of a foreign tax credit system in the interests of equity and efficiency, the idea being to encourage Australians not to avoid tax by arranging for their income to have an artificial overseas source. In 1978 the previous Government said that it would introduce some sort of a scheme to stop Australians shifting their money to tax havens or laundering their money in tax havens. The Government knew that most Western nations, including the United States, West Germany and Japan, have schemes to stop the avoidance of tax by the use of foreign tax havens. It is costing the Australian taxpayers $60m a year. The vast majority of taxpayers, people who are working, are in the pay as you earn tax bracket; their tax is taken out every week and they have no way to minimise their tax, to walk around the tax system. These were the people who were outraged by the bottom of the harbour revelations in 1982, when it became obvious that many companies could totally avoid all their tax liability.

As I said earlier, the whole exercise is revenue neutral. The Government has undertaken to introduce substantial tax cuts to bring the top marginal tax rate from 60 per cent down to 49 per cent, and to stop the double taxation of company profits which has been an enormous disincentive to investment in private companies and in small businesses. I believe that we are seeing a great watershed in the collection of taxation in this nation. Australians will see from now on that the system will be fair. There will be some incentive not to go into tax avoidance and to work harder, because if one works harder one will lose not 60 per cent of what one earns but only 49 per cent. I think it is an enormous tribute to the Treasurer that he was able to work on this scheme, with the help of Treasury officers, and that he was able to come up with this proposal once the consumer tax idea was rejected at the summit conference. It is a great credit to the Treasurer that he has been able to bring these very detailed amendments before the House over these weeks, and the Australian people will again see honesty and integrity in the tax system.

Another Bill involved is the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1986. This Bill relates to `dingo bonds', as they are called, a scheme for avoiding tax liability by discounted securities. There is also legislation on interest withholding tax which is long overdue. Another matter that I want to touch on as well is the changes in the appeal mechanisms. This is of great significance, as the honourable member for Dawson and other honourable members have mentioned today, because it is a test of the rule of law if a citizen has the right to go to a board, a court or a tribunal and contest the assessment of his or her taxes. In this country for the past 60 years the ordinary taxpayer has been able to seek from taxation boards of review redress of an assessment that is considered onerous. From inquiries that I have made I was pleased to find that the great tradition of going to a board of review and accepting its decision without the penalty of legal costs is to be retained by the abolition of the boards of review and their absorption into the administrative appeals system. In this country we have the Administrative Appeals Tribunal which has no power to award costs in its ordinary jurisdiction. In its workers compensation jurisdiction it can award costs against the Commonwealth, but there is no power to award other costs. This will allay the fears of taxpayers who feel that they might have lost this right to appeal without penalty of costs if they lose.

Most of the appeals that go to the Taxation Board of Review are small matters, involving perhaps a trifling amount, but very significant to some taxpayers-often a claim for a deduction for an overseas study tour or home office expenses. This might involve a teacher, an author or someone who works from his home and who claims that part of his electricity and home maintenance repairs should be set off against his income because that is his place of work. The boards of review were the tribunal where some of the capital gains tax disputes were heard under the old section 26 (a) when people did not want publicity for perhaps some development or some property subdivision, and enormous numbers of these cases were heard by the three boards of review in the eastern States. The system has become clogged, as other speakers have said, and there has been considerable delay, as every member of parliament knows, not only in the hearings but in getting objections looked at by the Commissioner of Taxation and then having the appeals transmitted by the Commissioner to the Board of Review.

There are procedures in the Act for expediting the transmission of appeals to the boards of review, but under the proposed changes, with the absorption of the Board of Review in each State into the administrative appeals system, it will be possible for a single individual, a member of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, to hear appeals, whereas under the Taxation Board of Review arrangements it was always a full board of three who by a majority decided each matter.

I was delighted to see that in the second reading speech and the Bill there is also an assurance that secrecy will remain. The Board of Review always publishes its decisions without mentioning the name of the appellant. Of course it is very difficult to maintain secrecy. One case that I remember involved the owner of private land in Sydney which was used as a golf course. Everyone knew who the man who owned the golf course, had it subdivided for sale and made a substantial profit was. Mostly, however, these are cases involving ordinary, humble taxpayers. Sometimes substantial amounts are involved, sometimes Queen's Counsel appear before the board of review. The board of review always attempted to have an informal procedure. It was a tribunal before which most of the applicants appeared in person, representing their own interests. Usually these were people who were untrained in the law but were guided and assisted by the three members of the tribunal, who themselves also were assisted by staff of the Australian Taxation Office.

I do believe-I have always believed-that in most cases the vast majority of appeals to boards of review are settled before hearing. I am sure that that procedure will continue. However, there is a backlog of cases. There have been problems with the taxation board of review system. I congratulate the Treasurer (Mr Keating) because I think it is a very sensible move to bring the boards of review which were out on their own under the umbrella of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, which has developed considerable expertise in the area of informality and minor legal processes. I feel that this is an important move. Certainly, I have been making representations to the Treasurer about the board of review delays. The changeover will actually take place on 1 July 1986.

They are the matters that I wanted to mention in the House today. Essentially, I wanted to touch on the guarantee to taxpayers that they will still have a right to object, beyond the Commissioner of Taxation, to an independent tribunal which they can approach without fear of cost. Many people are frightened of losing a case in court proceedings. Although they may feel that they have the better case and that they have justice on their side, they are frightened that something may happen and that if they lose not only will they lose the determination of the matter in hand but also they will have the penalty of costs of the other side awarded against them. At present there are no costs to be awarded in the taxation board of review system, and certainly there will be no costs awarded under the new procedure in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Even the $2 fee or deposit that was mentioned by the honourable member for Dawson has been abolished. I commend the Treasurer for bringing this package of legislation before the House. I ask the House to support the Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to confine my remarks in this debate on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1986, the Income Tax (Securities and Agreements) (Withholding Tax Recoupment) Bill 1986, the Taxation Laws Amendment (Foreign Tax Credits) Bill 1986 and the Taxation Boards of Review (Transfer of Jurisdiction) Bill 1986 to the introduction by the Government of a new foreign tax credit system because the new foreign tax credit system is something that will be a matter of great concern to a large number of people in the business community. Of course, fairly obviously it will be of particular concern to those firms involved in international activities. I would have thought that at a time when the greatest national challenge for Australia was to take action to restore our balance of payments the Government would be looking for constructive initiatives to try to ensure that Australian industries become more competitive. Also I would have thought that the Government would be trying to ensure that Australian industries not only are more competitive but also are more export oriented and outward looking in their attitudes. Certainly it has been one of the great problems of Australia, almost since white settlement, that in economic terms we have been very insular and inward looking.

SPEECH.PARA: Australian industry needs to be imbued with the attitude that it can take on the best in the world and go out there and beat them. However, Australian industries are not going to be able to do that if the Government continues to impose costs on them, in this case through taxation legislation, which will have the effect of making Australian firms less competitive than many of their international rivals. This whole tax package, including the foreign tax credit system which is included as part of the package, really militates against that objective of making Australian industry more competitive. That has been pointed out by a number of members, including me, in debates on the fringe benefits tax. No doubt it will be pointed out tomorrow in the debate on the capital gains tax that that too will increase costs to Australian businesses. It has been pointed out again and again in the Australian community in relation to the increase in company tax from 46c to 49c in the dollar. All those things have increased costs to Australian business-some of them by small amounts, some of them by very substantial amounts.

The proposed new foreign tax credit system is just another example of the ever-increasing taxation burden for business. Of course, the new foreign taxation credit system does not affect all businesses; it affects only those which operate overseas with overseas subsidiaries or branches. However, it is a measure which increases the cost structure of those particular firms. In other words, it is a taxation measure which is based not on the principle of making Australian industry more competitive but on the tired old Labor strategy of wealth redistribution, which militates against wealth creation. Also it is based on Labor's tired old strategy and tired old rhetoric of the politics of envy, which is so destructive to the objective of economic growth.

It is always argued-including by the Treasurer (Mr Keating)-that a good taxation system is one based on the three principles of efficiency, equity and simplicity. It is on those three basic principles alone that this particular foreign tax credit system proposed by the Government falls down. First of all, as I have already explained by implication, the foreign tax credit system in economic terms is grossly inefficient. I will explain later how it works, but what it does is discourage the earning of foreign income by Australian companies. At a time when this country is running a balance of payments deficit on an annual basis of over $14 billion I would have thought that the Government would be trying to encourage the earning of foreign income, not discourage it. Therefore, it is inefficient.

Secondly, the measure is one which is inequitable. It is introduced on the basis of eliminating tax havens, yet what this does, as I will explain later, is to create a completely new tax rort. This is a point that does not seem to have been drawn to the attention of either the Treasurer or the officials in his Department. It is something that needs to be given proper consideration. Although it has been given proper consideration in other countries which have these systems, it has not been given consideration in this country, as I will explain later.

Thirdly, we are looking for a tax system which in some ways is at least more simple than the vastly complex tax system we have had up to now. One only needs to speak to the managers of any of the Australian companies which will now be confronted by this foreign tax credit system to know that this particular measure will be vastly complex to companies. Just the administration of the tax will increase their administrative costs very substantially.

The current arrangements for the taxing of foreign income are that that foreign income when it is returned to Australia is exempt from taxation. I do not think that that is necessarily an anomalous situation, particularly when one considers-it often is not considered-that those companies which have been operating overseas already have paid tax in the country in which they have earned that income. That is one of the bases of the various double taxation agreements that Australia has with a number of other countries. I might add that we have taken a long time in negotiating those double taxation agreements. As I understand it, there is an enormous backlog of those agreements. I hope that the Government will do something to accelerate the negotiations of those agreements so that at least that will assist Australian companies operating overseas. Let us remember that Australian companies already have paid tax in, if one likes to use the economists' term, the `host country' in which they are operating.

We have three basic objections to the foreign tax credits system. In addition there is an objection in relation to the tax rort brought about by this measure. First of all, it does not take into consideration the fact that Australian companies operating in other countries have to cope with a completely different cost structure and a completely different taxation system from that which exists in Australia. Some countries place a greater emphasis on indirect taxation and less emphasis on income tax, which is the reverse of what we do in this country. An Australian company-operating in a country such as that-will already have borne a very substantial burden of taxation through the indirect taxation system.

In other words, the taxation system, to some extent, reflects the general cost structure of a particular country. Any government which has the slightest concern about the growth and survival of its economy will ensure that its tax structure and its taxation system promote competitiveness. I know that the Australian Government does not do that, but the governments of most other countries do, so where there are other substantial cost disadvantages those countries will be pursuing policies to offset them, in some respects through the taxation system. In any case, the different tax structures do lead to substantially different tax and cost outcomes. Imposing Australian company tax, a tax which will be one of the highest in the world, on Australian companies operating off-shore will only make those companies substantially less competitive, and less competitive, of course, in relation to other companies operating in those countries.

My second objection is also important and relates to my first objection; that is, that Australian companies operating off-shore and employing Australians in other countries have to cope already with a quite distorted Australian cost structure in relation to their employees. They have, of course, to pay Australian wage rates with all sorts of additional allowances for those who live outside Australia. In almost every case they have to provide some sort of housing. They now have to pay a fringe benefits tax on fringe benefits such as housing, which is a compulsory benefit that they provide. In addition to those cost problems, they will be hit with the highest company tax rate-or one of the highest company tax rates-in the world through the operation of the foreign tax credit system. It is inevitable that this system will discourage Australian firms from investing overseas; that brings me to my third objection.

I think that it is extraordinarily negative to try to stop Australian companies from expanding into other countries. They have to pay a company tax rate of 49 per cent if they are operating in Malaysia, Singapore, the United Kingdom or the United States of America whereas other companies operating in those countries, for example, Malaysia and Singapore, are paying 40 per cent company tax. If they are operating in the United Kingdom they are paying a tax rate in the vicinity of 35 per cent and the United States is heading towards a company tax rate of 33 per cent; so at least the home based companies operating in those countries are paying a very much lower rate of company tax than will Australian firms under this proposal. Mr Eric Mayer, Chairman of the Taxation Review Task Force of the Business Council of Australia, summed matters up very clearly when he said the following on 31 July 1985:

The Council believes that a foreign tax credit system would have a serious and negative effect on the existing overseas business operations of Australian companies and restrict desirable Australian overseas investment in the future with an attendant depressing effect on business and employment both overseas and in Australia. At a time when the Government is trying to encourage a stronger international orientation by Australian companies and promote export growth a foreign tax credit system would simply be counterproductive to this policy objective. The ability of Australian companies to grow by seeking economies of scale beyond the limited constraints of the Australian domestic market would be discouraged by a foreign tax credit system. Often, expansion into the large markets, for instance, in Asia and the Pacific Basin, represents the only way in which Australian business can grow and support ongoing operations.

I think that that was a very telling statement, one which sums up the third major objection that I have to this legislation. It will stop Australian companies from investing overseas. Many of them have already made that point publicly. It will limit their capacity to achieve economies of scale, which is a very difficult thing to achieve in a small domestic market of 15 million people. Those companies have to try to expand their operations off-shore. However, they will not be able to do that-or at least there will be a disincentive for them to do that-because of this measure. In turn, they will not achieve the economies of scale that they need to compete internationally. All of that will limit economic development in Australia and will also limit economic development in developing countries, or at least in those developing countries, in which Australian firms wish to operate or are operating. Those lost countries, whether developing countries or not, desperately need investment from the developed world. They desperately need technology transfers from the developed world. This is one of the most constructive ways, if not the most constructive way, of providing development in those countries. However, it is being inhibited by this Government with its foreign tax credit proposal.

It is also important to point out in this context that by inhibiting Australian investment overseas the Government is inhibiting the development of Australian export markets, because there is absolutely no doubt that where Australian investment goes abroad so Australian exports will follow that firm in varying degrees. That process is now being discouraged. Inevitably, many Australian companies will do one of two things; they will either close down their subsidiaries overseas or move the whole of their operation from Australia off-shore. Both of those things would be very much to the disadvantage of the Australian economy.

In the last couple of minutes left to me I will say something about the new tax rort that this foreign tax credit system will create. Under the Australian proposal-and this does not apply to the foreign tax credit systems that some other countries such as the United States and the United Kingdom have-this tax will not apply if the profits of an Australian subsidiary are held overseas rather than repatriated to Australia. Inevitably, should an Australian company keep its subsidiaries overseas it will do its best to avoid paying this foreign tax credit. Needless to say, with the highest company tax rate in the world, they cannot be blamed for doing that. What Australian companies will do is get their subsidiaries to lend money to the Australian parent company instead of repatriating profits so that they can hold their dollar earnings overseas. In order to avoid this taxation, a subsidiary will lend money to the parent company here in Australia. That, of course, is a form of tax avoidance; that is a tax rort, and is something that has not been addressed in this legislation-it has apparently not even been considered by the Government. SPEECH.PARA: I also draw to the attention of the House some of the significant changes we have made to the taxation system. In particular, the taxation rebates for persons receiving unemployment and other benefits will be increased from $75 a year to $220 a year for married or de facto couples, and from $50 a year to $170 per year for single beneficiaries. These increases will ensure that persons wholly or mainly dependent on social welfare benefits will pay no tax in 1985-86.
