TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Treasurer still believe, as he has repeatedly argued, that the reduction of the productivity claim from 4 per cent to 3 per cent, its staggered implementation and the 2 per cent wage discount at the current national wage case will be sufficient to isolate totally the effect of the depreciation on the consumer price index and that there is therefore no need for additional wage discounting?

—The Government Statistician's measured direct effects have come within the 2 per cent. In respect of the indirect effects, the honourable member will recall that delaying the 3 per cent cost of superannuation over a year would have a national cost of about 1 1/2 per cent, so the deferment of that cost to 1 July 1986 would go a substantial way to meeting indirect costs. Therefore, in respect of the depreciation on the Statistician's measurement of the direct cost, I think the answer is in the affirmative.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT: PRIVATE SECTOR INVESTMENT

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. What are the implications of the figures issued yesterday by the Australian Bureau of Statistics about private sector investment in research and development since the Hawke Government took office? Is there a change in direction or is it a case of too little too late? Are the sleepers in the private sector starting to wake?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The figures released yesterday by the Australian Bureau of Statistics compare Australia's performance in private sector research and development in the years 1978-79, 1981-82, and 1984-85. Three indicators are provided. The first indicator is the number of enterprises that received research and development expenditure, in both current dollar and constant dollar figures and in person years of effort-something which, in more sexist times, used to be called man years. The tables confirmed that between 1978-79 and 1981-82 the person years of effort fell in Australia from 8,626 to 8,388-a pathetically small figure of not much more than one-tenth of one per cent of the total labour force at a time when the private sector in every Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development nation was increasing its research and development work sharply. However, for 1984-85 up to the twenty-seventh month of the Hawke Government, the figure increased from 8,388 person years to 11,435 person years-a rise of 36.3 per cent. Actual expenditure rose by 51 per cent in constant dollars or 80 per cent in current prices while the number of enterprises rose by 39.6 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: While this change in direction is to be welcomed, a few cautionary words are in order. First, the change is long overdue. We could and should have started it 15 years ago. Second, we have a great distance to go to catch up with the raised levels of private sector research and development activity in Japan, the United States of America, Britain and Canada. Those countries are a long way ahead. Third, when we start from a low base, a sharp relative increase may not mean very much in absolute terms. This is like the honourable member for Denison's popularity. Our long incapacity to recognise the technological revolution around us is reflected in our very adverse terms of trade in high technology products. We still rank twenty-first of 24 OECD nations in the value of high technology imports over exports. Only Greece, Iceland and Turkey are lower.

I have been saying for years that Australia is now passing through an information revolution. I commend Dr Bill Caelli's article in yesterday's Australian which points out that in the nine months to March 1986 information technology products accounted for 12.8 per cent or $3.3 billion of imports in a narrow definition-that is, computers and office equipment-and 23.6 per cent of imports of $6.2 billion in a broader definition which includes music and entertaining equipment. The ABS figures are only a start. We have a great deal of rethinking to do. The sleepers are waking but they have taken a long time to do it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Treasurer. I refer him to his assurance that the Government is confident that the proposed fringe benefits tax liability on farm employers will not be unduly harsh and also to his calculation that the cost may be only a few dollars a week. Would the Treasurer consider a new fringe benefits tax liability of $25 a week on farm employers to be unduly harsh, given that many are experiencing income losses and that the average net farmer income is only $73 a week?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicated to the House the other day that if one took 60 per cent of what the employee of a farm is charged in terms of the rental value of a farmhouse building and then deducted from that the amount which is paid by the employee in rent and took 49 per cent of that amount, the value would have to be fairly substantial for the liability to reach $25 per week. It would mean that the farmer himself or herself was establishing a value on the rent which would be higher than the ones which I think are generally being charged. In that case the farmer would need to be certain that the value of the rental accommodation was being appropriately priced for taxation purposes. But in many cases we are talking about something in the order of $40. A 40 per cent discount on that would get us back to about $34. If one were charging the employee $20 or $25 a week one may then be taxing $10 a week at 49 per cent, which is $4.90. I am not saying that all farm employees are charged a rental of $40 for accommodation, but that is a fairly common figure. If the figure is markedly above that, presumably so too is the rental which the farmer charges and, after the 40 per cent discount and at the 49 per cent rate, I still think we are dealing with modest sums of money.

ANSWER.PARA: I think in fairness to the honourable gentleman and in fairness to the Government I ought to say that the fringe benefits tax is but part of a package of measures which the Government has introduced. The point is that the same farmer will enjoy the benefit of a reduction in the top marginal rate from 60 per cent to 49 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —When?

—I gave the honourable gentleman the answer to that yesterday. I thought that after they did the job on him in Adelaide he would have heard the answer. I gave it to him yesterday-it was 1 July 1987. If the farm is incorporated, as many are of course, there will now be no double taxation on the distribution. When one thinks about all incorporated enterprises, including farms, having the capability of putting distribution into the hands of shareholders and removing the corporate tax rate as it now applies, one can see that that is of substantial benefit. In this respect, the whole Government tax reform package is essentially about taking away some of the tax advantages or tax rorts which have been in the system to give other taxpayers the benefit of generally lower taxation rates. Instead of facing a marginal rate of 60 per cent, at one and a half times average weekly earnings, one would face a marginal rate of 49 per cent. The rates under that, instead of being 48 and 46 per cent, could be 40 per cent. These measures are of substantial and material benefit to all people, including farmers.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Social Security been drawn to media reports that an ex-officer of the Department of Social Security has written a book about how to cheat the social security system? Has this ex-officer demonstrated how to beat the system with impunity?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that an ex-officer of the Department has attempted to put his rather dishonest and extraordinary claims into practice and that he has enlisted the assistance of his wife to do so. The wife of this former departmental officer was recently granted the supporting parent's benefit in Western Australia. The former officer who was legitimately claiming the unemployment benefit at the time had his payment reduced to the single rate following the alleged separation. The payment of the supporting parent's benefit to his wife was swiftly suspended shortly after grant when follow-up investigations indicated possible misrepresentation. After, and only after, suspension and before the investigation was complete he visited the social security office in Western Australia claiming that he had also been receiving the unemployment benefit by misrepresentation to an office in New South Wales. Prior to this he tried to receive additional benefit by claiming his sister-in-law's children as his own. His application was rejected because they were not in his custody, care and control. Other matters relating to possible fraud and misrepresentation are currently under investigation. This person's rather poor record of success and the possibility of his prosecution must deter those who foolishly seek to use his less than foolproof manual of crime. The conduct of both him and his wife has been referred to the Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions.

ANSWER.PARA: Without in any way pre-empting the decision of the Director of Public Prosecutions, I must say that I believe this sordid affair demonstrates the foolishness of those who try to break the law and the very serious consequences for those who are caught. The social security system, with 105 million transactions completed each year, relies, like most organisations where the distribution of money is concerned, on the integrity of officials given responsibility for administration, particularly in relation to security. I am sure that our banking institutions would be outraged if one of their managers wrote a manual for the general public, using his intimate knowledge of security, to suggest a career of armed robbery for the general populace. The Department of Social Security uses a range of security measures and investigative procedures, most of which I cannot divulge to the House for obvious reasons. Indeed, I refer to this specific case for the fairly obvious reason that I know the person involved intends to divulge much of this information on television. However, I refer honourable members to comments I made in the House on 26 May, on overpayment detection.

All systems, no matter how sophisticated, are vulnerable to fraud by trusted employees. Fortunately, most employees are trustworthy, just as most citizens are honest and law-abiding. It is a sad fact of life that there are a few people who are not honest, who lie and cheat or misrepresent their circumstances. That is why we have police and courts to deal with these people. It is no excuse to say that one breaks the law to test the system. That is hollow and implausible. While many of the claims of this former officer have been found to be without foundation, others are continuing to be examined.

I say in closing that I found it most disappointing that the honourable member for Richmond, when interviewed in relation to this book, failed to condemn the project in any way or to disassociate himself from this kind of activity. The Government is continually investigating possible loopholes in the operation of the social security system and closing them either by administrative changes or by legislation. I was recently speaking to a delegation from Canada, who were extremely impressed with the fact that, whereas Canada's social security legislation is rarely amended, our legislation is amended on a continuing basis, with a Bill being presented every session. That means that we have the opportunity each year to tighten up and to learn from information that comes to hand. I must say that this exercise is a very nasty one and I think all honourable members of the House would condemn what this person is seeking to do in publishing this very dishonest tract.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Treasurer: Does his answer to the question asked by the honourable member for Mackellar mean that the Government will support full wage indexation in future national wage cases and will not pursue any discounting of wages additional to that contained in the accord mark 2?

—That was not the implication in either the question or the answer. I was asked whether I thought the discount the Government had negotiated in respect of the direct price effects of the depreciation was the appropriate one. The answer to that is in the affirmative. In respect of full wage indexation, under the principles there is always an area where the Government may introduce argument, if it sees fit from time to time, about the question of a guaranteed level of full indexation in particular cases. We always reserve our right to put those views, if we see fit, in the light of economic circumstances.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Health. In view of the clearly demonstrated ability of medical research to contribute to improvements in health care and, indeed, to effect reductions in health costs, will the Minister assure the medical research community that he will be arguing strenuously for a continued upgrading of financial support by this Government for medical research in the 1986-87 Budget?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —From the outset this Government has recognised the contribution that medical research could make, both to the long term health of the Australian community and also, of course, to cost containment in the long run. I think we have proven over the past three years our recognition of the importance of health research. In the 1985-86 Budget the Government appropriated $50.8m for medical research through the Medical Research Endowment Fund. This represented an increase of 14.9 per cent over the 1984-85 year and it represents, over the three years, a 71.5 per cent cumulative increase in moneys allocated to medical research. I think even our critics would not disparage the achievement in this area. In fact, there is no period in the Commonwealth's history when a government has made so sustained a commitment to medical research.

ANSWER.PARA: The Hawke Government has also introduced other measures to encourage private investment in research. These include a 150 per cent tax deduction for eligible companies spending money on research and development in Australia and, of course, the national biotechnology program research grant scheme, which gives preference to research proposals involving direct collaboration with private industry. One would hope that, as a result of these two major initiatives by the Hawke Government, there will be a greater investment of the private sector in medical and health research in this country and that will find a position much more comparable with countries such as the United States of America and Canada. I certainly can assure the honourable member for Perth that I will be fighting to maintain that excellent record in the Budget debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Treasurer to advice given by the Australian Taxation Office this week to the hospitality industry in relation to the fringe benefits tax. Is the Treasurer aware that a motel owner who requires a cook to live on the premises and allows him to eat in the kitchen would be liable to a fringe benefits tax of some $6,000 on his accommodation and some $5,000 on his meals because the valuation is based on the commercial retail rates prevailing for that room and for those meals? Can the Treasurer confirm that such a fringe benefits tax on the hospitality industry will create severe unemployment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I address the detail of the question, I point out again that this is another question put as though the owner of the particular hospitality industry-it is a hotel, I presume-receives no benefit from a reduction in marginal rates or the imputation system. If this was a substantial operation it would probably be incorporated. On every $100 of company income that shareholder at the moment is paying 46c in the dollar company tax, leaving $54; and if the person is paying an average rate of 40 per cent or 50 per cent he would be receiving about $27 out of every $100 of company income. Under the imputation system he will receive $51 out of $100, and not $27. It is not much good coming up with all these hard luck stories and then on the same basis denying that this is a package, a package which is revenue neutral to the Government. The Government hands back all the proceeds of the fringe benefits tax to taxpayers. That needs to be understood clearly by everyone in the community, including members of the Opposition.

ANSWER.PARA: The provision of accommodation, depending on the level of the rental value of that accommodation, would be fringe benefit taxed and the meals would be fringe benefit taxed. If $5,000 is the tax on meals, the tax being at 49 per cent, there would be $10,000 worth of meals a year. That is $250 a week, so it is a pretty dear pub. If that is what they charge the housekeeper, God help the patrons! If somebody pays for another person's meals, that is a benefit which is outside the tax system, and, as we say, we are handing back the full proceeds of the fringe benefits tax. To get all of this in perspective: The package will raise about $600m. Over half of that will come from the motor vehicle area alone. Therefore, the balance, including all the other questions I have had about farms--

TALK.START.PARA: —How much for charities?

—The honourable member keeps making this point about charities. Let me make this point again specifically for the honourable member, because it takes a lot to penetrate the block of ivory that he has on his shoulders. If a charity is handing out cars and credit cards and the rest, why does anyone in the House believe that the employee of a charity ought to be receiving those benefits outside the tax system when employees of any other body do not? It is as simple as that.
—Because a charity has a need for a car, you thickhead.
—Order!
—Let me just make this other point: The Government has made it quite clear-

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Donald Cameron interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Moreton will cease interjecting. I warn the honourable member for Moreton.

—The Government has made the position quite clear in relation to charities, particularly major ones, which may be affected in this way. However, it is a pretty curious proposition for a charity trying to keep the show on the road to hand out massive fringe benefits. One wonders why a charity would be handing out massive fringe benefits, anyway, but if it has handed out fringe benefits which are so large as to give it an economic problem, the Government has said that it will address that directly on the outlay side of the Budget. We have made that quite clear, and we repeat it. The honourable member for Moreton interjected, but I ask him to please listen to the answer. I go back to the main point: Outside the motor vehicle area, there is about $300m across the whole of all the other sectors of the economy in fringe benefits taxation, including the farm sector. Therefore, there is not much point in drawing pictures of economic debilitation around particular cases, when the broad impact of this is still going to be modest in terms of the increases in profitability for the whole economy, sector by sector, particularly for the hospitality industry.

ANSWER.PARA: The hospitality industry was one of the first industries to gain a benefit from the depreciation of the dollar, with a very high level of increase in local destinations for travel. It is the hospitality industry which has now been given a 4 per cent write-off for buildings. The hospitality industry has had the benefits of higher growth in activity and a higher level of incomes than would have been the case under the policies honourable members opposite pursue and have pursued for years. That is why there has been very strong employment growth in the hospitality industry. I remind honourable members opposite about when they had the handkerchiefs out for the restaurants a couple of months ago-there was going to be wholesale slaughter of the restaurants. Well, members opposite were wrong, were they not? How about that! They were wrong, and the fact is that they are wrong again.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Trade. I refer the Minister to the widely publicised incitement by Mr Bob Ansett to business persons to break proposed Commonwealth laws. Does this incitement conflict with Mr Ansett's role as an adviser to the Government? I remind the Minister of the old Chinese adage that to punish one is to educate one hundred. Will the Minister take steps to dismiss Mr Ansett from his position as Chairman of the Trade Negotiations Advisory Group of the Trade Development Council?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first point I want to make is that Mr Ansett was appointed to the Trade Negotiations Advisory Group of the Trade Development Council for the assistance that he might give us on trade and not for any absurd views that he might have on the taxation system. The point is that I think a number of people would be impressed by Mr Ansett's business record, particularly in the area of services and indeed in the export of services, and it was for that reason that I thought it might be a good idea to include someone like that in this group. It seems to me that the problems confronting Australia are such that we should try to bring together those people who have a reasonable contribution to make to improving Australia's trade position. However, I must disassociate myself from these views that he expresses. It is not that we object to people who are on these advisory groups holding views different from ours. We do not appoint people to advisory groups simply to echo the Government's views. What is different in this particular case is that Mr Ansett has decided to incite people to break an impending law. I think in that way he puts himself in an entirely different class. I just want to say that I am not quite sure what objection Mr Ansett has to the fringe benefits.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Tuckey interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I warn the honourable member for O'Connor. If he interjects again I will name him.
—I did not hear the interjection from the honourable member for O'Connor.
—Then there is no need to comment on it.
—Well, I am sure we were all fascinated by his literary allusion of a few weeks ago.
—On a point of order, Madam Speaker: It is interesting to see the Minister get his courage up, is it not, when you, Madam Speaker, tell me to shut up. He would not do it before.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will resume his seat.

INTERJECT.PARA: Mr Tuckey interjecting-

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I name the honourable member for O'Connor.

INTERJECT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Young) proposed:
That the honourable member for O'Connor be suspended from the service of the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that the motion be agreed to. Those of that opinion say aye, to the contrary no. I think the ayes have it.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Sinclair

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, could I suggest to you that the naming of the honourable gentleman, in the circumstances of your having warned him and the Minister for Trade deliberately having incited him, is totally unjustified.

INTERJECT.PARA: Government members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members on my right are not assisting either the House or the Chair.

—Madam Speaker, after you had warned the honourable member for O'Connor the Minister for Trade deliberately commented upon matters relating to the honourable member for O'Connor. In his answer he specifically referred to some literary allusions which apparently the honourable member for O'Connor had made. I suggest that it was in those circumstances quite justifiable for the honourable member for O'Connor to seek to respond in the only way possible within the Standing Orders of this place.

—In reply to the Leader of the National Party: The Chair has given the honourable member for O'Connor over a number of days a certain amount of indulgence. The Chair does not intend to continue that indulgence.
—Dawkins is gutless.

—Order! The honourable member for North Sydney will not interrupt the Chair. The honourable member for O'Connor chose to disregard the Chair's authority. He has been named. The question has been put and given to the ayes.
—Madam Speaker, I call for a division.
—Is a division required?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Sinclair

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question put:
That the honourable member for O'Connor be suspended from the service of the House.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for O'Connor is suspended from the service of the House for 24 hours.

INTERJECT.PARA: The honourable member for O'Connor thereupon withdrew from the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I was referring to the--
—Tax dodger Dawkins. Tax evader Dawkins.
—Order! The Leader of the National Party will withdraw that comment.
—Which one?
—The right honourable Leader of the National Party knows which comment.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Sinclair

TALK.START.PARA: —I withdraw the remark `dodger Dawkins'.

INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Would honourable members on my left be silent and would the Minister continue his answer.
—What about what Dawkins said?
—What did he say? How can the Chair hear what he said?
—You have a marvellously deaf ear on your right.
—Order! The honourable member for North Sydney will not cast aspersions upon the Chair.
—I was saying that we do not--
—Are you going to attack somebody else outside the House?
—I am not going to attack him at all. I said that we do not appoint people to advisory bodies simply to echo our views. There would not be any point in having them if we did.
—Is the Ansett scheme better than the Dawkins scheme? Is that what you are complaining about?
—The Deputy Leader of the Opposition will withdraw that comment.
—No, I will not. Why should I?
—Because the honourable member has been asked to do so by the Chair.
—On what grounds?
—The Chair will not allow personal aspersions to be cast across the table.
—Very well, I withdraw in deference to you, Madam Speaker.

—The point to be made here is that, in relation to the fringe benefits tax, it is not clear whether Mr Ansett's views are expressed in his role as an employer or in his role as a provider of otherwise tax free benefits to the employees of others. The whole point is that if the executives, that relatively small minority of the work force who receive tax free fringe benefits, were paid their remuneration package entirely in cash, of course, there would be no fringe benefits tax. Indeed, they would then be treated in precisely the same way as the overwhelming majority of the work force who happen to be much less well remunerated in total terms. Mr Ansett is entitled to his views on these matters; what he is not entitled to do is encourage people to break an impending law. It is not my intention to remove Mr Ansett from the advisory group, but I would have to say to him that, if he persists in providing this advice and taking this attitude in relation to the breaking of an impending law, it is a fact that the value of his advice will be diminished, as will his credit in the community generally.

DEBATE.TITLE: MINISTER FOR LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND ADMINISTRATIVE SERVICES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the House that today is the birthday of the father of the House, the Hon. Tom Uren. We wish him all the best.
—Happy birthday, father.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House notes that this day marks the twenty-fifth anniversary of the foundation of Amnesty International and records its continuing support for Amnesty's efforts in the promotion and protection of human rights.

Amnesty International today celebrates with pride 25 years of successful endeavour to identify and free prisoners of conscience, to secure fair and prompt trials for political prisoners, and to end torture and executions throughout the world. From small beginnings, Amnesty has become an organisation with over half a million members, supporters and subscribers world-wide. It has made ordinary people all over the world aware of the plight of those defending the human rights we in Australia take for granted. It has succeeded in bringing practical help to thousands of victims of abuse.

Amnesty International seeks to secure throughout the world the observance of the provisions of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. It has brought home to all governments the indisputable fact that the rights proclaimed by this Declaration apply to all people. These rights have been incorporated into many countries' constitutions and laws, and have been elaborated in other international human rights standards adopted by the United Nations.

In Australia Amnesty has some 10,000 committed members in branches in all States. One hundred and thirty groups are working hard towards the release of prisoners of conscience. The Government particularly commends the current campaign whereby the entire membership is writing to 10,000 decision-makers in South Africa towards this end.

For its part, the Government is committed to continuing, both bilaterally and in multilateral bodies, its active pursuit of these important human rights issues. The high priority the Government accords to these issues was clearly illustrated last year by our signature of the United Nations Convention Against Torture, appropriately on Human Rights Day, 10 December 1985. The strong support for this Convention by all branches of Amnesty in Australia and by Amnesty throughout the world was crucial to its acceptance by the United Nations General Assembly. We are actively working towards ratification of the Convention.

Amnesty International's work on this and other human rights issues has been most valuable to the Government, and we are always ready to take into account Amnesty's information and representations and to follow them up as appropriate. Australia has been an increasingly active member of the United Nations Commission on Human Rights over the last two years, and has given strong support to action on torture, summary and arbitrary execution, and disappeared persons, issues of special concern to Amnesty.

Australia is closely associated with the current initiative in the Commission on Human Rights to draft a declaration, the aim of which is to protect the rights of individuals and groups like Amnesty to promote and protect human rights. This Parliament has a very active Amnesty International group, as honourable members are aware, as is appropriate to an institution which is central to Australia's fundamental ideals of freedom and democracy. Members from all parties co-operate effectively for a common cause which is important to us all.

No Australian had a greater concern about the human rights of his fellow men than the late Senator Alan Missen. At a ceremony in King's Hall earlier today with which I was associated along with leaders of other parties, I was proud to announce that the Parliamentary Amnesty group had decided to establish a permanent memorial to Alan Missen, which will reflect his lifetime commitment to human rights causes and his service to Amnesty.

Amnesty International has taken as its symbol a candle surrounded by barbed-wire in recognition of the truth of the ancient Chinese proverb `Better to light a candle than curse the darkness'. That candle has become a symbol of concern for human rights among decent people everywhere and of hope for those suffering oppression for their political beliefs in many countries around the world. I am sure that I speak for all honourable members in congratulating Amnesty International on its twenty-fifth anniversary and in expressing our continuing support for the work of this exemplary international organisation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I assure the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that on this occasion he speaks for all members of the House in congratulating Amnesty International on its twenty-fifth anniversary. It is a very special body and a very special cause that in this Parliament can draw together the support of all the political parties and for that support to be freely and publicly given. Amnesty is one such body. It is committed to some basic ideals that are important to the Australian way of life-the concepts of political liberty, personal freedom, freedom of expression, and support and encouragement to those in other parts of the world who would seek to exercise similar rights of free political choice to those that are exercised in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Over its 25 years of existence the Amnesty movement has encouraged prisoners of political conscience all over the world, irrespective of whether they have lived under regimes of the Right or the Left, to continue their struggle for personal expression and individual freedom. In that sense the body has won the support and respect of political parties of both the Right and the Left in the free world. Deservedly, in this Parliament and in other parliaments, the Amnesty body is one that draws very strong bipartisan support.

I would like, as has the Prime Minister, to express my congratulations to the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner) and Senator Puplick, a senator for New South Wales, in particular, who do so much to further the work of Amnesty in the Parliament. Also, I take pride as parliamentary Leader of the Liberal Party in recording my appreciation for the decision of Amnesty in this Parliament to inaugurate a memorial lecture in memory of the late Alan Missen, whose work for Amnesty and whose commitment to the ideals that Amnesty stood for have been remarked upon, and deservedly so, by members on both sides of the House in recent times. He embodied the bipartisan support for Amnesty that is so very important for the survival of that body. He was a person who, with others, was able to put aside partisan political differences for this cause. It is therefore particularly fitting that a lecture should be inaugurated in his memory. I am quite sure that if he had thought of an epitaph, this would have been one that would have very greatly warmed him because of his commitment to political freedom and individual liberty. I warmly endorse the Prime Minister's remarks. It is fitting that this Parliament record its appreciation for the work of Amnesty and, in so doing, remark the contribution made by the late Alan Missen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek the indulgence of the House to comment further on the motion moved by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). In so doing, I speak on behalf of members of the National Party of Australia to say that the tragedy of the celebration of Amnesty International's twenty-fifth anniversary is the reality that there is a need for such a body. While bodies like the Red Cross, the Salvation Army, World Vision and many others work in either a charitable or religious role, the work of Amnesty occupies a different part of the political spectrum. The fact that there is total unanimity within this chamber and the other place as to the aspirations of those who work within Amnesty reflects the concern that in so many countries around the world there are still practices against the sanctity of the individual in the abuse of human rights.

SPEECH.PARA: Amnesty's twenty-fifth anniversary is marked by a growing world awareness of the difficulties that exist in so many countries around the world. This motion not only marks our commendation of those who work for this cause within this place-the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner), Senator Puplick, the late Alan Missen and others-but also reflects the marked efforts made by so many in parliamentary environments that are not quite so easy as this one. Indeed, I think it is as a token to them as much as to those in this place that I rise to support this motion. I commend those who, within the Parliamentary Group and the wider national group, work to achieve those motives, which we all endorse. I commend those who have worked within Amnesty for their 25 years of effort. I trust that by the time the next 25 years of its existence is over, the cause for which it fights might well have eased. One would only hope that absolute governments-be they of the Right or the Left-would see fit to recognise the sanctity of human rights and human liberty to a greater degree than, sadly, so many do this day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek, on behalf of the Parliamentary Group of Amnesty International, to join with the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in supporting his motion, which has been so warmly supported by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair). The Leader of the Opposition spoke of the basic high ideals of Amnesty. Perhaps it is appropriate briefly to refer to those at this time. Amnesty is a world-wide movement which is independent of any government, political faction, ideology, economic interest or religious creed. It plays a specific role within the overall spectrum of human rights work. The activities of the organisation focus strictly on prisoners. It seeks the release of men and women who are detained anywhere for their belief, colour, sex, ethnic origin, language or religion, provided they have neither used nor advocated violence. They are termed prisoners of conscience. Amnesty advocates fair and early trails for all political prisoners and works on behalf of such persons detained without charge or without trial. Finally, Amnesty opposes the death penalty and torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment of all prisoners without reservation.

SPEECH.PARA: Previous speakers have referred to the successes of the Amnesty organisation. There are 2,600 Amnesty groups and national sections in 40 countries and half a million members and supporters in 150 countries. It was put to me today by a member of the media that in some ways Amnesty has been a failure. It was put to me that half of the 159 members of the United Nations still hold prisoners of conscience. There have been reports of the use of torture in more than 60 countries. In over 50 countries people may be held without trial or charge and in 34 countries the death penalty continues in force-in many, for so-called crimes that are politically motivated. The Leader of the National Party was quite right in referring to this still outstanding, unresolved series of injustices regarding human rights that makes the continuation of the work of Amnesty so desperately needed.

With respect to the journalist who asked me a question, Amnesty has not been a failure. It has been an outstanding success. Merely looking at the vehemence of the attacks on the Amnesty organisation by totalitarian regimes of the Left and Right indicates that Amnesty is respected and listened to by governments world-wide. Amnesty has been a leader in promoting international standards of human rights. Were it not for Amnesty, the United Nations declaration on torture would probably never have come about. It has also been important, of course, in specific instances regarding human rights and prisoners of conscience. Were it not for Amnesty, many prisoners of conscience around the world would never, apart from their immediate families and friends, have their voices heard by the outside world. Ever since the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, no country can claim that human rights abuses are a matter for the internal jurisdiction of that country. That is no longer a tolerable position for any government to hold.

The work of Amnesty is based on the work of its individual members. As I remarked earlier today at the ceremony the Prime Minister referred to, let this motion and this twenty-fifth anniversary not be simply a symbolic recognition. Let them be a springboard for future action by Amnesty and by the wider Australian community, to make sure that the next 25 years of Amnesty are successful in removing those abuses of human rights that have been referred to by all speakers to this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to be associated with this motion. I have been involved with the Parliamentary Group of Amnesty International as its Chairman for a time and as a member for the 13 years in which the Group has functioned as a branch of Amnesty. I am very proud that within this Parliament there have been as many members as are and continue to be associated with it involved in the Parliamentary Group. It is a unique organisation. I do not know of any other organisation with which members of Parliament so readily associate themselves as they have with Amnesty International. Considering that it has been in existence for only 25 years and that for some 13 years of its existence members in this Parliament have been so active with it, its unique position will be appreciated. The Australian Parliamentary Group, as I understand it, is the only one of its type in the world. There is a Human Rights Group in the House of Commons in the United Kingdom, but nowhere else have members of Parliament joined an organisation such as Amnesty International.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not easy to be involved with Amnesty because when one takes up the issue of political prisoners and the issue of torture with governments on the basis Amnesty expects, with balance in the program being an important factor, one often finds that one's comments are condemned and criticised by those to whom advice is offered. I was recently in Kampuchea, and, while speaking to a political leader, I raised the question of political prisoners. I found that, whilst people were happy for Amnesty to investigate activities of the past, the present leadership had no interest in anyone looking at its human rights record in more recent years, and wanted to disparage Amnesty because of comments that it had offered. That was a country of the Left. I have equally raised questions in relation to countries that are described as right wing in character, and Amnesty has been equally disparaged by the governments of those countries. I remember a time when India was the subject of some criticism as a Third World nation, and there was criticism of Amnesty then as well.

It is the important balance in the program that makes Amnesty such a unique organisation. The fact that here in Australia parliamentarians across the board are prepared to be involved distinguishes us from places such as Canada, where, when I looked at what was happening there, it seemed to me that it was only the Opposition that was concerned to make political point-scoring on the issue of prisoners of conscience against the Government of the day. It seemed that, as governments changed, the parties that were raising the Amnesty issues changed. Here in Australia that has not been the case, and that makes us unique in the world.

I am delighted that this motion has been moved so ably by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and seconded by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and has been supported by other members, such as the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair), because this demonstrates the way in which Amnesty International has bipartisan support. As we take up issues in which we seek to involve members of Parliament in the future, I hope that we shall have the unanimous support of members of Parliament for those particular questions when they are raised.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: UNITED NATIONS EDUCATIONAL, SCIENTIFIC AND CULTURAL ORGANISATION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —With the indulgence of the Chair, Madam Speaker, I wish to read into the record an answer to a question which was raised on 22 May in this Parliament by the honourable member for Wentworth (Mr Coleman).
—Please proceed.

—On Thursday 22 May, the honourable member for Wentworth asked a question of the Minister representing the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Beazley, regarding provision by the Australian Ambassador to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation of certain information to the Director-General of UNESCO, Mr M'Bow. The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: The issue to which the honourable member refers is related to an initiative taken by the so-called Geneva Group, comprising the OECD members, including Australia, which each contribute more than one per cent of the budgets of the United Nations specialised agencies. A meeting of the Geneva Group on 20-21 March 1986 agreed on the principle of an Australian proposal that there should be a limit of two terms on the tenure in office of the heads of specialised agencies and other United Nations bodies. The honourable member will know of the Government's interest in the proposal from my answer to his question No. 2388 (Hansard, 29 November 1985, at page 4268).

A further meeting of the Geneva Group on 11 April agreed that this proposal should be taken up formally with the agency heads by the co-chairmen of the Group. The question of when this would be done was deferred pending further group consultations on 30 April.

Reflecting Australian concern that the Geneva Group's proposal should be discussed with the Director-General of UNESCO, Mr M'Bow, before the UNESCO Executive Board and special committee meetings beginning on 28 April, Mr Whitlam convoked meetings of Western UNESCO delegations on 16 and 22 April and indicated at the latter that it was his intention to pass to Mr M'Bow a copy of the Geneva Group proposal and to circulate copies to all Executive Board members. On 23 April he called on Mr M'Bow and gave him a summary of the decisions of the Geneva Group meeting. He also wrote to all Executive Board members on 24 April.

I am informed that it had always been intended that the initiative on tenure of Directors-General and other Geneva Group decisions would be discussed with the heads of agencies, including Mr M'Bow. The action was not contrary to instructions from Canberra, given the concern that has been expressed that Mr M'Bow should be briefed on the proposal about tenure before the Executive Board meeting, and the delay that was occurring from within the Geneva Group in informing him.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker has received a letter from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr N.A. Brown) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The public concern at the Government's incompetent handling of current industrial relations issues.

More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know where the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) is.
—He is on strike.

—I do not know whether he is on strike or whether he is off having another one of those peculiar negotiations with the trade union movement. If ever anything were needed to show the absolute, complete and final collapse of the Government's prices and incomes accord with the trade unions, it must surely have come today with the so-called national day of protest of the Australian Council of Trade Unions-a national day of protest in which members of the trade union movement have been incited to take industrial action to bludgeon the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission yet again into doing what the trade union movement wants it to do.

SPEECH.PARA: We say without any qualification whatsoever that we condemn this industrial action. We invite and encourage the Government to condemn it likewise. If the system of conciliation and arbitration which the Government continues to praise and hold out as the answer to all industrial problems is half as good as the Government says it is, it must have as an essential ingredient for its proper working compliance with the Arbitration Commission and support for the Arbitration Commission. It must be completely divorced from anything remotely resembling an attempt to intimidate or to put improper pressure upon the Arbitration Commission. What we are seeing today is yet another attempt to exert improper pressure on the Arbitration Commission, and complete silence from the Government in response to that pressure. If the Government will not dissociate itself from this industrial action, if it will not take in hand its constituent members of the trade union movement and encourage them to show more respect for the Commission, for the community and for the future of this nation, we say that the Government should be utterly condemned.

There is no doubt that if anything were needed to show that the accord had been a miserable failure we have seen it today in this now outbreak of industrial disputation, involving apparently some 500,000 people, egged on by the Australian Council of Trade Unions, with no criticism or condemnation from the Government. It has always been the great claim of the Government that on a twofold basis the accord holds the future for the security, development and progress of this country. The Government has always put it on a dual basis. It said first of all that the accord would introduce-it says it has introduced-a new dawn of economic progress and that this new dawn would beam down on the happy people of Australia as a result solely of the prices and incomes accord. We have seen this claim made in so many places, particularly in a comic-book presentation from the Government entitled `Accord-The First 2 Years'. Honourable members will remember the booklet. It is the one in which the inflation rate is depicted as floating down merrily, like a balloon, to 5.1 per cent at December 1984. According to the Government, the inflation rate coming down would be the great success of the accord. There is no sign of any second edition of this booklet being released to show that the balloon has now filled with helium and has taken off to give us an inflation rate of 9.2 per cent, and it is apparently merrily on the way up. That is the presentation that the Government made. Secondly, it has said that with this accord an unparalleled nirvana has descended upon the country and the people are the happy recipients of a new era of industrial harmony.

Let us look at both of those statements briefly, because they are both absolutely false and show the complete failure of the prices and incomes accord. Let us look at the first proposal that the Government put under the accord. It said that the accord was responsible for a new dawn of economic progress. We say that the accord has produced record interest rates in this country and it is producing an inflation rate which is higher than that in virtually any industrialised country in the world. It is an accord which has produced the real lasting monument of the Hawke Government-600,000 people unemployed with no hope of the unemployment level ever being reduced. Most recently and most disastrously, the accord, working its way through the centralised arbitration system, has produced a balance of payments situation which can only be described as a national crisis. That is what has been produced by the accord.

We can see in our most recently published trade figures that what is happening to this country as a result of the accord and of the economic policies pursued by this Government is that our nation is now pricing itself out of goods and out of trade overseas, and it is pricing itself out of jobs. There should be no argument about the first leg of the prop that the Government put under the accord, because it is obvious to anyone who is prepared to look at the facts that the accord has been economically a complete failure. It has not brought prosperity to this nation. It is bringing to it economic ruin.

The Government said that the other great achievement of the accord was that it had introduced industrial peace and harmony to this country. If anything were needed to disprove that nonsense, we would simply have to look at what we are faced with today. Today we are faced with a demand by the Australian Council of Trade Unions, its orders having been sent out through its constituent union bodies that the members of those trade unions will go on strike, that they will take part in industrial stoppages, that they will take extended breaks, that they will engage in whatever industrial action they can engage in to force and bludgeon the Arbitration Commission to bring down decisions in the current wages case before it which are not conducive to the economic prosperity of this country but which are simply what the trade union movement wants. That is what is happening.

If there were any need for evidence that the accord has been a failure with regard to the industrial situation in this country, it must be found in what this country is faced with today. In the first place, it is utterly false to say that the accord has brought about industrial peace in this country, and that is seen to be doubly false when we look at the evidence available today. We have seen the statistics. Of course, the Minister and the Government are all very keen to trot out statistics to show how the number of industrial disputes of over 10 or more days has dropped.

TALK.START.PARA: —He will do it again today, no doubt.

—No doubt the Minister will do that again today. The Government does not tell us what is happening with industrial disputes in those areas that are not recorded in the statistics. There is evidence, of which the House should be aware, on what is actually happening at the work place and on the shop floor in the area of industrial disputation. We say that this sort of industrial disputation in this country comes about because of the excessive power of the trade union movement and because the Government, whose masters are in the trade union movement, will not stand up to them.

SPEECH.PARA: I said that there was evidence of this wider industrial disputation and it is apparent now for any honourable member who wants to see it by examining the statistics and the real facts. It has been like pulling teeth to get this document out of the Minister. Honourable members may not be aware that the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations keeps a report on industrial statistics. This document tells the story that is not told in the statistics that the Government is always so keen to trot out. What do we see from this document? It contains 388 pages of industrial disputes which have occurred since March this year-388 pages of disputes which have originated since March, egged on by the trade union movement and never criticised or condemned by this Government. These disputes are causing this country and its people untold economic damage. The document reveals that 324 new disputes have been notified since March this year. It has always been utterly false to say that there has been a new dawn of industrial harmony in this country as a result of the accord. If anything is needed to put a final nail in the coffin, it must be the industrial disputation which is taking place today.

We say that this situation has been brought on and egged on by the Government because the Government has not been prepared to condemn it or to exert any pressure or influence on the trade union movement at all in order to bring this disputation to an end. It is not simply that the Government stands by and does nothing; it wants to make things worse, it wants to give more power to the trade union movement. We see this from the leaked-and I emphasise leaked-Australian Labor Party industrial relations policy which was thoughtfully brought to public notice by some public-spirited citizen only a few days ago. This policy shows the Labor Party in its true colours. It proposes to make four major changes to the industrial law of this country which can only strengthen the position of the trade union movement and encourage more industrial disputation to the detriment of this nation. We have seen all this from the leaked ALP industrial relations policy. The ALP wants, first of all, to exempt trade unions from the provisions of the Trade Practices Act. Today we have seen the hypocrisy of the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins) who is concerned with that Act, saying that outside citizens are complaining about a law that has not even been passed by the Parliament. Yet his own Party is proposing a change to the law so that trade unions will be exempt from the legal provisions contained in an Act that has already been passed by this Parliament and implemented.

The second ALP proposal is that trade unions should be immune from common law actions for the damage they do in the course of industrial disputes. According to the ALP, it does not matter that there is a law, that damage has flowed from a breach of the law and that innocent victims of that damage should have the right to sue and get some compensation. Oh no, the ALP says that trade unions are different, they are above the law and they should be exempted from the liability that applies to everyone else. The third point that the ALP makes in this policy is that subcontractors-people who are not even employees, people who should be and want to be free to lead their own lives in their own way-should be subject to the compulsory union membership that is so widely spread in this country and, of course, subject to the straightjacket of trade union awards obtained through the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.

As if all that were not enough, the ALP then goes on to say that it wants the repeal of all penal provisions directed at trade unions. Is it any wonder that the trade union movement today thumbs its nose at the Government. First of all, the Government turns a blind eye to any industrial action and then secondly, by way of policy of its own party, it goes further and encourages the trade union movement to engage in further industrial disputation from which this nation and its people can only suffer. What is the Government response to all of this? It goes off to conferences with the trade union movement; it waffles about upcoming meetings of advisory bodies; but it will not take the hard decisions which must be taken. We have told it what hard decisions are needed if this country is not to continue down the economic slippery slope into ruin and we defy the Government today to stand up in this place and say one way or the other whether it will make these hard decisions. I put it to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations so that there is no opportunity for his avoiding it on this occasion as he has on so many others, when he has been interviewed by the Press or when he has been answering questions in this Parliament. We have put some specific questions to the Minister and we want him to answer them today in his reply.

First, does the Minister support the present productivity case before the Arbitration Commission in the terms in which it is being pursued by the trade union movement? Does he propose that there should be any amendment to it? We want a straight and specific answer. Secondly, will he seek any adjournment of the national wage case as we in the Opposition have urged him to do? Will he seek any adjournment of those proceedings until later this year or beyond the end of the year so that at least employers in this country will have a chance to catch up and some opportunity to expand their businesses and employ more people? Thirdly, is there not an overwhelming case now on all the economic evidence before the Government for the Minister to argue for full discounting in the current national wage case? Is this what the Minister is on about or not? We have seen an article in the Daily Telegraph today-I do not know whether it is a leak or an inspired guess-in which the Prime Minister has said that we must cut pay rises and that the Government is looking for some sort of discounting in the Arbitration Commission. Can the Minister tell us one way or the other-is this correct? What is his position? These are specific questions. They must be answered. The Minister has an opportunity to answer them now and if they are not answered in a constructive and persuasive way, we will certainly be entitled to say, as we have many times in the past and will continue to say, that the Government's attitude on wage fixing has been completely irresponsible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WILLIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —Anyone listening to this debate for the past quarter of an hour would realise that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr N.A. Brown) really has no shame whatever. He is prepared to say anything, to make any calumny in this place in order to make a point. The Opposition really defies any attempt to have people take it seriously because Opposition members simply do not make credible statements in this place. Until the Deputy Leader of the Opposition begins making credible statements, he will not deserve to have deference shown to his remarks or to have them taken seriously.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me take up a few of the absurd comments we have just heard from him. He said that I had been egging the unions on to industrial disputation. He has no evidence whatever for that statement and of course it is totally untrue. The contrary is obviously the case. As Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, I have certainly endeavoured to minimise the level of industrial disputation. I have been very much more successful in doing that than my predecessors in the Fraser Government. The level of industrial disputation under this Government has plummeted compared with anything that prevailed under the previous Government. That is an undeniable fact and it is absurd and ridiculous in the extreme for the Opposition spokesman to stand up in this place and suggest that I am egging the unions on to industrial disputation. As I said, the contrary is the case. I have continuously done everything in my power to minimise the level of industrial disputation and of course this level has been very greatly reduced.

The Opposition is aware of that. It is aware of being on very weak ground here. It has sought to argue that the level of industrial disputation has been reduced only because this is a trend that is occurring all over the world. Recently the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) put out a Press statement to that effect. He spoke about the myths of the accord and said that there had been reduced industrial disputation in other countries and that we had nothing to boast about in this country. The reality is that we have had a very spectacular reduction not only by our past historical standards, but also compared with other countries.

Independent research at the Australian National University which was published in the Australian Financial Review found that there was compelling evidence of a structural break in Australian strike behaviour under the Hawke Government's accord. The Australian Financial Review article publicised that research. It found that the fall in the number of disputes in Australia has been significantly greater than in other Western nations. Even if honourable members want to make international comparisons, let me make it quite clear that the reduction in international disputation in this country has been far greater than that in other countries with which we normally compare ourselves.

In the period 1983-85 compared with the period of the Fraser Government there was a fall of 75 per cent in the level of industrial disputation in Australia compared with a fall of 54 per cent in the United States of America and an increase of 22 per cent under the Thatcher Government in the United Kingdom. So let us get it straight. We have been recording a reduction in the level of industrial disputation which is not only commendable and very important in terms of our historical level but also, compared with other countries, a very substantial achievement that stands up very well to international comparison.

While I am on the matter of industrial disputation, let me say that the suggestion that I have not in any way criticised the national day of protest which the Australian Council of Trade Unions has undertaken today is wrong. Indeed, yesterday-the day before that dispute-I made it quite clear in discussions with the media that I certainly did not in any way support the taking of industrial action in relation to the present case before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Indeed, I have made it clear that the Government's position is this: We call on all parties to adhere to the proper processes in relation to the Commission, to put their case properly before the Commission and to accept the outcome. In that respect I must say that there has been a deafening silence from the Opposition in relation to the actions of the Confederation of Australian Industry, which on the weekend sought to take action which, by any standards, was improper behaviour by a party appearing in the national wage case. The CAI said that if the Arbitration Commission were to give an outcome which the Confederation saw as inappropriate-that is, allowing the superannuation claim in the productivity case and the 2.3 per cent wage increase-it would regard that as evidence that the Commission was biased and would boycott the Commission. I regard that as a quite improper suggestion on the part of the CAI just as I regard the taking of industrial action on the part of the trade unions improper also.

I can understand that there is concern amongst wage and salary earners in this country about the length of time that the present case has taken. The normal expectation, of course, was that the case would result in some wage increases in early April. We are now at the end of May. It is quite clear that there will be no outcome from the case until late June. So, one can understand that there is concern at the very long delay in the finalisation of the case and a wage outcome. However, in our view, that does not in any way justify the taking of industrial action. I criticised that action yesterday and I do so again today.

The suggestion that 600,000 people unemployed is a monument to the accord is just amazing hypocrisy from the Opposition. The number of jobs created since this Government came to office is almost double what the previous Government achieved. It was in office for over twice as long as we have been in government. So we have a record of employment achievement which is staggeringly higher than that of the previous Government-a record of almost twice as many jobs in less than half the time. Yet, the Opposition talks about the accord as being some failure in relation to employment. If people do not know, they ought to understand the reason the unemployment rate has not come down in the face of that extraordinarily high level of employment growth, for which the accord must take great credit, is the fact that there has been a very large increase in the participation rate. A lot of people who were not previously looking for work under the previous Government because there was no hope of finding it have, under this Government, realised that there is a chance of getting a job and have gone out and looked for one. Therefore, the size of the work force has increased. That increase in the participation rate has added over 200,000 people to the work force. If there had not been that increase in the participation rate we would be seeing at present an unemployment rate of just over 5 per cent instead of just under 8 per cent. The increase in the participation rate has kept the unemployment rate up in the face of the fastest employment growth we have had in this country for many years. That is the reality, not the absurd picture painted by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition.

The honourable member talked about a national crisis produced by the accord. In this respect he was talking about the balance of payments current account. He said that this is the result of pricing ourselves out of the overseas market, losing international competitiveness and so on. If that is the Opposition's analysis of our current account problem, one can only say that honourable members opposite deserve to remain in opposition for a very long time, because it shows that they are economic cretins of the first order-something that they proved conclusively when they were in government. They are proving conclusively now in opposition that they have learnt nothing in the last three years. Anyone with any sense knows-all members of the National Party of Australia should know because they are the ones who keep complaining about farmers' incomes-that the primary reason we have a balance of payments current account problem is the very adverse terms of trade we have had over the last year and a quarter. From the December quarter 1984 to the March quarter this year the terms of trade have turned against us by about 11 1/2 per cent. That has been the reason for a very strong increase in the balance of payments current account over and above what we expected in the Budget and, of course, this has brought a situation which is a cause of concern. That terms of trade adjustment is, of course, washing over the J-curve effects which are coming from the devaluation, which would otherwise be turning the current account around. In that situation, it is absurd in the extreme to argue that it is the fault of wage increases, the accord, this Government or the trade union movement that there is a current account problem at this time. If I might say so, it is an absolute economic nonsense.

I think members of this House, when considering issues of this kind, must discount enormously comments by Opposition members about the failures of this Government. Their wages policy is a nonsense. The wages policy that they put forward for us to adopt apparently is one for a permanent wage freeze-as though that were something which would be achievable or desirable at present. The reality is that wage freezes can work if we create the worst recession for 50 years as the previous Government did. Wage freezes can then be imposed. But that cannot be done in the context of a strong growth in the economy; nor is it desirable to do so. What we want is a responsible wages policy. That is what the Government has said it will achieve. It has quite clearly achieved that in its term of office. The absolute rate of increase in wages has been considerably less than it was under the previous Government-about half the rate-and we have indicated that in the current circumstances our wage policy, if it needs to be adjusted, will be adjusted.

In terms of the current account problem, we have indicated publicly-indeed, I did so yesterday to the ACTU executive itself-that a further adjustment has to be made to our economic policy and that an option in that area is wages policy. That is something which the Government is considering very closely at present and it will shortly decide its position in respect of that matter in some detail. There is no lack of resolution on the part of this Government to face up to the situation which is before us-a situation which is not of our making, not of the making of the ACTU, not of the making of the workers of this country and not really of the making of any particular sector of the economy. This situation has been foisted upon us by the fact that the rest of the world is not now prepared to pay the price for our exports that it was prepared to pay in previous years. In that situation we have to adjust and we will make that adjustment. There is far more chance of making that adjustment through the accord processes with minimal effects in foisting adversity on the Australian people and particularly in creating unemployment than would be the case if we did not have the accord. The conventional wisdom in current circumstances would simply be to depress the economy considerably, create a lot of unemployment and reduce the imports. The accord gives an alternative process and that alternative process is being pursued.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have three minutes to answer these questions. Why won't you do it?

—The Opposition is asking me why I have not answered the questions. Members of the Opposition had the whole of Question Time to ask questions. If they want to ask me questions they must get up in Question Time and ask them. I will make my own speeches in my own time. We have had released recently in this country a so-called industrial relations policy from the Opposition-a policy over which it agonised for ages, a policy it had little hope of getting together for a long time. It agonised about how it would get it together and about how it would sell it to all these people whom it had to convince it was an important policy. When it finally came out, what did we see? We saw a pathetic attempt to produce an industrial relations policy, the principal element of which was no wages policy whatever. So at a time when the Opposition is saying to us `What about altering your wages policy?, at a time when I am saying that that is something that is under consideration in any case, the Opposition has a policy that has absolutely no wages policy. Members of the Opposition are simply saying to people: `Go out there and do your own thing'. They say to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission: `Do not give them anything', but then they say that it has no basis for stopping people making agreements outside. Indeed, they would encourage people to go out and make voluntary agreements and to set any wage level they liked. In those circumstances, if the Opposition were in government pursuing such a wages policy, we could be absolutely sure that we would be seeing an enormous wages blow-out, and the possibility of having any rational economic outcome would be totally gone.

SPEECH.PARA: On top to that let me say that the policy honourable members opposite have produced has other enormous deficiencies. There is obviously no time for me to go into those now, but let me flag just one point. In respect of the voluntary agreements area, which the Opposition has indicated is the centrepiece of its industrial relations policy, there are grave questions to be asked about its constitutional validity. In fact, I would say that there is no way in which that policy can be based upon the conciliation and arbitration power in placitum (xxxv.) of section 51 of the Constitution. What we have is an industrial relations policy with no wages policy, its centrepiece constitutionally flawed and not capable of being implemented under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. So after three years of agonising the Opposition has produced an industrial relations policy which is economically hopeless, industrially unworkable, and constitutionally not capable of being implemented. The Government refutes the absurd suggestions coming from the Opposition in this debate, and we assure the country that the wages policy under this Government will continue to be a responsible one, appropriate to the economic circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.PARA: We have been told by the Australian Council of Trade Unions, and this has not been contradicted by the Government, that a national strike is justified by delays in granting, not deciding, its productivity claim. There is no concession from either the ACTU or the Government on the unassailable truth that the decision on whether grounds for a claim even exist is yet to be made by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. The ACTU would have us believe that it is all cut and dried; that it is not a question of if, it is a matter of when. It is the same with the national wage case claim for a further 2.5 per cent. This day of yet another series of strikes-another day of shame-is upon us because of alleged delays by the Commission in granting claims which will add another 5.5 per cent to the cost of employment. It does not seem to have crossed the small, collective mind of the ACTU-the real government of Australia, I might say-that the only unusual delays have occurred because the Commission has refused to continue its deliberations on the merits of the claims while strikes are current. We hear a lot of misleading drivel about the incidence of strikes these days and the statistical measure of man days lost. TALK.START.PARA: —Why?

—The honourable member for Corangamite asks why. It is because the statistics exclude work bans, go-slows and other work restrictions. Such tactics undoubtedly are clearly disruptive and costly to the employer.
—They tell only half the story.

—They tell barely half the story in some ways. Furthermore, ABS figures include only stoppages of work of 10 man days or more.
