Strike time is not even measured in such a case if the stoppage by the six employees does not exceed one shift, but the damage done to the productive sector is simply beyond estimation.

SPEECH.PARA: Most of the time lost today is in so-called response to the lack of a decision on the national wage case. Even today's debacle will not be reflected in the figures to be published by the ABS in their entirety. Even the figures relating to this national strike today will not appear in figures subsequently. So it is that the ABS figures on time lost due to strikes become meaningless. It is not the duration of a strike or the man hours lost as a direct result of a strike that are significant; it is the quality and the dimensions of the effect that is important. The bald figures cannot measure that. It is also completely false to maintain that a decline in working days lost due to strikes can be equated, as they are by this Minister and this Government, with industrial harmony.

The accord has contributed to decreased productivity in many industries. Rather than go directly on strike, far too often these days union bosses have been content to pursue more indirect means of industrial action by imposing bans, limitations and other restrictions. None of these union tactics are picked up in statistics from the Australian Bureau of Statistics. That fact has been totally ignored again today by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) but it should be well understood by Australians who are the victims of sudden union disruption such as we are confronted today. Confronted as it is by what the Government clearly intended was an offer it had better not refuse, the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission is bound to consider the so far irrefutable cases mounted by employers against both the national wage and productivity cases. The Commission must realise, as we all know, that it has before it what is at once the most important and most complicated set of circumstances it has had to consider in living memory.

Despite that, the Commission gets no comfort or joy from the Government and this Minister, who is full bore behind the Australian Council of Trade Unions and is unquestioning in his servitude in a way that is unprecedented. It is inescapable to observe that this Government has its own unique formula which determines its handling of current industrial relations issues. As its base, the Government takes as its starting point any demand from the ACTU; it multiplies it by a factor for servility and then adds a loading for economic naivety. Regardless of all that, the Minister and his acolytes continue to trot out the spurious and increasingly discredited argument that the accord, mark I and mark II, has somehow led to a unique decline in industrial disputes in Australia. That is plainly ridiculous. It is part of the great myth that the Government tries in vain to sell. It is well and timely to remember, as the Leader of the Opposition reminded us in a Press statement the other day, that under both versions of the accord Australia has experienced the highest interest rates for over 50 years, over 9 per cent inflation-at a time when Japan, West Germany and the United States are heading for zero or near zero inflation-and a veritable balance of payments crisis. The fact is that over the past four years there has been a world-wide decline in industrial disputation in the Western democracies, including Italy, the United States, France, Canada and West Germany. That circumstance, therefore, is not peculiar to Australia. No doubt the honourable member for Barton (Mr Punch) will get up and at strength 10 do what he often does in this place-substitute volume for reason. But will he try to obtain from the Minister answers to questions asked by the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown)? What about the Government's attitude to the national productivity case? What about its attitude to discounting for the value of the Australian dollar? Further, what about its attitude to or support for the national wage case claim? It is appropriate and no wonder that my colleague raised this matter. The public is concerned, and so are we, at the Government's incompetent handling of the current industrial relations issues.

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Punch Mr G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have come to accept the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr N.A. Brown) coming into this place and cutting the facts of the day to his point of view, regardless of whether or not they fit. He shapes his whole point of view around a little anecdotal evidence and ignores the vast realities happening on the industrial landscape. But I must say that I am quite shocked that the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) would come in here and lend his name to such drivel that is the matter of public importance today-because that is what it is. On the one day when this nation has a day of national protest by the trade union movement-not, as the honourable member for Curtin said, a national day of strikes-honour- able members opposite come in here quick as a flash and leap on to it as a matter of public importance faster than one can say `Jack Robinson', maintaining that the country is falling apart, that there are strikes everywhere, that the union bosses have taken over the country and all the rest of the rot that comes from those opposite, who seek to justify the politics of greed with some anecdotal-based, out of date policies that are best suited to the failures of Thatcherism rather than anything that suits this country.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a little like the Mudginberri dispute. For how many months did we hear day after day that the union movement was taking over the country? The only industrial problem that honourable members opposite could cite for months and months was Mudginberri. Now we will hear for months and months about the national day of protest, or the national day of mourning, as the honourable member for Curtin called it. I think it is about time for some mature debate about where this country is heading from honourable members opposite; given that this Government knows exactly what it is doing; and if honourable members opposite want some answers, I will give them in a minute. It is about time that those opposite offered some sort of mature response in terms of industrial relations policy.

The Deputy Leader of the Opposition said that the accord was responsible for 600,000 people being unemployed. To me that is amazing. Members opposite on the back bench, when next there is a leadership and a deputy leadership ballot, provided that some of them do not resign or do not run by accident ought to have a good hard look at who was the Minister responsible for employment when much of that unemployment got into the momentum that we had to confront in March 1983 when we were first elected. Let us look at a couple of the facts. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) gave us a few in this House yesterday. The honourable member for Curtin can talk about statistics, statistics and damned lies, but these are the statistics on which the nation is based; they are the statistics on which the former Government based its policy; they are the only statistics that the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development recognises; and therefore they are fact, whether honourable members opposite like it or not: In the Fraser years, there was an average annualised rate of growth in employment of 0.8 per cent. Under this Government it has been 3.5 per cent. What about unemployment? Under the former Government it was 10.2 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?

—It was 10.2 per cent. Under this Government the rate is 7.9 per cent, despite a rise of 2 per cent in the participation rate; that is, 2 per cent of the population who gave up any hope of ever getting a job and did not even register while those opposite were on the treasury benches. Honourable members opposite want to talk about industrial disputes on this day of national protest by the union movement-not national strike. It might suit those opposite to hear this: The average number of days lost under their Government was 3.2 million days per annum, while under this Government it has been 1.4 million. Under the former Government the figure was two and a half times greater than it is at present. Yet, all facts aside, that does not stop honourable members opposite from coming in here with this ridiculous drivel that we have heard today. I am very glad that one of the senior advocates for the employers was in the gallery here a short while ago.
—You drove him out.

—The honourable member opposite drove him out actually; he left while he was speaking-another foot in the mouth. I am very glad that he was here to hear exactly what those opposite have to say, because it might be a sober reminder to him of just what there was in days past. It might be a sober reminder to the employers of this country to have a good hard look once again this month at the accord. Instead of running television advertisements which, in my view, have served only to incite much of what has happened today, they would do well to have a look at the alternative coming from those opposite. It is a timely reminder for those on the Opposition back benches to remember what happened and to consider what would happen again under the policies advocated by those opposite. I am referring to the head to head confrontation between the Government and the union movement and head to head confrontation between business and the union movement. The small business sector of this nation appears to be the ideological battleground for the conservatives in this country who, like the Marxists of the last century, seem to see something inherently wise in renewing some sort of employer-union battles out there in the private sector. Honourable members opposite should have a good hard look at their own ideology, because it is warped.

SPEECH.PARA: Also, what about the policy document that was handed to us before honourable members opposite managed to neutralise everyone concerned? Under that policy there was to be no indexation, no productivity pay claims, no anything for the union movement. They said: `We will just accept the return of profit share to the levels of the 1960s; we will just accept the lowest strike rates for 20 years; we will just accept the lowest real unit labour costs for something like 20 years. If we want to see just how hypocritical is the policy honourable members opposite are advocating-this is apart from the fact that it probably is unconstitutional, but we will deal with that another time-let us recall what the now Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown), had to say on 24 March 1982 when he was the Minister for unemployment; I beg your pardon, Mr Deputy Speaker, when he was the Minister for Employment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who was that?
—That was the honourable member for Menzies. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The OECD has made it plain; we make it plain to the people: What we look for is some support such as we have seen recently from the German trade union movement.
He continued:
If that sort of example were set by Australian trade unions, they, too, in partnership with us, would be making a very substantial contribution to increasing employment and reducing unemployment.

He talked about it but it never happened. It has happened under this Government. Honourable members opposite have returned to a policy that would restore this nation to the industrial relations battlefield that it was when the Deputy Leader of the Opposition was the Minister for Employment in this country. There is absolutely no doubt about the reason honourable members opposite have proposed as a matter of public importance today `the public concern at the Government's incompetent handling of current industrial relations issues'. All that has been cited has been the events of today-this national day of protest. Why have we had a national day of protest today by the union movement? It is because the union movement has been pursuing, as is its right, the present case before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission since February. Employers have been doing everything they can to delay it, at the encouragement of honourable members opposite. Unions today have taken one very mild action compared with the actions of yesteryear-regrettable though it is, it is mild. They have declared today a national day of protest. I think honourable members opposite should regard that as an example of just how far the union movement has come in giving up so many claims in the national interest.

It is about time that the employers of this nation recognised that and did a little bit of that themselves. Even more to the point, if the employers of this country are thinking of supporting the return of the present Opposition to government, they had better have a good hard look at the Opposition's industrial relations policy and the people who are advocating it. They should look at the Opposition's track record and at what is being advocated. They should look at whether it is possible to implement it-because it is not.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1986[COGNATE BILLS:INCOME TAX (SECURITIES AND AGREEMENTS) (WITHHOLDING TAX RECOUPMENT) BILL 1986TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (FOREIGN TAX CREDITS) BILL 1986TAXATION BOARDS OF REVIEW (TRANSFER OF JURISDICTION) BILL 1986]

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before the debate is resumed on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1986, I remind the House that it has been agreed that a general debate be allowed covering this Bill and Orders of the Day Nos 2 to 4.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brumby Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my pleasure to rise to speak in support of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1986, the Income Tax (Securities and Agreements) (Withholding Tax Recoupment) Bill 1986, the Taxation Laws Amendment (Foreign Tax Credits) Bill 1986 and the Taxation Boards of Review (Transfer of Jurisdiction) Bill 1986.
—It won't be a pleasure to listen to you.

—I suggest, if the honourable member is not interested in listening to this contribution, that he leave the House. There are four Bills before the House. The major thrust of these Bills-certainly the main Bill-arises from the National Taxation Summit last year and from the tax reform statement issued late last year by the Treasurer (Mr Keating). Over recent weeks we have seen a number of Bills having to do with the Government's tax reform statement debated in this House. These Bills before the House relate to that statement as well. Of course, tomorrow there will be further discussion and debate in this House on the question of a capital gains tax, which also arises from the tax reform statement.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, there are four Bills before the House. I think that the major Bill is the Taxation Laws Amendment (Foreign Tax Credits) Bill. It is designed to give effect to proposals announced by the Treasurer in his 19 September 1985 tax reform statement. The intention of the Bill is to replace the present double taxation relief arrangements of the income tax law with the general foreign tax credit system. The Taxation Boards of Review (Transfer of Jurisdiction) Bill, also before the House, reflects in large part the Government's response to recommendations made in a report by the Administrative Review Council entitled `Review of Taxation Decisions by Boards of Review'. It proposes that, with minor departures, the recommendations of the Administrative Review Council be adopted. In accordance with the Council's recommendations, the principal function of the Bill is to abolish the taxation boards of review and to transfer the present jurisdiction of the boards to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. This takeover is scheduled to take place on 1 July 1986. I should point out that the present avenue of appeal under some taxation laws to a supreme court will, of course, remain.

The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) amends the income tax law in two major respects. It also contains a number of other amendments of the taxation laws. The principal measures which it seeks to give effect to, again, are proposals which were announced previously by the Treasurer. The first of these was to tax each year the income accruing to resident taxpayers from discounted, deferred interest and capital indexed securities. The other was to strengthen the interest withholding tax provisions in relation to such securities held by non-residents and other non-traditional financing arrangements. I think it is important to mention that this Bill also exempts from tax certain allowances which are paid to recipients of the new Commonwealth formal training allowance.

Another measure in this legislation will correct a technical defect in the rebate provisions of the income tax law that applied to certain employment termination payments. In addition, the income tax secrecy provisions are to be amended to enable information concerning superannuation funds, approved deposit funds and similar funds to be conveyed to persons who may be responsible for supervision of the superannuation industry. Finally, I point out in respect of this Bill that it will amend the income tax gift provisions and make a number of what are purely technical amendments relevant to the recent changes to the repatriation laws.

I will make some comments during my speech on the question of training allowances because I think that is an important aspect of the legislation before the House. However, I want to make some general comments which relate to this package of legislation and the other legislation which arises from the 19 September 1985 tax reform statement of the Government. To date this has been a fairly wide-ranging debate which, I think it is fair to say, has looked at many issues of tax reform before the House. There have been contributions from Opposition members in this debate on such wide-ranging areas as the fringe benefits tax, negative gearing and the entertainment expenses changes made by this Government. I refer just briefly to those because they relate to these Bills in the sense that they are matters which arose from the tax reform statement of 19 September 1985. (Quorum formed)

I was talking about the Government's tax reform proposals, which are well represented before the House today in these four Bills. I make the point that one of those Bills has to do with foreign tax credits. Over the past few days and during this debate we have heard contributions from Opposition members who have said that this Government has a policy of taxing business too heavily in this country. That has been a consistent theme of the debate. I point out that this whole exercise in tax reform in which the Government is engaged, and which includes the Bill now before the House on foreign tax credits, is a revenue neutral arrangement. No additional taxes will be levied as a result of the tax reform statement or these Bills; they are all taxes that will go into general revenue and be redistributed back to businesses and Australian wage and salary earners in the form of other tax concessions and reduced levels of pay as you earn tax.

When one looks at the business area affected by this general foreign tax credit system the point needs to be be made that while the Opposition can argue that through taxes such as the fringe benefits tax, or perhaps the capital gains tax or this legislation, the Government is taking from business it conveniently forgets to mention all the other good things that we have done in terms of taxation arrangements for business. We have got the general economic setting pretty right, we have strong economic growth, new investment at good levels, record levels of employment growth, and industrial disputation and real labour costs are down. We have also done a great deal in this area of business taxation. When the Opposition makes those claims it conveniently forgets to mention that it is this Government which introduced the 5:3 depreciation allowance. That has provided businesses with a benefit that is costing of the order of $2 billion a year.

The Opposition forgets to mention the group tax loss provisions introduced by this Government and the 150 per cent tax deduction for research and development which has already been so successful in stimulating research and development in Australia. And, of course, during the debate on these Bills the Opposition has entirely neglected to mention the major corporate tax reform embodied in this tax reform package; that is, the removal of double taxation on dividends. When one takes all of those matters into account one sees that, on the one hand, we have given considerable benefits to business which enable it to invest, grow and create jobs-which all Australians want-while on the other invoking a new measure of fairness and equity into our tax system so that we move away from those days in the past when under Opposition parties it was the PAYE earners in Australia who shouldered the bulk of the burden of tax liability and when it was other areas that were avoiding and evading their rightful tax responsibilities.

The Bills before the House give effect to many of the measures contained in the tax reform statement. One of the other matters raised in this debate was the Government's decision to stop making a tax deduction available for what are known as entertainment expenses. We were told when we took that decision that that would mean the destruction of the entertainment industry and the restaurant industry. Of course, what we have seen since that tax change-what it has brought about-is not any great reduction in employment levels or profitability in the restaurant industry or entertainment industry; in fact, we have seen increases in employment in those industries.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nineteen thousand jobs.

—As the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown), who is an astute commentator and observer of politics and economic matters, rightly points out, in the entertainment and restaurant industries as a whole there has been an increase in employment of 19,000 people since that tax was introduced. So much for the claim by the Opposition that this tax reform package, and these Bills, would result in the obliteration and destruction of the entertainment industry.
—They were spurious claims.

—It was a highly spurious claim, as the honourable member points out. It is worth looking at another claim made during the debate today, and previously, by Opposition members concerning this tax reform package. This again concerns the so-called consequences and implications of the decision we took in relation to negative gearing. We were told that because of negative gearing there would be a disastrous drying up of housing construction, rental unit construction, flat construction, and so on in Australia. We have not seen that consequence throughout Australia. We certainly have not seen it in my electorate, where housing approvals are running as strongly as they were in 1984-85. I point out that in the Greater Bendigo area that means that housing approvals are currently running in excess of $40m a year. The point is worth making that when we took government in 1982-83 housing approvals were running at only $10m a year, so we have improved the housing position, housing stock and housing commencements by 300 per cent over the past three years. Those figures have stuck, and despite the concern in relation to high interest rates over the past six months, and the implications of that for the housing industry, certainly in my area, and in Australia as a whole, we have seen little effect of that.

SPEECH.PARA: This year, of course, we will see housing commencements of the order of 135,000 units Australia-wide. Last year we saw 137,000; in 1984-85, 152,000; and in 1983-84, the first year of our government, 137,000. When one thinks of those figures one should bear in mind the last year of the Fraser Government, in which only 105,000 homes and units were constructed in Australia. It was a disaster, so we have seen in the three and a half years of our Government an additional 200,000 houses and units constructed which would not have been constructed were it not for the economic and taxation decisions taken by this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you come back to a bit of tax?

—I will come back to a bit of tax, because the Opposition has suggested it would like to concentrate on the tax reform statement. I was talking about that statement, negative gearing, non-deductibility of expenses for entertainment and about the Bills before the House, which affect business taxation in many ways. I have already mentioned that and do not want to repeat my arguments because, frankly, they would be an embarrassment to the Opposition. We have heard claims in this debate that taxation levels under this Government have risen to horrendous proportions. We have also heard the claim that all of the revenue that we are bringing into the system from these tax reform changes will disappear into government coffers and that it will never be returned in tax benefits to business or PAYE income earners; that it will be hidden away in an ever-increasing rise in government spending. I point out that nothing could be further from the truth. I repeat for the benefit of Opposition members that this whole package is revenue neutral. We have given specific commitments in regard to the tax reform package. I see that the shadow Minister for Social Security, the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt), is in the House. I think he probably understands what revenue neutral means, but for the benefit of other Opposition members in the House, it means that money coming in through one source-it may be $1 billion-will be returned to taxpayers by another source to the tune of exactly the same amount, $1 billion. So $1 billion comes in but $1 billion goes out. It is like keeping the car in neutral-nothing really changes except that we have put a bit more equity and fairness into the system. That is what we have done with this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I must say that it is good legislation. When one compares our record with the Opposition's record, one must acknowledge-I think Opposition members privately would acknowledge-that under the Fraser Government there simply was not any semblance of fairness or equity in its taxation arrangements. We saw a massive growth in rorts, avoidance, evasion and perks. That is what happened under the previous Government. We also saw an increase in the total tax take. Figures produced by the Australian Bureau of Statistics show that during the period of the Fraser Government the percentage of taxation as a proportion of real gross domestic product actually increased in real terms. That is what happened under a government which was supposed to be based on the concept of small government.

Let us look at the record of the previous Government. Honourable members who think back to 1977-it is not that long ago-will remember when Malcolm Fraser promised in television advertisements, during the election campaign, a fistful of dollars. Those disgraceful, misleading advertisements promised a fistful of dollars. No doubt they seduced some voters in the electorate who were gullible enough to believe that the Fraser Government could honestly represent its election promises. They had to wait only a matter of weeks after the 1977 election, when basically Fraser said: `Now we have the election out of the way, we have been returned to office, we will grab your money back'. That is what the previous Government did. The honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth) is demonstrating what happened by putting his hand in his pocket. That is what happened, but it was Malcolm Fraser's hands, and he was taking back the money from the people to whom he had so dishonestly promised a fistful of dollars before the 1977 election.

TALK.START.PARA: —But Howard was Treasurer and he took it.

—As the honourable member points out quite astutely, at that time the present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) was the Federal Treasurer in the Fraser Government. I am sure it was actually his idea-I have it on good advice-to take back those tax cuts after the election.

SPEECH.PARA: During the 1980 election campaign exactly the same thing happened. In that year the Fraser Government promised direct tax cuts of $2.35m to Australian taxpayers. That was the greatest con job of all time. It said: `Here is $2.5m in income tax cuts, but look at the fine print'. The fine print showed that the Government was actually increasing taxes in the indirect sales tax area by $1.8m. So $2.5m in tax cuts became only $600m in tax cuts. That goes to show that one cannot really trust the Opposition-the Liberal Party or the National Party. We in the Labor Party know that this whole tax exercise is revenue neutral and that every extra dollar that is received will go back to people by way of a fair and equitable tax system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adermann The Hon A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope that my contribution will be more relevant to the Bills before the House-the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2), the Income Tax (Securities and Agreements) (Withholding Tax Recoupment) Bill, the Taxation Laws Amendment (Foreign Tax Credits) Bill, and the Taxation Boards of Review (Transfer of Jurisdiction) Bill. I register a bitter complaint that the Government should bring in such a comprehensive package of very significant tax Bills, bracket them together and allow us only a fraction of the time necessary to debate them. Whilst I would have desired to speak to and analyse in detail the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2), the time allotted to me under this Government's curtailment of debate prevents me from having that opportunity. I can register my very serious concern about only one aspect-the proposed alteration of the secrecy provisions.

SPEECH.PARA: I register my strong objection to the provision which allows the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation to convey information on superannuation to the Secretary to the Treasury or to any body set up to deal with superannuation. This contains inherent dangers. The absolute secrecy of a taxpayer's returns has been extremely important and is a fundamental plank in our taxation assessment system. I have very grave misgivings, and even foresee possible abuse, if this previous provision of secrecy is to be diluted or qualified, as is proposed by this Bill. I want the Government to note that the reason I do not say more and expand more on this very serious matter is that I have been denied the time and opportunity to do so, as I want to speak at more length on another Bill in this package with which I violently disagree. Similarly, I would desire to comment on the Income Tax (Securities and Agreements) (Withholding Tax Recoupment) Bill. I would like to have stated clearly why I cannot support the Taxation Laws Amendment (Foreign Tax Credits) Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —The member for Dawson did that.

—The honourable member for Dawson did that and he did it extremely well. Instead, I must confine my brief ration of time to a discussion of the Taxation Boards of Review (Transfer of Jurisdiction) Bill. I absolutely oppose this Bill without any qualification, even though my Opposition colleagues may not entirely agree with me. I believe it is an erosion of the taxpayer's rights to justice, his appeal processes are diluted, and it is most dangerous legislation. Although I know that in the battle against tax evasion it was necessary to give greater discretion to the Commissioner of Taxation, I am alarmed that that power has become so wide and in some ways so harsh under this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I have become concerned about fairness and equity, not only in the matter of demands and penalties, but also in the matter of appeals. This Bill is all about appeals. The Government and the Commissioner point to the fact that there is a backlog of 94,000 cases on appeal to the boards of review. That is their so-called justification for this Bill. I agree that this is a serious logjam, and I deplore the interminable time it is taking to have appeals heard. I know that taxpayers experience extreme financial hardship, are precluded from making any business decisions and plans because they cannot predict the result of their appeal, and there is often a long period of heartbreak and worry.

Let me say, however, very definitely and without equivocation that the Australian Taxation Office has contributed very greatly to this most unsatisfactory situation. Where the Taxation Office fears that a decision might be cast for the taxpayer and against the Taxation Office, and when that decision might have flow-on consequences, it will delay submitting that case to the Board of Review for an inordinate time. There are still cases from 1980-81 and probably earlier, which taxpayers have appealed, which the Department has not brought forward, and which it could, and should, have submitted to the review board long ago. The reason, unfortunately, is plain to see. The Taxation Office knows that such delays mean that the taxpayer is in limbo. He does not know whether he must alter his corporate or business structure, what funds he might have available to conduct his business, and, in fact, whether or not he is solvent. I make it clear that I am not talking about tax dodgers. I am talking about family companies, family partnerships, and honest individual taxpayers. Very clearly, the Taxation Office hopes to put the taxpayer under such strain and in such intolerable circumstances by this protraction of five or six years, and the knowledge that assessments for the succeeding years are under a cloud, that he will withdraw the appeal.
It is no use either the Government or the Taxation Office protesting that I am wrong. I am not wrong; I am dead right.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are absolutely right.

—Yes, I am dead right. The Taxation Office should bring on these appeals, but it knows that if a taxpayer succeeds then a goodly number of other appeals will be automatically allowed. That would substantially reduce the backlog and save taxpayers a great deal of interest and fear of penalty, and it would bring justice and fairness, which seem sometimes to be sadly lacking.

SPEECH.PARA: The answer is not, I repeat, to abolish the boards of review and bring the jurisdiction under the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The answer is to get the appeals to the boards and provide the boards with more bodies to deal with them. The boards of review, not only because of the quality of their decisions but also simply because they exist, have fulfilled an excellent role. During my many years as an accountant, many times one of my clients would have a claim rejected or reduced by the Taxation Office, particularly in regard to the use of a vehicle for both business and private purposes, or some other similar type of expense. I would appeal for reconsideration and present substantiation on my client's behalf. Again, it would fall on deaf ears in the Taxation Office. So, finally I would send the $2 fee and a request for the appeal to be submitted to a board of review. Invariably-and I never had a single case go to the board-the Taxation Office would then write back either accepting our submission or making a proposition for a greater taxable deduction than it would previously entertain. Obviously, it must have known that its decision was not sustainable before a board of review, and when it could not bully or bluff the taxpayer, the very threat of an appeal to the board was enough to make it discuss and consider the matter further. Under the change encompassed by this Bill, the boards of review are to abolished.

Furthermore, as the application for appeal will be lodged directly by the taxpayer with the Administrative Appeals Tribunal body, and the Commissioner of Taxation, presumably, is required to provide only details that he wants to provide concerning the case, the whole process will be considerably different and, for reasons which I shall elucidate, will disadvantage the taxpayer in comparison with the existing system. The boards of review have very specific advantages. Not only were they created for the purpose of adjudicating on taxation matters; they were independent of the Tax Commissioner, and the informality of the hearings enabled a taxpayer to put his appeal clearly without any requirement of judicial-type atmosphere or language. Taxpayers had a great confidence in these boards.

This Bill makes some undesirable changes. First of all, appeals become the function of another tribunal, which deals with and considers appeals over the whole range of government administration. No matter what the Government says about creating a special department within the AAT, I believe that the special meaning and expertise of a specific structure dealing with tax alone is lost. I think that that is a grievous loss.

Secondly, I fear that the informality will be either diminished or lost. Thirdly, I am most concerned that a board of three referees can be replaced by a single arbiter. I would have opposed that move even if the review boards were retained and the number of referees on those boards was reduced. Unfortunately, where a single arbiter sits as jury and referee, the decision is far more likely to reflect the personal view and the limitations, even perhaps the bias, of that referee than a more balanced panel of three.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Family Court.

—Yes. There is a danger, too, where a single arbiter sits, if his decisions predominantly favour the taxpayer against the Commissioner, that he might be worried about his permanency and future as an arbiter of tax appeals. Certainly it would be some sort of inhibition to giving the benefit of the doubt or to evidence concern about any arbitrariness by the Commissioner if a score-sheet of his cases were kept and his suitability to continue were considered. A panel of three is ideal. It provides balance. It provides the facility for the arbiters to discuss the submission and examine its validity, and it gives a much greater balance and range of views. It shares the responsibility, and it is infinitely preferable. If it means that to provide continuation of panels of three requires more appointments, so be it. With something as important as taxation appeals, it is far better to provide more personnel if necessary than to risk the diminution or dilution of a taxpayer's rights and his confidence, and to replace a most satisfactory structure and system with something that is less substantial and less commendable.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not say this carpingly. I say it because over quite a long experience in accounting and taxation, and having had many dealings and debates with tax assessors over assessments, I have seen the worth, effectiveness and quality of taxation boards of review of three members. Perhaps the Taxation Office has also seen this, and, with the increasingly adversarial and pre-emptory attitude of the Office these days, perhaps it would like to remove the degree of restraint and inspection provided by such taxation review boards.

Although the decisions of the boards are appealable to a court, the number of decisions favouring the taxpayer which are not taken to court appeal by the Commissioner must be compelling evidence of the quality and correctness of those boards and his perception that they would be reinforced and upheld by the courts in very many cases. Surely these are very strong reasons why we should strengthen our review boards, and not diminish their number of referees, nor submerge them in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Appeals to the review boards are special and specific. They are, to some degree I suppose, appeals against an administrative arm of government. More importantly, they require specialist and specific arbitration by specifically appointed arbiters, independent of the Taxation Office and of the Government and departments, and quite separate from the appeals structure of other departments and bodies which form the bulk of the work and attention of the AAT.

There are two other most grievous concerns which I have about this legislation. At present, the review boards are required to give a full statement of reasons for their decisions. This means that both the Commissioner and the taxpayer, particularly the latter, are fully apprised on the reasons why their submission was not upheld, are able to consider those reasons and get advice on them, and to contemplate whether those reasons are appealable and warrant the formidable expense of retaining counsel and going to the courts. These reasons, too, provide a basis for eliminating insubstantial or frivolous further appeal. They are vitally important to the taxpayer, and he has an inalienable right to be given a full statement of the reasons for the arbitration to which he is being expected to submit. This Bill takes that right away or considerably diminishes it. Under the proposed change, the arbiter of the AAT is required to give no reasons to the taxpayer. This may save time and cost but it denies justice, and savings should never result in denial of justice. A statement of reasons is provided only by the arbiter to the main Administrative Appeals Tribunal, and the taxpayer has to go to the AAT to try to ascertain those reasons. That is clumsy and ineffective, and I oppose it.

Additionally, this Bill allows the Attorney-General to intervene in the AAT if he judges it to be in the public interest. Under the present boards there is no capacity for the Attorney-General or anyone else to interfere with, impede or influence the board's decision. Under this horrific provision, the Attorney-General can do all those things. This proposal has absolutely nothing to commend it or support it. It is dangerous and has plenty to fear and it is completely incompatible with the effectiveness and quality of the taxation appeals system presently applying.

No taxpayer should ever have to look over his shoulder when he is trying to get justice or consideration of a matter which can affect his total welfare and that of his family, and which is conceivably of heavy financial consequence, to see whether the Attorney-General is going to intervene, circumscribe his rights and limit or remove his capacity to appeal. This is a totally objectionable provision, completely indefensible, and an intrusion into human rights, about which this Government is supposed to be greatly concerned, and I absolutely and utterly reject it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It could be referred to the Human Rights Commission.

—Yes, it could be so referred. Finally, I condemn the Government for bringing to this Parliament such a major change with such ramifications without any discussion and consultation with accountants, tax agents and taxpayers' bodies. It is true that Eric Risstrom predicted this move and expressed concern about it. However, there has been no consultation, no discussion and no Green Paper proposal ever conducted by this Government. Probably the Government knew that it was unsupportable, and such discussion would have exposed that. Unfortunately, this Government's track record is no consultation or discussions beyond a cup of tea with the Australian Council of Trade Unions, then, to prevent scrutiny, ruthlessly guillotining or gagging debate in this House. Again today we have the guillotine. This Government should have tabled these Bills to allow scrutiny and discussion and adequate opportunity for comment. I regard the legislation designed to abolish the review boards as one of the most devious and reprehensible Bills ever presented by this Government, and I absolutely and unequivocally oppose it. I do that because for very many years I have been involved in taxation and accounting. I know the value of those boards. I very much suspect the motives in getting rid of those boards, and this Bill will find no favour with me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Griffiths Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the debate on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2), the Income Tax (Securities and Agreements) (Withholding Tax Recoupment) Bill, the Taxation Laws Amendment (Foreign Tax Credits) Bill and the Taxation Boards of Review (Transfer of Jurisdiction) Bill, I wish to concentrate on the foreign tax credits legislation, but I note that most of the previous speakers traversed the debate reasonably widely. Given that this legislation is a direct result of the National Taxation Summit and the taxation White Paper that was put together, obviously there are implications far beyond the specific matters in the legislation itself. One point that was raised earlier that I think bears repeating is that this legislation, and all other legislation that is part of the tax reform package, is revenue neutral. It is worth stressing that point. Whilst it may be a little polemical, it is worth putting it this way: The Government does not expect to gain from any of these proposals one dollar that will not subsequently be redistributed by way of direct benefit to the taxpayers of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The whole of the tax package has come about as a result of a clear mandate. I have said before in this House that it is very rare indeed for a government to be able to say that it went to the people at election time not ruling out any specific proposals. I think it suffered some electoral pain for adopting that position. Subsequently it presided over what can only be seen as the major reform of the Australian taxation system in the history of this country. Unfortunately, the Government has had to respond to attempts made in another place to change the substance of those tax reform measures. I think it is totally inappropriate for the Senate to seek to change the tax package. I believe that in the final analysis it will receive the sanction that the Australian people will apply through the ballot box.

In the context of the debate on this legislation, I think it is worth making very briefly some points that follow up matters that the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby) raised. He indicated the Opposition's approach to these matters when he referred to the famous tax grab after, I think, the 1977 election. I went through some figures some time ago that showed how the former Government got its tax revenue. It is interesting to note that, according to the figures that I was able to establish, there were substantial income tax cuts under the Fraser Government-$2.35 billion over one year-but, I hasten to add, it is worth noting where that money came from. Looking at how that figure of approximately $2.4 billion was arrived at, it is interesting to see how the Australian taxpayer made up that money.

There was an increase of 2.5 per cent in existing sales tax rates and a subsequent revenue yield of some $500m; that was $500m of the $2.35 billion package. Taxation at a rate of 7.5 per cent was levied on certain goods that were previously exempt. This resulted in a revenue yield of a further $150m. The Fraser Government removed the excise exemption for off-road distillate, at a revenue gain of $304m. I would have thought that that move was a significant impediment to our rural community. The Fraser Government also increased excise on motor spirit and distillate, with a revenue yield of some $214m. Excise on tobacco, for example, gave a yield of $125m and the yield from the excise on beer was $135m. When all those figures are added up they account for of the order of $1.6 billion of the $2.35 billion package. It is very much a case of giving with one hand and taking away with the other. It is worth reflecting on the previous Government's approach to taxation reform when we are considering the sorts of Bills that are coming into the House now.

In my electorate, as I would imagine is the case in most electorates throughout Australia, there has been some consternation about different aspects of the tax package, essentially because, as is inevitably the case when one is presiding over quite complicated reforms of the tax system, they are open to misinterpretation in the community. There is one concern about which quite a number of people have approached me. My electorate abuts Melbourne Airport and Essendon Airport. In direct relationship to that fact, I have in my electorate a very large number of employees in the airline industry. I have received many representations on how the fringe benefits tax would affect my constituents insofar as it related to concessional air travel.

I am pleased to advise you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and the House that as a result of negotiations between the Australian Council of Trade Unions, other airline industry unions, Ansett Airlines of Australia, Trans Australia Airlines and Qantas Airways Ltd, a broad agreement has been arrived at. The end result of that agreement is that for existing employees existing entitlements to staff travel concessions will remain unchanged. There will be absolutely no impact on airline employees. The companies will pay the tax and not the employees. The fringe benefits tax will be calculated on the basis that it applies to the arm's length price of an airline ticket. The arm's length price is 50 per cent lower than the lowest published fare for international travel. The Government accepts that the concession is based upon staff travel being seen to be different from business travel.

As I have indicated, the existing travel concessions will remain intact-that is, the parties have agreed to maintain the status quo. The airlines will not diminish staff concessional travel arrangements, nor, I might add, will benefits be improved. Existing concessional travel entitlements for current and future employees and eligible relatives will be maintained. The most important point-this is one that has caused a lot of consternation-is that the status quo will be maintained for retired employees and those entitlements to which they currently have access will continue unaltered.

In the context of taxation reform legislation, it is also worth going back and having a look at the relationship between these Bills and revenue that will subsequently be dispersed through the taxation system to mostly ordinary pay as you earn taxpayers in this country. A couple of points are worth making. One is that on a national accounts basis the profitability of Australian corporations-that is, the gross operating surplus of trading companies-has risen by some $8.5 billion or 48 per cent in the last two years. For comparative reasons, I think the House should be provided with similar information for the last two years of the Fraser Government. Under the tutelage as Treasurer, of the present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), profitability rose by only $1 billion in those two years, compared with $8.5 billion in the last two years. I think that is significant. It is also worth noting that under the coalition there was a 7 per cent growth in profits, with a 24 per cent inflation rate over the same period. Under this Government there has been 14 per cent growth in profits, which, of course, is quite significant.

When we talk about these tax changes we ought not to forget what we have already put in place, because those measures directly benefit particular companies in our community. It is worth noting that the Government did bring in the accelerated depreciation allowances at a significant cost-if my memory serves me correctly, it was in excess of $2 billion a year. This Government introduced group loss provisions and the 150 per cent tax deduction for research and development which, of itself, I think will cost at least $100m a year. There are also major corporate tax reforms in terms of the full imputation changes, the removal of double tax on dividends and the abolition of Division 7 tax which together will cost about $250m. With the $8.5 billion increase in profits over two years, the full imputation system, the depreciation provisions, group losses and faster write-off for investment in research and development, I believe that companies in this country can legitimately compare this Government's performance with that of the previous Government. Whilst from time to time they may be upset with some particular changes-and they always will be-they must realise that there is a strong case to be made for the argument that this Government has done a great deal to assist companies in this country. In addition we have introduced deregulation of the financial system, something that was talked about for a long time but never addressed by the previous Government, the steel plan, the motor vehicle plan and the rural package.

Previous speakers touched upon capital gains taxes. It is important to note that every comparable country has a capital gains tax and one of the consistent themes in the Australian economy in the post-war period is that we have been a capital scarce country. Those who wish to embrace the scare campaign on capital gains taxes must find it rather difficult when the US, which is very much the country of full blooded capitalism, has currently before its Congress legislation which will increase the level of capital gains tax to that applying to income tax-although I concede that both of those are at slightly lower rates than ours. The fact is that the capital gains tax will be a significant advance to the Australian economy. It is worth noting that it will be totally prospective; every property owned up to 19 September 1985 will be exempt.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will apply to small businesses and primary producers.

—I must point out to honourable members that I do not, and doubt whether I ever will, own any large blocks of flats and I do not have any great assets outside my home which, in any event, is heavily mortgaged. Frankly, the capital gains tax will not affect me or the majority of Australian taxpayers. To the extent that it will affect those who are caught with investments after 19 September 1985, it is more than justified. In philosophical terms this is something that the Opposition should support because it is fundamentally about efficiency in an economy and trying to have a tax system that is neutral in encouraging money in one sector of the economy or another.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the great problems that our urban communities have had in the post-war period is the massive increase in house and land prices. That is substantially a function of people owning more than one property and sitting on it. Some years ago I was interested to look at some figures dealing with land in the eastern suburbs of Melbourne. These showed that while there was a great availability of land at a time when people were very rapidly bidding up the cost of home building blocks, a lot of that land was locked up by people who owned their own home and one or two additional blocks of land or even homes. This very much rationed the availability of land and forced up prices. I do not think that anyone in this House would seriously put the view that we should not reform tax mechanisms that have demonstrably contributed to very great inflation in home and land prices in the major capital cities and, indeed, elsewhere.

Some nights ago I went to Warrnambool where I was talking to some of that town's fine citizens. We were talking about the prices of homes and land in Warrnambool. For heaven's sake, that town is right out in the middle of the bush and I would have presumed that a decent three-bedroomed home down there would cost about $40,000. That is certainly not the case. The prices in a place like Warrnambool were surprisingly similar to the prices being paid in Melbourne itself and to some extent that is a function of the pre-existing laws relating to capital gains.

I conclude my remarks by referring to something that has been discussed in this House over the past couple of days; that is, the widely publicised tax boycott advocated by Mr Bob Ansett, Mr McLachlan of the National Farmers Federation and the Queensland Premier, amongst many others. These people have advocated breaching the Commonwealth's proposed taxation legislation as a protest. Mr Ansett evidenced the famous Boston Tea Party as the philosophical and principal position from which he argued his point that a boycott would be appropriate. It is worth pointing out that, as with the Eureka Stockade, the Boston Rebellion or Tea Party was fundamentally about no taxation without representation. It is somewhat misleading to call upon either of those two major historical incidents to argue the case for opposing a particular tax that has been arrived at-whether one accepts its desirability or not-through the properly constituted democratic processes of this country.

I for one was very disappointed with the comments of Mr Ansett and Mr McLachlan. I was also disappointed that Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen came into the debate, but one can usually expect that sort of behaviour from him. It is particularly hypocritical for the Queensland Premier to take this attitude because over many years he has established as a political catchcry the need to enforce law and order in this country, yet as soon as it suits him and for what he perceives to be a minor political advantage, he is prepared to advocate the breaking of the laws of this land. In the case of the Boston Tea Party the British Red Coats were fighting people who were trying to establish a democratic process in the US; that is, it was the Red Coats versus the democrats. As a very interesting historic analogy, we now have the rednecks fighting the democratic process.

I think all members of the House, irrespective of party, should be prepared to condemn that sort of behaviour, I hope that the steam will go out of the so-called campaign for a boycott of the tax measures. It may not, but I believe these things transcend party lines and I do not think that honourable members opposite would support a proposition where people in the community were incited to break the law. I do not know what Mr Ansett's response would be if people who hired motor vehicles from him and entered into contractual arrangements suddenly decided that because they did not like the colour of the car or because they disapproved of some aspect of it, they should return the car and say they were not prepared to pay for its use.

This is a case of electing to break a particular law that does not suit one. I have indicated my view that consumers should boycott Budget Rent A Car System Pty Ltd until such time as Mr Ansett takes the view that we should not encourage breaking the laws of the land and I maintain that position. In terms of this Government's relationship with Mr Ansett, I believe it would be appropriate in the circumstances to analyse what business dealings we have with his company and in a peaceful and law-abiding manner-

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you sack him from the trade body?

—I am sure that if a trade union official advocated a breach of Commonwealth legislation and, if he were on an advisory body to a Liberal government, the honourable member would take exactly the same view. I am somewhat disappointed that on an issue like this we do not have a greater degree of bipartisan support.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to what the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Griffiths) had to say about breaking the law, let me make my position quite clear right from the outset. I do not think that it is appropriate for people to advocate the breaking of the law. To that extent I am at one with the honourable member for Maribyrnong. I would be much more convinced by the remarks of the honourable member and people on his side of the House if they displayed as much concern when the law was broken by their trade union colleagues as they do when action of this sort is proposed by people they regard as their political opponents. For instance, I have never heard the honourable member say one word about the dispute that took place last year at Mudginberri. I have never heard the honourable member say in this House that trade unionists should not have taken certain action which is clearly in breach of the law set down by this Government or any other government. So let us have no crocodile tears from the honourable member or from anybody else from the Australian Labor Party in relation to this matter. Let them put their own house in order and be consistent in their attitudes. I am totally consistent when I say that I do not agree with people who advocate the breaking of the law. The simplest way of getting rid of this law, of course, is to change the government. More and more people will understand that this is what is needed.

SPEECH.PARA: I was particularly interested in the honourable member for Maribyrnong's exposition in support of the capital gains tax. I found it fascinating that this should come from a member of the Labor Party. Of course, all of us on this side of the House remember very clearly the famous statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke)-and I will use almost his exact words, language which even we could understand-`There will be no capital gains tax'. Members of the Labor Party, one after the other, are supporting the tax changes brought in by the present Government. They are saying what a good thing those changes are. However, they have not for one moment mentioned the complete about-face and the total rejection of the statement `There will be no capital gains tax'. In this one instance alone we find a reason why nobody in this country could trust the word of the Labor Party and the Labor Government on any issue. This was a fundamental issue which was so heavily underlined by the Prime Minister himself who said: `There will be no capital gains tax'. Notwithstanding that promise, speaker after speaker on the Labor side has supported its introduction. Talk about--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Chair reminds the honourable member that he is addressing his remarks to a Bill which I understand will be before the House tomorrow. That Bill is not listed in the legislation presently before the House.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I am responding to the remarks of the honourable member for Maribyrnong. However, I take your point. I would like to respond to one other remark of the honourable member which went unchallenged. I say again that it is all very well to talk about the taxation package. Of course, he did not mention that a tremendous proportion of Australian taxpayers will be moving into the highest tax bracket. About one in two Australian taxpayers will be in the highest tax bracket following the introduction of these changes by the Labor Party.

SPEECH.PARA: I would now like to address my remarks to the issue arising from the Taxation Boards of Review (Transfer of Jurisdiction) Bill. The Bill proposes to implement a report of the Administrative Review Council which, given its title, not unsurprisingly argued the case for abolishing taxation review boards and incorporating the review process into the administrative appeals system. Let us understand the process that now obtains. The process has its origin in a challenge by the taxpayer which can be killed by the Commissioner of Taxation; or the Commissioner may decide to refer it to an independent board of review. The taxpayer has a further right to secure a hearing in the Supreme Court. The Court can canvass all the facts of the case and make a decision, whether the case turns on point of fact or on points of law. This is a very important right of access to the higher courts of the land. This right surely must constrain the Taxation Commissioner to take into careful account the statement of the facts. It surely must be one of the important compulsions which the Taxation Commissioner takes into account when he makes his decision whether or not to refer the matter to a board of review. And the board for its part must have to take the same kind of care, if it does not wish to see a successful challenge in the Supreme Court.

So let us not underestimate for a moment the constraint that operates on the taxing authority by the existence of the citizen's right to have the matter canvassed from go to whoa in the Supreme Court. I want to know whether these rights in their entirety remain unaffected by this legislation. All the Treasurer (Mr Keating) says in his second reading speech is that the present avenue of appeal under some taxation laws to a Supreme Court will remain. I would like to be reassured on this point, because the right of appeal from the Administrative Appeals Tribunal to the Federal Court of Australia can only be on a point of law.
Paragraphs 157 and 158 of the report of the Administrative Review Council read:

157. A consequence of the transfer of jurisdiction to the AAT would be that appeals would lie, as with other jurisdictions of the AAT, to the Federal Court of Australia. As appeals from the boards presently lie to the State Supreme Courts, and thence to the Federal Court, the jurisdiction of State Supreme Courts in respect of appeals from Boards of Review would be eliminated. This reduction in the number of appeal stages was given by some State Councils of the Taxation Institute of Australia as one reason for preferring the transfer of the Boards' jurisdiction to the AAT.

158. As appeals from the AAT to the Federal Court may be made only on questions of law, appeals would no longer be by way of rehearing the matter, as presently occurs in hearings before the Supreme Courts.
Is the House being treated fairly by such a brief reference-and an ambiguous reference at that-by the Minister in his second reading speech?

The question is: Does the process mean that the right of appeal through the court remains unaffected by this legislation? Or are we being put in a position where a very important right is being curtailed by the action of the Government? One is left in doubt because the Minister does not close with the issue outlined in the Review Council's report. So the House and the people of Australia will need reassurance. Clearly a right of appeal to the Federal Court is a more limited right than the appeal right that now exists. The key question is: What sacrifices is the taxpayer making in this change?

A more general argument concerns me. The present system has been in operation 60 years. With very little notice, the change is being exacted in a cognate and guillotined debate. Is it intended to rush the taxpayer off his sense of balance, to seize the opportunity to ring in changes, while people are pre-occupied with present and legitimate concerns about fringe benefits and capital gains taxes? The fact is, that an increasing backlog of cases calling for review is building up. I have personally received representations from chartered accountants in my electorate expressing concern about the delays. As we all know, taxation payments have to be made prior to review. A significant number of appeals are upheld by the board and the process of delay has the effect of funding the Government for an extensive period. Moreover, it denies the taxpayer the ability to employ funds in a high interest rate market. As honourable members would understand, the sense of grievance is considerable when considerable amounts of money are involved. I am informed that this backlog of cases is building at an ever increasing rate.

It is not surprising under those circumstances that the accountancy profession is becoming actively concerned about the pressures placed on it by this Government. We should not be surprised to read the statement by Mr Bernard Wright, President of the Australian Society of Accountants, who is reported today as saying that the Government must delay the introduction of the fringe benefits tax until it can offer a simple, cost effective system of compliance. The profession complains, quite rightly, about the unnecessary administrative burden on all organisations, not only in industry, commerce and government, but also charities and non-profit organisations.

We will expect taxation appeals under this new taxation system to be considerable indeed because everyone is saying how much more complex the system is likely to be following the changes. This means a new avenue is opened up for factual disputation. Will appeals be to the Supreme Court as they would from the boards? I seriously doubt it. Thus, the Government is not only producing horrendously complicated tax administration, but also hell-bent to limit the right of appeal on the facts; and many of the appeals will be disputes of fact. Given those scenarios, it is no wonder that the second reading speech is clouded in ambiguity by the issue of appeals to the Supreme Court. For instance, why does the Government repeal section 196, the right of appeal to the Supreme Court on the assessment, and leave the issue so cloudy in the second reading speech? Why does the Government feel obliged to restrain the appeal mechanism? I think that is a good question and it is one for which there are no obvious explanations. I hope that the Treasurer, or whoever answers for the Government, will make the point absolutely clear when he replies. As I have suggested, it is intended to increase the powers of the Commissioner of Taxation to quash appellants. The Government needs this now that it has invented the most complex tax laws in Australia's history.

Given that scenario, to explain the transaction in this legislation we have to look at the Government's general predicament, because the debate on this legislation takes place against a sense of national crisis, entirely engendered by the management errors of this Government. There is no dispute about it. In the last few days the nation has been put through the wringer. People have been told by the Treasurer of this country that the nation, under Labor, is on the way to becoming a banana republic, and they have heard that statement loudly and clearly. We all have to make sacrifices, we are told. The cupboard is bare, we are told. But we get a strange sort of message from the Treasurer because he says that the internal economy is terrific; it is just those rotten sods overseas who are making it so difficult for us. I do not see how we can be a banana republic on the one hand and so terrifically forward looking and in such good economic shape internally on the other hand. It just does not make sense, but that has never worried the Treasurer.

The impression created by the Treasurer not only has left a sense of depression about the national needs of the economy but also has successfully give a widespread impression that the Government does not know what to do. It leaves us with a racy analysis, blaming everybody in sight but itself and, in the most dramatic piece of handwringing by a Treasurer ever in the history of Federation, it has deepened national bewilderment rather than doing anything else. Of course, we had the Prime Minister, whilst overseas, finding his own sanguine approach to the economy exposed, apparently having been hoping to maintain a very shallow approach to the problem. Being found out, he has been told by his colleagues, left behind in the discomfort of a government in crisis, that it is time to stop wishing the problems will disappear and instead try to come to terms with them. Many have seen the point in a recent cartoon in the Sydney Morning Herald which depicts the Treasurer being confronted by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) saying `You have been telling us fibs for the last 12 months', and the Prime Minister angrily saying: `You have been telling the truth for two weeks'. We have seen what happened to that. The Prime Minister very quickly moved in and tried to do something to ease this sense of real concern that is felt throughout the nation following this extraordinary remark by the Treasurer that we are heading down the track to becoming a banana republic.

I do not think it is too much to say that there can be no doubt that the Prime Minister's authority over the economic management of the Government has suffered a very grave loss of confidence in this public dispute. As one prominent newspaper stated, he found himself a lame duck Prime Minister with no explanations and little direction. What have we seen since he came back to Australia? We have not had one statement to this Parliament. Of course, that is too much to expect. We find the Government increasingly treating the Parliament of the nation with more and more contempt. We had the Acting Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen), a bewildered witness to the decline of the Prime Minister's stakes, finding himself resurrected for leadership qualities, and in a stage-managed unveiling he was brought in from the cold to hose down the all-too-frank-talking Treasurer and to restore the Government's composure. So here we are today in the Parliament, meeting in an atmosphere of economic crisis, with the Prime Minister handing out bromide to all who pass him by.

TALK.START.PARA: —Get on with the tax Bills.

—The honourable member says that I should get on with it. I think we should analyse the economic malaise that is gripping this nation, which has been brought about by the actions of this Government. Speakers from the Government side of the Parliament get up and say: `It is all terrific. These are great taxation changes'. We find total confusion out in the market-place, we find employers confronted with the most complex series of obligations they have ever been confronted with and we find the Commissioner of Taxation sending out documents before the law has ever been passed. The honourable member for Canberra asks me to get on with the subject. I am getting on with the subject all right. I am pointing out to this House and to the Australian people the absolute confusion that has been brought about by the actions of this Government. As I have said, we are meeting here today in an atmosphere of economic crisis, with the Prime Minister trying to hose down the whole thing. I think we are finding that the Government really is battling with a serious economic situation. It cannot hide that serious economic situation by statements from the Treasurer that all is well at home, that it is only the people and the countries overseas who are making things difficult for us. That simply does not hold water in the present situation.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the Bills before us in this cognate debate-hopefully I will have an opportunity to say more about the capital gains tax on another occasion-I seriously ask the Treasurer to clear up the confusion about the appeals mechanism following the moving of the taxation boards of review across to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. There is a very real and a very proper concern by taxpayers that a hitherto sacred right of appeal has suddenly, mysteriously, been taken away from them. If that is the case we have a serious erosion of the ordinary citizen's right to have what he regards as a proper consideration of his taxation obligations heard by the highest court in the land. If that is not to be the case in the future, it needs to be stated plainly and clearly for people to appreciate. I hope that the Government moves swiftly to eliminate this possible cause of confusion through its elimination of a very important right of appeal presently available to taxpayers in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will surprise honourable members by actually speaking to the legislation that is before the House. I want to make particular reference to the foreign tax credit system which is outlined in the Taxation Laws Amendment (Foreign Tax Credits) Bill. This is a very important part of the legislative tax package before the House, and it has two main rationales. The first is to improve the equity and efficiency of the tax system, which is basically the aim of this total tax package, and the second is to assist in combating tax avoidance through the use of off-shore companies or other entities.

SPEECH.PARA: The foreign tax credit system is a mechanism which ensures that income earned by Australians overseas is subject to the same rate of tax as income earned from Australian sources-at least to the extent that the income is remitted to Australia. The present tax system provides an incentive in some circumstances for Australians to invest overseas rather than in Australia, and this must be to Australia's detriment. Some people have argued against the foreign tax credit system on the grounds that Australian investment overseas helps our export performance and can create jobs in Australia. This is undoubtedly true in some circumstances but, to the extent that there are real benefits to companies from investing overseas, this investment will obviously take place in the absence of the tax incentives. The only additional overseas investment arising from tax incentives will occur in instances where that investment would otherwise have taken place in Australia. Almost by definition, such investment represents a loss of Australian jobs.

The foreign tax credit system will go some way towards removing the existing tax incentives for overseas investment. The present possibility that foreign source income may be taxable at a low rate overseas and be exempt from Australian tax when remitted to Australia has led to the development of a number of tax avoidance schemes aimed at giving income a foreign source. Such overseas investment does nothing, or very little, for the foreign country and certainly it is not to Australia's benefit.

The increasing internationalisation of business in general and the growing number of multinationals of all sizes have led to a spectacular growth in services designed to advise companies on the most tax efficient way of planning their international operations. These services indicate the best way of repatriating profits and income from overseas operations by exploiting international tax treaties through the passing of money via subsidiaries set up in intermediate countries. There are many examples of this, and I refer to one that has been devised by Touche Ross which explains the great need for this legislation. That company has developed a computerised network with a database covering the tax rates and rules of 185 countries and more than 800 international tax treaties. The computer system can devise the best method of repatriating profits from any particular country to the home country of the investor.

An article in the Australian Financial Review of 11 October last year set out an example of a British company earning interest income in Brazil, Belgium, Italy and South Korea being advised to pass the income from Brazil and Italy through a subsidiary in West Germany; pass the income from Belgium and South Korea through a Dutch subsidiary; and, in addition, pass the income from South Korea through another subsidiary in Finland before sending it through to West Germany. They are some of the complex issues that that company goes through to avoid paying tax. What sorts of resources have gone into devising ways to avoid paying any Australian tax? The complexities of these arrangements illustrate to what lengths companies will go to exploit a particular feature of a country's international tax arrangements.

The interplay of the domestic tax laws and international tax treaties can also be illustrated by the use of the so-called `stepping stone' strategy; for example, a tax haven company plans to invest funds as a loan in a high-tax state, A.
