The funds are channelled through a company set up for this purpose in a high-tax state, B. This latter company receives interest from state A at a rate of, say, 12 per cent and pays interest to the tax haven company at the rate of 11.5 per cent. State A levies a withholding tax on interest which is reduced to nil under the tax treaty between states A and B. State B does not levy a withholding tax on interest under domestic law. In such a case the tax haven company benefits from a treaty between the high-tax states A and B and is subject to tax in the latter state only to an insignificant degree. That shows the complexities of the situation and to what lengths companies will go to avoid paying these taxes.

In the face of such sophistication and the preparedness to devote so many resources to such tax avoidance or tax minimisation schemes Australia must be prepared to protect the equity and integrity of its own tax system. The foreign tax credits system will nullify some of these tax avoidance activities and will provide a basis for further anti-avoidance measures if the Government decides such measures are warranted.

The first main feature of this system being established under the legislation before the House is that the foreign tax credits system assesses foreign source income on a world-wide basis, allowing the excess foreign tax credits from investments in high tax countries to be offset against the Australian tax due on income from low tax countries. It also allows an unlimited number of tiers of subsidiaries to be included in the calculation of any underlying foreign tax. Both these features significantly reduce the potential impact of the foreign tax credits system on foreign source income.

Certain foreign source, interest income will be assessed separately from all other income, with separate tax credit limits. This is an anti-avoidance measure as interest income is one of the main vehicles used in avoidance schemes. Rules will be developed to trace interest income through dividends received from foreign subsidiaries. Interest earned by a subsidiary carrying on its normal business activities, and interest received by banks and other financial institutions, will be excluded from the quarantining process.

Under the Bill, losses incurred in any year in respect of an overseas branch operation or other particular business, commercial or investment activity will not be offset against domestic income in the same year, nor against other foreign source income, but will be available for offset against profits derived in any of the seven succeeding years from the same branch or activity. This provision is designed to ensure that losses are not used to reduce Australian tax liability on other income in circumstances where subsequent profits from the same investment will not be subject to commensurate Australian tax.

A further essential part of this legislation is that a tax avoidance mechanism, which has been canvassed by some tax advisers, will be dealt with also. I am referring to Australian companies investing overseas in the form of a branch so that any initial losses would be offset against Australian source income and then converting the branch to a subsidiary when the operation becomes profitable. In this way the losses would be fully deductible for the purposes of Australian tax while the profits would escape Australian tax unless remitted to Australia. A second approach could be to set up both a branch and a subsidiary in a foreign country and arrange affairs between them so that the branch bore the losses while the subsidiary earned the profits. Once again, the losses would be fully deductible while the profits escaped taxation. The loss offset provisions in the Bill will prevent the use of such tax avoidance techniques. One can appreciate the very elaborate measures undertaken by many companies to avoid dutifully paying their tax.

The Bill provides for tax sparing provisions to be granted in certain circumstances to developing countries. Developing countries may offer taxation incentives, such as tax holidays, to foreign investors; that is, these countries promise to forgo some of the tax revenue they would normally collect from foreign investors in order to encourage a greater level of investment and so lift their rate of development. By ensuring that foreign source income is taxed at Australian rates, the foreign tax credits system would simply result in the tax forgone by the developing country being collected by Australia, and the intended incentive for Australian investment in that country would be removed. Tax sparing provisions are designed to prevent such an outcome and Australia will consider granting tax sparing provisions on a case by case basis to developing countries both in the context of a comprehensive double tax treaty or by regulations pending the negotiation of such a treaty.

Although this Bill is obviously complex, as a great deal of tax legislation is, it is important that it be considered as part of the tax package. It is pretty useless to provide a very comprehensive domestic tax package without at the same time dealing with the realities of the financial markets. As I said early in the speech, there is no doubt that the markets that we are looking at for business in Australia have become very sophisticated. They are on an international basis, and one cannot just look at the tax arrangements in isolation from the international operations of many of the companies which have an Australian base. I recommend this Bill to the House, as well as the other pieces of legislation, as they will be a very integral part of ensuring that our corporate citizens return a fair and equitable portion of profits to Australia. This legislation complements the domestic tax package which has been before the House over the last few weeks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Over the past couple of weeks we have noticed that the rhetoric of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has not included reference to economic miracles and J-curves. Instead, his newly discovered holy writ is now morality. His new tax imposts are moral-if the Treasurer is to be believed-for the first time in the recorded history of taxes. Never mind the historical adage to the effect that there is no such thing as a moral tax, this Government can summon the gall to claim that, by some new miracle more likely to be seen at Lourdes than in this Parliament, its new and onerous taxes deserve a place in the hearts and minds of all taxpayers. That is plainly ridiculous. Even if it were so, if we were to examine briefly the Government's morality in a wholly but not exhaustive range of activities, we would see that it is severely flawed.

SPEECH.PARA: In deciding the merits of the Government's and the Treasurer's newly discovered morality it is necessary to remember some unpleasant facts. Not so long ago the theme was not the Government's morality but its record. Of course, it is a record shattering Government, by any measure. It holds the all-time Australian record for expenditure, deficits and, especially relevant, taxation. So too is this Hawke Government the all-time record holder for the number of broken promises and undertakings it has perpetrated. The most relevant broken promise in the context of any debate on taxes and on any part of the Treasurer's so-called tax package is the solemn pledge of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) not to introduce a capital gains tax. That is a laugh-what a joke-because, as you know, Mr Deputy Speaker, capital gains taxes are to be debated tomorrow under the constraint of the guillotine, as are these Bills being debated under the constraint of the guillotine tonight.

I turn briefly, as a surprising number of members have done already, to the Taxation Laws Amendment (Foreign Tax Credits) Bill 1986, which is being debated cognately with the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1986, the Income Tax (Securities and Agreements) (Withholding Tax Recoupment) Bill 1986 and the Taxation Boards of Review (Transfer of Jurisdiction) Bill 1986. The first Bill provides that all foreign source income of a foreign branch of an Australian company will be exposed to Australian tax, whereas such income is now exempt if it is subject to income tax in the source country. Of course, it is not confined to foreign branches of a particular Australian company.

The Government's 1985 White Paper on taxation agreed that this basis for taxation was consistent with the approach adopted by many countries with general credit systems. Whether, after allowance of appropriate credits, there would be any practical discrimination in favour of the corporate form is a matter that could be settled only on the facts. However, one advantage of the corporate form has been the channelling of dividends into tax havens instead of direct remission to the Australian parent company. Largely, that would disappear under this legislation. Of course, to the extent that it succeeds in doing that the measure is welcome. The White Paper estimated a direct gain to revenue of $30m at 1984-85 levels of income. In paragraph 20.9 of the White Paper the Government argued:
In addition there may be an indirect benefit as adoption of the system would diminish the tax advantages to Australians of establishing operations outside the country.

All that is perfectly true and worth saying, of course. While I acknowledge that there could be, and undoubtedly will be, benefits in many ways, there could be down-side effects as well, particularly if we find that companies are driven off-shore. I know that it is very difficult with any legislation for anyone to be precise about that sort of prospect, but I wonder just how much work was done on this. I wonder how much we might fear that, instead of companies conducting their main operations in Australia, they will in fact be driven off-shore. The Government claims that it has considered representations from many sources and has held discussions with interested business groups. As if to give validity to that statement, I note an article by Louise Dodson in the Australian Financial Review of 23 May, when she reported that the Business Council of Australia had succeeded in winning a number of concessions which included an absence of limits on the number of subsidiaries that could get tax credits and the concession that overseas branches of Australian life insurance companies would be taxed only on income sent to Australia and not on all branch profits.

That seems to bear out the Treasurer's claim about consultation. However, questions raised by the construction industry indicate that it was not consulted, or if it was consulted its doubts and questions were not satisfied. All should be aware that the construction industry operates in our region. It is a significant earner of overseas income and has the potential to expand even further. That industry has its doubts and queries. For instance, at present, in countries where taxation is lower than it is in Australia, Australian construction companies are still able to compete with locally based companies. I note that the nature of construction work is such that the contractor is subject to taxation in the country in which the project is located. A constructor cannot manufacture off-shore.

Against the reasons for introducing this legislation, the construction industry is concerned that for some time Government Ministers have been promoting the export of goods and services to reduce our imbalance of imports over exports. Considerable focus has been concentrated on the competitiveness of Australian manufacturing and service industries and their lack of application to overseas markets. At the same time, of course, proposals for the introduction of a foreign tax credit system, which appears likely to have an adverse effect on construction companies working overseas, is being adopted by this Government. That is a contradiction in policies if ever there was one.

The Government is making noises about promoting the export of goods and services, and it is even providing incentives under the Export Market Development Grants Act, while at the same time it is disadvantaging or disincentiving constructors. I remind the House that tendering for construction work in foreign countries is very competitive. Some governments give more assistance to their construction companies operating overseas than do others. Where company and personal tax in a host country is lower than it is in Australia the Australian contractor can put in a lower bid price while retaining an acceptable after-tax return to the parent company in Australia. If the money returned to Australia is now to be taxed-as it is-to bring it up to Australian tax rates, the tender prices for new projects will have to increase in order to obtain the acceptable return from any one particular project.

As we know, in any competitive situation that is likely to render that bid uncompetitive and therefore unacceptable to a client in an overseas situation. Let me give an example. In Hong Kong the company tax rate is about 18.5 per cent. A construction company, in order to maintain the same after-tax profit for a contract worth, say, $100m in the first instance, will need to increase that price to $106m as a result of this foreign tax credits legislation. This additional cost on the bid, together with the extra cost of expatriate personnel packages, would almost certainly lose the job for the Australian contractor if there were companies bidding who were subject only to Hong Kong taxation or who had a favourable foreign tax credit scheme.

A foreign tax credit scheme may reduce tax avoidance when a company sets up a manufacturing plant in a tax haven. However, in construction, the tenderer or potential contractor has no ability to change the location of a project and must, of course, accept the tax laws of the country in which the project is situated. Therefore, it is a case not of selecting a tax haven country but of selecting a suitable project. A suitable project is one in which the contractor has the necessary expertise, can provide a suitable financial package if it is part of the deal, and believes that it can offer something more competitive than other contractors. In being competitive the most significant factors in assessing the tender profit margin are risk and, more importantly, taxation. A properly designed foreign tax credit system can assist a contractor to spread his risk over all his operation, thus enabling him to bid more competitively. Unfortunately, in the case of overseas contractors, I do not see those elements present.

It is in the area of taxation that the Government continues to wrong-foot and destabilise the wealth creators in the private sector. Under what can only be described as this avaricious Government the stampede to raise more and more tax revenue has already caused it to abandon the long established practice of taxing income of any kind in the hands of a recipient or beneficiary, and in that I am talking about fringe benefits taxes. Just as it is deceitful to describe the Government's most recent tax proposals as tax reform-as I have heard honourable members on the other side do on occasions today-so is it stretching the meaning of the word `package' to describe a series of disparate tax measures as a tax package. These new taxes are designed to increase the total tax take-nothing more and nothing less. They have, of course, a decided anti-business and anti-rural bias. I remind the House that decisions on negative gearing and capital gains taxes, which are having a disastrous impact on residential accommodation, are included. Also, there is the quarantining of farm losses which, along with the capital gains tax, is having a similar effect on the rural sector. The foreign tax credit system will destroy our international competitiveness and will cause some Australian companies to move their whole Australian operation off-shore. I hope that the Taxation Laws Amendment (Foreign Tax Credits) Bill does not result in that happening, but I suspect it will.

Then there is the fringe benefits tax treatment, which as a de facto payroll tax will significantly increase the cost of business and act as a disincentive to employment. It will also decrease the profitability and competitiveness of Australian companies. Jointly and severally, the measures contained in the entire so-called tax package have the potential to crush various areas of economic endeavour. So much for the claimed neutrality of these measures in total. I have heard that thrown around the chamber today on more than one occasion, and it is patently false. Because of the application of the guillotine by the Leader of the House (Mr Young) in relation to this legislation there is far too little time to debate these measures; we are simply, in a large part, left to examine the twisted thinking that is behind them. That is to be regretted. It has been dwelt on by more than one speaker other than myself. However, it still needs to be said that, if we were to make a contribution to improving the legislation, we should, of course, have been given an opportunity to debate many of these very complex Bills clause by clause at the Committee stage. That is not to be the case, which is to be deplored.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HURFORD
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank all honourable members who have taken part in this debate. Before responding on behalf of the Government, I seek leave to present the explanatory memoranda to the taxation Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the explanatory memoranda to the following Bills: Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1986, Income Tax (Securities and Agreements) (Withholding Tax Recoupment) Bill 1986, Taxation Laws Amendment (Foreign Tax Credits) Bill 1986, Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill 1986, Income Tax (Rates) Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill 1986, and erratum to Taxation Boards of Review (Transfer of Jurisdiction) Bill 1986. I appreciate the opportunity to do that.

SPEECH.PARA: I should like to respond firstly to the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), who raised the following matters during the debate this morning: Firstly, that a Taxation Board of Review has three members, whereas the Administrative Appeals Tribunal may have only one member and that member may be a former taxation officer who might be biased against the taxpayer; secondly, that there will be no right of appeal to the High Court of Australia under the new arrangements; thirdly, that the proposed amendments will remove a taxpayer's present entitlement to the Commissioner's reasons for the decision on an objection.

I shall respond to those three points. Firstly, the more flexible procedures of the AAT will allow single-member hearings. Single-member hearings, however, will largely involve questions of fact and not difficult questions of law. More complex cases will be heard by three-member tribunals.

There is no evidence to support the statement that a former taxation officer sitting on the Tribunal might be biased against the taxpayer, but if there is such evidence I hope the honourable member will draw particular cases to our attention. We have no evidence of that. Former taxation officers have been appointed chairmen of boards of review for many years and have given distinguished service in that role. I have been a taxation practitioner in my capacity as a chartered accountant and I attest to that fact. There is no evidence that such chairmen have been biased in their decision making. In fact, decisions given by boards of review constituted in part by former taxation officers are so often, as we all know, in favour of the taxpayer.

The honourable member was also incorrect in some other matters. There will be no change to a taxpayer's right of appeal to the High Court under the new arrangements. As is outlined on page 29 of the explanatory memorandum tabled at the time of the introduction of the Bill, a decision of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal may be taken on appeal to the Full Court of the Federal Court of Australia. A decision of that Court may be appealed from to the High Court by special leave of that Court. There is no present entitlement to reasons for a decision by the Commissioner on an objection. This will not change under the proposals contained in the Bill. It is the Commissioner's general practice, however, to provide reasons for a decision on disallowance of that objection. In addition, reasons for the decision may be discussed with the Commissioner's officers at the appeal stage. I add that under the new arrangements the Commissioner will, until 1 July 1988, provide to the AAT exactly the same statement of reasons and documents that he presently provides to a board of review. From 1 July 1988 a more detailed statement of reasons will be provided to the Tribunal in accordance with the normal practice of the Tribunal.

The honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) mentioned a letter he had received from a constituent who had been fined $200 for not lodging a taxation return when in fact the taxpayer was entitled to a refund. I respond by saying that taxation returns are normally due to be lodged by 31 August each year unless an extension of time to lodge has been granted. The taxpayer concerned apparently had not lodged the return in question by April the following year, some eight months after it was due. The Commissioner normally sends a final notice before commencing court proceedings to afford taxpayers a further opportunity to lodge an outstanding return. The fine of $200 imposed by the court was well below the level of penalty now applicable to such offences.

I would say more about the contribution by the honourable member for Dawson but, as time is short, in his case and in the case of the contribution by the honourable member for Fairfax (Mr Adermann) I will respond in writing. The honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) queried whether the present rights of appeal to State supreme courts would be maintained in their entirety. This was made clear at page 7 of the second reading speech of the Treasurer (Mr Keating). Appeals from the AAT on a question of law will go to the Federal Court. Where a right of appeal directly from a decision of the Commission to a supreme court presently exists, that right will be maintained. The question of appeal rights from the AAT is dealt with in the note prepared by the Attorney-General's Department. I will send in the post, in response to what the honourable member had to say about the Taxation Boards of Review (Transfer of Jurisdiction) Bill 1986, the responses we have had from the Attorney-General's Department. I will also respond in writing to the honourable member for Mackellar because he raised some other points when he led for the Opposition in this debate. I recognise the contributions made by the honourable member for Dawson and the honourable member for Forde (Dr Watson) and, as I know the Opposition wants to have a Committee stage debate, I will not detain the House any longer. I say to those honourable members that they will receive a response in writing. I thank the House and I commend the Bills to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I am delighted to be given the opportunity to speak on this legislation in the Committee stage. If ever I have seen a package of legislation which has been so correctly designated by the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), as legislation that will further increase and, I think, substantially increase, the power of the Australian Taxation Office vis-a-vis the citizens of Australia, it is this legislation. I suppose it is only a matter of time before our national anthem is changed Advance Australia Fair to `Advance Taxtralia Fair'. I say quite bluntly that a high taxing government must legislate in this manner to obtain the revenues that are so essential for it to pay for its very expensive policies.

SPEECH.PARA: If I could write a two-word policy for a potentially successful political party in this country, I would write the words `cut taxes', because everything flows from there. If we cut taxes, we have to have better housekeeping. It means we have to be far better in our handling of expenditure. It also means that more people in Australia have more money in their pockets to do their thing, which is basic to our philosophy and, of course, complete anathema to the philosphy of the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) and the other members of the Hawke socialist Government. They believe they can do a better job with your money, Mr Chairman, and my money, than we can do ourselves.

Believe it or not, I am not a critic of the Australian Taxation Office. Indeed, I admire the Office for working under the worst piece of legislation that I have come across in 22 years of legal practice. Effectively, we are looking at legislation now with more than 1,100 clauses. If we take into account board of review decisions, Australian Taxation Office official directions and the like, we have an enormous Office but, more importantly, we have a very significant number of Australians who probably have to bear in mind on any day of the week about 2,000 taxation provisions. I will not have a bar of seeing the Australian Taxation Office criticised because we in this Parliament have permitted the Income Tax Assessment Act to be amended in excess of 93 times since 7 December 1936. That is two years before I was born, Mr McLeay, and even more years before you were born.

I wonder whether one day someone will have the guts to say that the sooner the Income Tax Assessment Act is torn up, the better; the sooner we get legislation which is understandably to the men and women of Australia who are obliged to pay their taxes, the better. We now have a situation in which the High Court of Australia is able to take into account extrinsic material in interpreting tax legislation. That is very important, because we have now passed out of an era in which there was strict and literal interpretation, which, in the opinion of many, quite apolitically, produced results which were not in the national interest. Would it not be marvellous to say to the people of Australia: `There is the tax law of this country-100 clauses, 30 pages in; simple English; there for you to understand'?

It is a national disgrace that at present the system has created a situation in which some 80,000 appeals are awaiting hearing and determination. The average waiting time can be as long as three years. To the extent that the Government has said that this is wrong and has moved to provide an alternative system of appeal, one would say that that is an encouraging sign. Very properly, the honourable member for Mackellar said: `If it will improve the system, that is good'. But will it improve the system? I am involved, in an honorary capacity, in a number of matters before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. I believe the Administrative Appeals Tribunal to be more formal in its hearing and, therefore, more protracted in its deliberations than would a board of review be, so I have a question mark in my mind as to whether the move to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal will necessarily mean better service both for the taxpayer and for the Australian Taxation Office.

Of course, the taxpayer is in a totally different position from that of any other litigant in Australia, because he or she can lodge an appeal for a very small sum. I think that $3 is the deposit; it used to be. But the rules are these: `You appeal; fair enough. But you pay in advance'. I have grave reservations about the justice of that, because I am aware of cases in which persons have paid and in which the matter has dragged and dragged, and finally they have just given it up as a bad job. I do not know of any other jurisdiction which says to a litigant: `Before you come before us, you have to pay up'. It almost presumes that the litigant will lose.

I question, too-and again, this is a criticism not of the Australian Taxation Office but of the wretched system that we have in this country-the variation of interest rates payable depending on whether one is receiving a refund or paying taxation which is due but which is in arrears; 14 per cent for one, but 20 per cent for the other. It does not seem very fair to me. I take the very thoughtful point made by the honourable member for Mackellar about the situation in which a member of a board of review goes on to the taxation section of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and happens to be a former Deputy Commissioner. I am not for a moment suggesting that such persons should be disqualified, but it is rather like putting up a defendant before the arresting sergeant or, as the honourable member for Mackellar said, inviting the poacher to plead his case before the gamekeeper. The question of the appearance of justice is very important indeed. Remember the maxim: Justice must not only be done; justice must be manifestly-many people forget that word `manifestly'-seen to be done.

I question the action of this Government in ramming this legislation through a parliament which day by day becomes more like Moscow and less like Canberra and saying: `The law will come into effect on 1 July'. It does not sit well with the sort of constructive and thoughtful law reform which I know that he, in his heart of hearts, would espouse. What is this rush? SPEECH.PARA: I cannot talk about the bandicoot and the ferret. I cannot talk about what the Government has done to this country by taking away incentives. TALK.START.PARA: —These Bills are the result of a long grind, a long journey, from the first summit on the way to the second. It is rather interesting that when the Treasurer (Mr Keating) came down from the mount at the first summit, he had achieved only a shadow of the projected results he had wanted when he went to that summit. Since then, these Bills have been forecast so long ahead of time and so long ahead of execution that, really, we have been through a period of government by decree, in which people have been making decisions in the community unknowing of the final consequences that might result from those decisions and unknowing of the details which would surround the actual legislation when it was presented. We have the details now, which we are considering, but many people have made decisions or withheld their decision-making to the detriment of the industrial and commercial community because of the traditional way that this Government has insulted the Australian people and really treated them with contempt when it comes to decision-making about some of their most important areas of conduct. The same rules have been applied to this legislation as those which were applied to the assets test, for instance, which had a gestation period of about 11 months. This legislation has not been quite as long as 11 months in coming, but the wait seems much longer to those who have been inconvenienced by this very long period.

SPEECH.PARA: We have seen the emergence of capital gains legislation, which will be discussed in another period in this House, and the negative gearing, the entertainment expenses and the fringe benefits legislation. The Treasurer has continued to say in answer to questions in this House and in debate that these measures are part of a package. When one examines it, it is a pretty shonky package. He keeps on saying that the moves are revenue neutral and that we will be looking at a reduced maximum taxation level of 49 per cent. First of all, 49 per cent is not the proper figure on which Australians' income is taxed. The figure is 50 per cent. That is only a subterfuge to separate the Medicare levy from the general level of income taxation.

We have been through this question in prior decades when previous Australian governments have separated social service contributions from taxation. It may not be long before these will be melded. On the other hand, the Medicare levy may be kept separate as a subterfuge, because the levy will not stay at one per cent. The much vaunted figure of 49 per cent-that magic figure which is below 50 per cent-that the Treasurer uses for the top level taxation rate is not really 49 per cent; it is 50 per cent. In the present financial crisis in which we are living in Australia, on the road to the banana republic, we can expect that Medicare levy figure to come closer and closer to the actual cost of Medicare in the community. One honourable member on this side of the House said the other night that the closest figure that he could work out was a levy of 3 1/2 per cent. If the Government gets around to having the courage of its stated convictions that it will do the proper and hard things in the economic decision-making area, we can expect the top level taxation rate to be something over 52 per cent. That will make a monkey once again out of the Treasurer when he refers to the economic parameters which he uses from time to time.

The same types of statements were made about the fringe benefits tax legislation. As the Australian Financial Review pointed out in one of the articles it ran soon after the introduction of that tax, the employers liable to pay the fringe benefits tax would not have to pay 100 per cent of the tax; they would have to pay closer to 198 per cent of the tax, because it is a non-claimable expense. If a company pays 100 per cent of the fringe benefits tax, at present it will be taxed at a rate of 46 per cent. After the changes in taxation are effected the rate will be 49 or 50 per cent. That means that employers, after they have paid their company, personal or partnership tax, will be paying nearly twice the actual tax.

All of these proposals are tied together in what is called the tax package, which relies so much on the prices and incomes accord. At every turn that the Treasurer takes in relation to his financial plans, he goes back to the accord. It must be admitted that the accord, probably in its first year of operation, had a dampening effect on wage rises in this community. It certainly does not have that dampening effect now. It was always a device to get around the discipline of floating the dollar. The accord, with its magical indexation of wages to costs, is an automatic way of getting around the discipline of floating the dollar.

The Government set about trying to separate from the local economy the effects of overseas trading on the Australian economy. The Treasurer, right to this day, maintains the separateness of what he calls the domestic economy, because that is where he sees that the votes reside. Of course, as he sees it, the votes are dependent on how he can sell the health of Australia's domestic economy, so he continues falsely to separate the economic effect of the overseas trade imbalances from the domestic economy. He uses the lowering of the price of the products that we export as basically the sole reason for the present balance of trade defect. We know that if the inflation rate in Australia continues to rise at about 9 per cent per annum, people who produce coal, wheat, iron ore and aluminium, for instance, will simply be unable to continue their production, because they cannot produce at a loss. That will be the final test of whether the Treasurer can give some sensible responses to the challenges which are in front of him. In these Bills that are part of a package we are seeing again pathetic attempts by the Treasurer to implement what is only a small proportion of what he attempted to get at the National Taxation Summit in the face of his inability to control inflation and costs in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: This clause relates to the quite astonishing proposal that the Parliament be asked to relax the secrecy provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act to allow the Commissioner of Taxation to divulge material about the taxation of superannuation funds and similar bodies-similar vehicles-to a body yet to be set up whose constitution is yet to be determined. The full input of this proposal will hardly have dawned on honourable members. Before the Government has even made up its mind about new regulatory arrangements for superannuation funds, the Parliament is being asked to make a major change to the secrecy provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act. It is being asked to say that previously secret material will be disclosed to a committee, a group or a regulatory body as yet unnamed. That proposal is totally unacceptable. We oppose it utterly. Heaven forbid, the Government might want to disclose this information to a committee of public safety of some kind. In a more sinister context, it might be Mr Gary Weaven of the Australian Council of Trade Unions who is chosen to head this regulatory body running superannuation funds in Australia. After all, the Government has already delegated responsibility for retirement security of Australians to the trade union movement and the Treasurer has already suggested to his friends such as Mr Hodgson and Mr Gallagher that they should extract agreements from employers in the field to pay superannuation moneys into superannuation funds controlled by the trade union movement. Where there is agreement it is a different matter. That would fall within suitable guidelines.

Here we have a situation in which the Government is highly suspect on the problem of superannuation. TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I and a number of my colleagues will demonstrate the harsh reality of the Government's proposed fringe benefits taxation legislation-the reality versus the myth, a myth sold constantly to an unsuspecting people about a whole array of new taxes by a government propaganda machine that would make the infamous Dr Goebbles green with envy. SPEECH.PARA: Among the many groups to be sorely disadvantaged will be the non-governmental charitable and welfare organisations which are otherwise tax exempt. These bodies, the demand for whose services always outstrips their ability to respond, struggle constantly to make ends meet. In times such as we have at present-during the first signs of an economic downturn aggravated by high levels of growing unemployment-such restrictive measures can only cause the disadvantaged to place much greater reliance on non-governmental welfare services. Consequently, the continuing financial viability of the considerable number of community welfare and charitable organisations will be severely threatened by the Government's new taxation policies.

It is a slightly abridged version which was presented in Oslo, Norway, on 11 December. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: When Alfred Nobel drafted his final will in late 1895, thus providing this enduring and monumental legacy, the world was changed with anticipation and optimism for the 20th century. Mind and hand, the distinctive attributes of our species, were at last finding their intertwined fulfillment in science and technology. Science promised mastery of a hostile environment and an end to chaotic societal relations punctuated by war and brutality. Advancing technology augured unlimited potential for human power, inspiring a dream for an end to drudgery and for an age of abundance.

The hope of a benevolent civilization was shattered in the blood-soaked trenches of the First World War. The ``war to end all wars'' claimed 16 million lives and left embers that kindled an even more catastrophic conflagration.

Over the sorry course of 5000 years of endless conflicts, some limits had been set on human savagery. Moral safeguards proscribed killing unarmed civilians and health workers, poisoning drinking waters, spreading infection among children and the disabled, and burning defenseless cities. But the Second World War introduced total war-unprincipled in method, unlimited in violence, and indiscriminate in victims. The ovens of Auschwitz and the atomic incineration of Hiroshima and Nagasaki inscribed a still-darker chapter in the chronicle of human brutality. The prolonged agony that left 50 million dead did not provide an enduring basis for an armistice against barbarism. On the contrary, arsenals soon burgeoned with genocidal weapons capable of equivalent of many of thousands of World War IIs.
The advent of the nuclear age posed an unprecedented question-not whether war would exact yet more lives, but whether war would preclude human existence altogether.

Every historic period has its Cassandras. Our era is the first in which prophecies of doom stem from objectives scientific analyses. Nearly a quarter of a century ago, a study by American physicians concluded that medicine, which in past wars had mitigated misery and saved lives, would have nothing to offer after a nuclear war. This conclusion was extrapolated from the destruction wrought by blast, fire, and radiation on Hiroshima and Nagasaki. Astonishingly, nearly 40 years elapsed before scientists first discovered additional ecological consequences. Nuclear war, they found, could blanket the sky with smoke, dust, and soot, creating a pall of all-pervasive darkness and frigid cold. The impact on climate could last for several years and would not spare the Southern Hemisphere.

But there is more. Since cities are enormous storehouses of combustible synthetics, raging firestorms would release into the air a Pandora's box of deadly toxins. When the dust, poisons, and soot finally cleared, another plague would be visited on the unfortunate survivors; high levels of ultraviolet light caused by depletion of atmospheric ozone would take an additional tall.

This scenario may not constitute a complete appraisal of the dire biological and ecological aftermath. We know little or nothing of the synergistic effects on out fragile ecosystem of subfreezing temperatures, darkness, high levels of radiation, massive release of toxins, excessive ultraviolet emissions, and other events still unforeseen.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) raised a question concerning some issues raised by the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) at Question Time today and I now provide some additional information. The question from the honourable member for Richmond, which implicitly suggested that people on remand in prisons are getting sickness benefits because of loopholes in the legislation, is a furphy. The loophole to which he referred forms the basis of our legal system; that is, that one is innocent until proven guilty. Since 1947, section 135THA of the Social Security Act has embodied this principle of law.

SPEECH.PARA: If a person on sickness benefit has been convicted of an offence and imprisoned, no sickness benefit is payable for the period of the imprisonment. If a person on sickness benefit is placed on remand, however, sickness benefit may be paid if other conditions of eligibility are met; for instance, by continuing coverage under a medical certificate. No prisoner, on remand or otherwise, is eligible to receive unemployment benefits because he or she could not comply with the work test requirement of being available for work. However, special benefit may be granted to prisoners on remand where they have dependants or face severe hardships through financial commitments. I point out to the honourable member for Richmond, who I see is now in the House, that remand periods for most prisoners are short.

Claims have been made that some prisoners are receiving benefits and those claims have been subject to investigation by officers of my Department for some time. Indeed, for several months the Department has been investigating claims that a number of people who are not eligible are receiving benefits. That investigation is very comprehensive and goes not only to the question of prisoners in New South Wales but generally throughout the Commonwealth. I would have thought it would have been known to the honourable member that those investigations have been proceeding. I might say that we are not without our difficulties in pursuing those investigations, because obviously we are dealing with State governments and State responsibilities. In the case of New South Wales, the progress of these investigations has been inhibited by the difficulties in gaining access to prisoners' files held by State governments.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, the whole tenor of the Act and its administration rests primarily with seeking to ensure the welfare of the dependants of remanded prisoners who have not yet been convicted and who may, in fact, be found not guilty. On the question of those remanded in relation to the so-called Milperra massacre, I must point out that the case itself and the length of remand of those involved are an extraordinary aberration in the legal history of this country. ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Charleville Drug Farm Raid: Commonwealth Indemnity

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 29 November:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it always a requirement for an indemnity guaranteeing payment of damages to Commonwealth property and injuries to Commonwealth personnel to be signed on behalf of the requesting State by the Premier of the State which seeks the use of the property and personnel for the purposes of arresting drug traffickers and the seizure of plants grown on drug farms; if so, was the Queensland Premier required to sign such an indemnity in the instance of the recent Charleville drug farm raid.

(2) Is he required to approve the use of Commonwealth equipment and personnel in such cases; if so, was there any delay in his approval in the Charleville drug farm raid which could have resulted in unnecessary risk to life and the opportunity of people to escape from the drug farm.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The requirement for an indemnity guaranteeing payment of damages to Commonwealth property and injuries to Commonwealth personnel in regard to aid to the civil power by the Australian Defence Force is determined in each case by consultation with the appropriate financial and legal authorities. In the case of the Charleville drug farm raid, it was determined that indemnification of the Commonwealth by the Queensland Police was appropriate. Accordingly, the Queensland Police Commissioner signed, on 5 November 1985, a document of indemnification for that operation. The requirement to sign this indemnification delayed the operation, without detriment, for twenty-four hours.

(2) The Minister for Defence is not required, in all cases, to approve the use of Commonwealth equipment and personnel in the event of Defence Force aid to the civil power. The Minister's approval is required in situations where there is a likelihood that Defence Force personnel may be required to use force. Where there is no likelihood of Defence Force personnel being required to use force, approval is given by the Chief of the Defence Force. In the case of the Charleville drug farm raid, approval was correctly given by the Chief of the Defence Force, and there was no delay in approval.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Conquest Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 14 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: What are the (a) sources and (b) amounts of Commonwealth revenue derived from 1 litre of (i) motor spirit, (ii) diesel fuel and (iii) aviation fuel.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: There are several sources of Commonwealth revenue from the production and marketing of petroleum in Australia. These include excise taxes on the sale of indigenous crude oil and LPG, excise taxes on petroleum products, royalty and licence fees paid by producers of petroleum from offshore areas as well as company tax paid by producers, refiners, marketers, retail outlets, etc. The amount of these taxes that can be attributable to each litre of petroleum product will vary with the type of product, the proportion of imports of crude oil and petroleum products, the cost of oil, as well as between each producing area in Australia, and the method chosen to allocate joint costs, such as the cost of crude oil, to each petroleum product.

Indicative estimates of some of the cost components for petrol have been prepared by the Department of Resources and Energy, based on the Import Parity Price set with effect from 1 May 1986, and the product excise rates expected to be applicable from mid May 1986. On that basis, Commonwealth excise and royalty receipts from a litre of petrol would amount to approximately 26 cents.

As noted above this amount will differ between each petroleum product. While diesel fuel attracts the same rate of product excise as for motor spirit, certain users are eligible for partial or full rebates of their excise. Further, the contribution of the crude oil excise and royalty to the cost of a litre of diesel would probably be lower than for motor spirit, reflecting the lower proportion of indigenous feedstocks used in the production of diesel.
The total figures are not available for diesel fuel and aviation fuel however excise and customs duties on the refined products, expected to be applicable from mid May 1986, are:
Motor spirit-19.2 cents per litre.
Diesel fuel (unrebated)-19.2 cents per litre.
Aviation gasoline-16.163 cents per litre.
Aviation turbine kerosene-15.354 cents per litre.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 19 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will proposals utilising airships be eligible for the supply of Airborne Surveillance Warning and Control Systems.
(2) When (a) the proposals be considered, and (b) a decision be made.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There are several studies underway in the Department of Defence examining the potential contribution of various sensor systems to airspace surveillance and control in Australia. The systems being evaluated include airships, airborne early warning and control aircraft, and ground based systems such as over-the-horizon radar. A Request for Proposal (RFP), specifically for Airborne Surveillance Warning and Control Systems and explicitly mentioning airships, was issued by my Department on 13 December 1985. The information expected to be made available in the responses to the RFP will help considerably in judgments on how best to develop further our capabilities in airspace surveillance and control.
(2) (a) Detailed consideration of the responses to the RFP will start after the closing date of 28 May 1986.

(b) Decisions on surveillance and control systems will be made progressively following the completion of the various studies. The possible way ahead for, specifically, airborne systems should become clearer within about a year, when there is the prospect that we would place funded studies with industry to develop tenders. It is too early to tell whether we shall pursue airships in these funded studies.
